{"text": "First off, I'm not into visual novels, in fact I hate them. I always thought they were boring and for the most part for me it was. But this game really caught my eye with its visuals, the drink gimmick and the riff of the music in the trailer. So I got suckered in and bought the game. It was probably one of the best decision I've ever made. The lore is interesting and well built, the characters are well written, have their own unique personality, goals, and looks. And to add onto the list of reasons why I love this game I've been really a fan of a bar or a food stand tale where a client would unwrap their life stories and problems, and this game did that kind of storytelling the best among the magna, novels, and movies I've seen. Not to mention a great soundtrack to boot. The main mechanic in this game is also quite interesting, usually in visual novels you always have a clear cut pathway laid to you in decision making, it works for the most part but this game changes it up and have the drinks served affect the endings, the way the characters treat you, and not to mention secret dialogues that spills the beans on mysterious regulars and urban legends. So keep your eyes out on your client's favorite drinks or drinks they might hate.... Maybe a secret drink here and there and randomly serve them to get even more interesting dialogue. Therefore Replay value of this game is great, there's different character endings to unlock, secret dialogue, etc.... Overall this game is fantastic and I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a great story, characters and music. Even to those who hate visual novels.", "appid": "447530", "steamid": "profiles/76561198039875201", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1532174400.0}

{"text": "Serious Sam is not a low-budget Doom, like some seem to think. It isn't doom at all, in fact, it really is just it's own thing.  At it's worst, it's a slog; a pain to get through certain parts, and can be just plain frustrating due to the fact that the game puts out way too much at once.  However, at it's best, it's an extremely fast paced, action packed, high adrenaline horde shooter. Basically, it's like an FPS version of Smash TV. If you enjoy a game which has a heavy focus on fighting armies of enemies at once, then you might like it. It is kind of niche, but I really enjoyed Serious Sam TFE, TSE, and Revolution. Even though they're not fancy and all that junk, they still fire bullets and that's the point of FPS games right? You can accept contracts to earn extra money (You get three hours to complete one). You get $3,000 for each class you unlock (Rifleman, Medic, Engineer, Sniper.) {"text": "This game has lots of mixed reviews - some of them praise it, some of them hate it.  It actually costs 4$/‚Ç¨, so it's not even that cheap. Some users called this game pretentious, since the story looks random and shallow with little effort employed in the graphical sector, while the gameplay itself isn't really even an arcade/puzzle - rather, it's just a simple platformer with few movement options. Other users praise the abstract artwork, the minimalistic environment, the relaxing atmosphere and such. The Italian translation of the game is horrible, so I think you should stick with the English one.. the first screen selection in which you're allowed to choose between easy, hard or normal literally reads \"pass the game upon another difficulty in order to see analternative story ending\" (yeah, \"analternative\" is written like this in the Italian page). Anyways, the whole environment is really minimalistic. It's all 2D, you're a red cube, you can move left or right and everything is black and white. Obviously, the goal is to reach the end in each level. There are lots of taglines and messages between the levels, it's up to you I think to judge if they're enough philosophical or not.. just keep in mind that many translation suck that much that you won't be able to enjoy anything. Most of the times you won't even know what you're doing and why some of the black figures are moving and why they're moving that way, but in the end the game looks like a simple minimalistic puzzle game which doesn't present some noticeable kind of uniqueness in my view. Plus.. it's slow. Apart from the three endings, there are 55 levels and you'll have to move your cube through a mix of texts and abstract black figures which will constantly move - remind that you'll be able to go only left or right.  All in all, the graphics get better and better between the levels and I don't know, I agree with those who say that the game is pretentious since it's no philosopical masterpiece, but on the other side it has a nice mix of good music, nice graphics (not in the minimalistic levels themselves, but rather in the animations in-between) and somehow challenging but simple gameplay. It's more a matter of timing and waiting rather than pure arcade ability, given the limited moves your cube has. But it's ok. I'd recommend the game, all in all. It can be enjoyed by lovers of relaxing puzzles or semi-philosophical matters. In a general way it's not a masterpiece, but it's a nice effort. New mechanics are added as you'll progress with the levels, making the game somehow more challenging.", "appid": "511160", "steamid": "profiles/76561198356141989", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "15", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1589803200.0}

{"text": "Jogo muito bom, gr√°ficos lindos, jogabilidade boa, um excelente suporte, atualiza√ß√µes frequentes  e uma evolu√ß√£o muito grande que fez com que hoje esteja com uma boa presen√ßa na √°rea dos jogos.", "appid": "230410", "steamid": "profiles/76561198063698166", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1480161600.0}
{"text": "Do I recommend this game? No. You can read the reviews and decide for yourself whether you think you'll be able to stomach it, otherwise I see little value in trying to play it for simple reasons such as liking the art, or metroidvanias, or puzzles, or because a lot of people say it's amazing. Something I've noticed while playing La-Mulana is that an overwhelming majority of modern (and not-so-modern) games have quite some of the so-called \"handholding\" in some shape or form. This includes games being touted as having nearly no handholding such as Dark Souls (I'm sorry, I need to draw comparisons simply because other people probably draw them but for the wrong reasons, and it's a good difficult game that is similar but also incredibly different). Generally, by what is considered \"good game design\" nowadays, you'd enter the game world and have some sort of guidance, some visible path to follow, even it isn't very evident. In Dark Souls 1, the indications you're given initially are kind of broad (ring the 2 bells, one is up and one is down), but once you find the stairs to Undead Burg you're pretty much set for the whole game. You might need to use a guide here and there but it's not that big of a deal and you would've probably figured things out if you kept at it for long enough. Dark Souls is even kind enough to give you a whole tutorial level, with doors that open gradually so you don't get lost and can progress linearly. And this is considered having little handholding. In La-Mulana, you're told you're going to explore the eponymous ruins, and then you just appear in a village, and the only help you can get in-game is an old man that is almost useless. Where are the ruins, how do I enter them? I don't know, figure it out. Once you enter the ruins, you go around exploring, maybe end up going through 4 different areas way too deep inside that are too hard for you, and maybe you manage to go back to the first area, then think,  Where is the boss? What is my goal? Where do I go? What is the purpose of this game? Figure it out. Of course, that's not how you're really supposed to start off. There's a manual, and a short guide, longer than the manual, which give you some indications on what to do and how to progress through the game, and there's even hints on some puzzles and a convenient list of all items in the game. But even then, you're mostly on your own. Though the manuals don't leave you as clueless as you would be otherwise, I think it's very interesting to observe how greatly the design philosophy of this game differs from practically everything I've ever played. And beware, because even if you have a smooth start, you will be dropped into that state of cluelessness again and again throughout your playthrough. It's not quite just a game, it's really some ancient ruins. Most games want you to play and beat them, but this one doesn't care. It doesn't care about you, it doesn't care whether you play it or not. It's up to you to try to go through it, and sometimes the game will go from apathy to outright resistance. It will actively and aggressively go against you to prevent itself from being solved. As it turns out, this is not the first game to do something like this, as it was mainly inspired by  , which I've yet to play. And coincidentally,   (which I've never played) a few days ago, just before finishing La-Mulana, which describes the exact same things I had observed in this game, so I was somewhat illuminated because I understand there must've been a whole generation of games like this, and it makes sense why they were so highly regarded and considered as innovative. However, you can bet La-Mulana (and its sequel) has a massively increased scale compared to any games it might've taken inspiration from. Now as for the actual content of the game, which other people have talked enough about, but I have to include anyways. La-Mulana has these stone tablets scattered all around the game, and it all basically comes down to writing/screenshotting them all down, then using their hints to solve puzzles. What is a \"puzzle\", you ask? Just about anything. Pushing buttons, using specific items in specific places, doing sequences of arbitrary actions, killing certain enemies, etc. What happens when you solve a puzzle? They generally activate or unlock something, sometimes in the same room, sometimes in some other place (figure out where by yourself). You must take note of almost everything: the names of rooms, the layouts of floors, each place that looks like a puzzle for which you don't have the solution yet, and just about anything that seems of interest. La-Mulana is also an action platformer, with a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up NES-style \"commitment\" jump, where you can't change your direction mid-air if you jumped directionally. Hard to explain through text, but it's another barrier the game puts before you, and you need to master it if you don't want to die or fall off things all the time. You must also learn about the hitboxes of your attacks and such, and bosses tend to have ridiculously small hitboxes as well. Overall, not sure if I would say the action/platforming is enjoyable, but it's at least somewhat satisfying when you finally manage to take control over this unwieldy character, and the upgrade items (mainly health) also feel great as you can increasingly disregard all these uncomfortable aspects of the game as you progress. These upgrades feel less like \"oh yes I got cool ability now! look at all these places I've opened up! and look at all this cool stuff I can do!\" and more like \"HAHA YES I CAN ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• OVER THE GAME IN SO MANY WAYS NOW (and also opened up some very few places)\" I must also mention that solving puzzles and reading stone tablets serve the function of unveiling the lore little by little. Dark Souls is lauded for its storytelling method of having everything cryptically hidden in item descriptions and NPC dialogues, but it almost never forces you to understand this lore, because it's a game that wants you to play it, so it allows you to just beat up enemies and bosses if you so wish. In La-Mulana you HAVE to understand the lore, because it's intrinsically connected to the gameplay and the puzzles. It's a very rare game that requires both intense gaming ability and intense puzzle solving ability, whereas most games tend to focus on either one or the other. In conclusion, this game is an uphill battle against it, full of frustration and despair. So why should you play it? Hell I don't know, maybe you really want to know what the ultimate secret of La-Mulana is, maybe the lore you started discovering is just   alluring and you just   to know all of it. Maybe you find the puzzle solving fun, even though some of the puzzles are ridiculously obtuse and require extreme inspection or precise thinking. I can tell you it's definitely an adventure, though. PS: Writing concisely here because I ran out of characters. Get people that have beaten the game to give you hints, or play it in parallel with others to complement each other and not have to rely on walkthroughs. Use the manual and the guide (  and  ). The manual is terribly translated but the guide is fine. You should just read the whole guide before starting to play the game. The manual is short and badly translated but it has a full item list. The guide doesn't have the item list but it has everything the manual has plus wayyyyyy more info (especially useful is \"How to progress\" part in page 38). The \"guide\" isn't a full walkthrough, it's just a stepping stone for beginners, so don't be afraid to rely on it as much as possible. TL;DR: 10/10 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• this game", "appid": "230700", "steamid": "profiles/76561198034301657", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "22", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1589803200.0}

{"text": "When it comes to early access, you're bound to come across bugs here and there but to have such a responsive development cycle and such a highly playable pinball game puts the icing on the cake in all aspects of the pinball world. I got my feet wet into the Zaccaria Pinball world by purchasing the retro tables and it brings me back into the world of Microsoft Pinball Arcade - well except it's been moderninzed and upgraded with high detail visuals. Speaking of - This game does not play like an early access game at all, it plays like a finalized product. Despite some quirks of the games, the developers have been fixing the bugs on a regular basis when they have been reported. The pricing structure is kind of strange although much cheaper than some of the big name pinball games out there.  I would like to see groups or smaller packs of games at more affordable prices versus the $50 price tag for everything. Maybe packs of 4 or 5 tables at a time and you got a deal. But though... It's not a deal breaker. I guess I need to experiment with the demo tables to see which ones I like and don't and go from there. {"text": "Good game.", "appid": "730", "steamid": "profiles/76561198175303433", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1454328000.0}
{"text": "I first watched a You-tube Let's Play of this game about a year ago and immediately added it to my Steam Wishlist.  This is a simulator based in the age of sail and will not appeal to everyone. It's based around captaining and sailing ships of the period in and around the Caribbean and it takes time to sail from point A to point B.  Many folks won't have the patience for this kind of immersion.  It reminds me of the Silent Hunter submarine simulation series in that way. Though this game is beautifully rendered and nowhere near as buggy as those games.  I'm a fan of the Hornblower books and have been for decades, so I'm steeped in the terminology, lore and mythos of this era. I've played Port Royal 3, Sid Meier's Pirates and this one features most of the likeable aspects of those games (minus the music (and the dancing!))  Plus this is an MMO which you can choose to play on a PvE server (if you prefer playing aginst an AI) or a PvP server (if you enjoy the more challenging intelligence of other players) or you can play on both!  On the down side the learning curve is steep and there's no in-game tutorial yet, but there is a wiki and many many you-tube tutorials, plus the game features well designed, easy to use in-game chat facilities and the user community is very helpful. As soon as Steam announced their 60% off sale I jumped at it and for me its the best gaming investment I've made in a long long time.  On the other hand if you're one of those folks who needs a LOT of hand-holding and a more dumbed down gaming experience this may not be for you.   I'd advise that you check out any of the many You-tube Let's Plays and decide for yourself. Steam's \"buy it and try it and refund it if not satisfied\" will not be a good strategy here as the limited play time before being unable to refund the game will not be sufficient for you to make any kind of progress in the game. Downsides:  Currently no in-game soundtrack  After mastering the basic challenges PvE lacks challenges. Steam Achievements MAY change that when the game goes \"live\"", "appid": "311310", "steamid": "profiles/76561198103468164", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "21", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1509278400.0}

{"text": "I'm going to give a listed synopsis of the premise and introductory events to avoid specific spoilers. And because of this, the pacing of the game is completely different to that of the original games. It's essentially up to you how you want to get things going. Structurally, you go on your ship [The Tempest], talk to your crew mates, go on missions and... explore. Same loop. But there is   no impending doom. The Reapers are not coming to obliterate any and all organic things. There is a main threat, but it's been going on for a long time and isn't really time sensitive. [Not yet anyways.] However, your arrival has acted as a catalyst. Imagine. If you're more inclined to the seedy underbelly of Omega, Kadara has you covered. With resources tight on the Nexus and the other Arks missing. Unrest was inevitable. It's not just the ‚Äúlocal fauna‚Äù you'll need to deal with out in Andromeda.  In fact, leadership on the Nexus itself has been in strife from the get go. Kesh, Tann, Addison and Kandros all try to subtlety manipulate the Pathfinder. Lack of resources and stress affects people differently. You might notice many of the other species were left back in the Milky Way. Saved for the second wave. Curiously, when pressed ‚Äî and perhaps paradoxically ‚Äî Tann cites technical problems with the Quarian Ark as to why they're not in the first wave. The main difference in Andromeda is that the combat is vastly improved even from ME3. I make the contention that the combat is better than 2 or 3 and not ME1. As ME1 did not have poor combat. It simply was a different genre. It was a much more of a pure RPG. Whereas now it's much more based on action. ‚Äî  As you explore your galaxy map, you select which planets to go to and land on. You have a vehicle now called the Nomad. Which is both upgradable and customizable. At times this makes the game feel a bit like ME1 did when exploring with the Mako. ‚Äî which is really nice. Although some planets are too small and condensed for that kind of travel. Such as Havarl ‚Äî an Angara jungle planet.  When you perform tasks that make the planets you travel more sustainable for life, you get AVP [Andromeda Viability Points] which allow you to wake blocks of citizens from cryo and subsequently aid you in your quest to colonize the Andromeda galaxy. There are three new species you'll find within this game. The Kett, who serve as the main antagonist. However, I got a distinct ‚ÄúFirst Contact War‚Äù vibe from some of the interactions. Referring to the first contact humans had with the Turians. ‚Äî The Angara, a wide spread species within the Heleus Cluster. And lastly, a slightly more enigmatic synthetic species referred to as ‚ÄúThe Remnant‚Äù. SAM is able to interface with Remnant technology found throughout the galaxy where no Angara has before. Or Kett for that matter.  You can level into Tech, Biotics or Soldier trees which will further level any associated profiles that SAM can use to add buffs ‚Äî Sentinel, Vanguard, Adept. I went heavy into the tech tree and leveled the Engineer profile which increased damage of Tech powers and Constructs. You can prime targets with tech and biotic combos for heavy hitting damage. Though, if you do many of the side missions, you'll be able to craft a pretty well-rounded Ryder. Andromeda embodies 'passing of the torch' in every way it could be interpreted.   You're no longer required to build up paragon or renegade points, a system I never liked. You're not limited by dialogue options for not having a certain reputation. But there is plenty of romance, so don't be afraid to flirt or you might miss your chance. This is something I find myself stuck in ambivalence regarding. This sentiment is also shared for Dragon Age: Inquisition. Both Inquisition and Andromeda share a similar idea in that the very premise of the game is such to impress and/or assuage misgivings about the protagonist's presence. And there are quite literally hundreds of quests to go on. {"text": "OOTP18 is the latest version of a great baseball simulator.  I noticed two significant changes from OOTP16 (last version that I owned).  First, the 3D view of the game.  Pervious versions that I played was basically text-only with minimal graphical reflections of the action.  This addition is a very nice touch and aligns with the play-by-play text that is presented.  Since I tend to play all the games (not sim), I have enjoyed this feature much  more than I would have thought.  Another little nuance that I thought was great is after a completed game, there is a nice recap of the game along with player \"quotes\" and a probability of winning line as the game progressed.  The other significant change that I found is the new \"challenge mode.\"  Although this does not fundamentally change the game, you can now compare your results to the other OOTP18 players out there.  Challenge mode restricts a couple things in the game (e.g. player editor, long-term simulation), but does enable your score to be recorded against other players.  These two changes were worth getting OOTP18.   For those that are unfamiliar with the series, OOTP18 is a baseball game for all of the armchair GMs and Managers that are out there.  This is the third iteration that I have played (OOTP16 and OOTP10) and the game continues to evolve very well.  As with the pervious couple of versions, OOTP has the MLB and Player's Association license.  As a sports fan, you always wonder about how you would remake your favorite team into a dynasty and now is your chance.  You start with the ability to manage a MLB team today or any year from 1871.  You may also choose one of several International Leagues that are available.  From day one, you can delegate authority to the AI or control everything.  From the GM perspective, this includes player and staff contracts, free agent signings, major/minor league roster moves, drafts, trades, and organizational budget allocations.  From the manager perspective, you set your pitching rotations and lineups.  At that point, you can dive into playing each baseball game or sim through the days.  All the statistics from MLB history is available and its fun starting from scratch in 1871 to learn about the early pioneers in baseball.  The other great thing about the OOTP series is the ability to create your own fictional leagues, uniforms, and designs with the large user-mod community. The bottom line is that this game is a must have for people who love baseball.", "appid": "465650", "steamid": "profiles/76561198007833990", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "12", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1495368000.0}

{"text": "–ü–æ –≤—Å–µ–ª–µ–Ω–Ω–æ–π –¢–æ–ª–∫–∏–Ω–∞ –¥–µ–ª–∞–ª–∏ –Ω–µ–º–∞–ª–æ –∏–≥—Ä —Ä–∞–∑–ª–∏—á–Ω—ã—Ö –∂–∞–Ω—Ä–æ–≤ , –Ω–æ –±–æ–ª—å—à–∞—è –∏—Ö —á–∞—Å—Ç—å –∏–ª–∏ –±—ã–ª–∏ –Ω–µ—É–¥–∞—á–Ω—ã–º–∏ , –∏–ª–∏ –±—ã—Å—Ç—Ä–æ –∑–∞–±—ã–≤–∞–ª–∏—Å—å . –ò–∑ –¥–æ—Å—Ç–æ–π–Ω—ã—Ö –º–æ–∂–Ω–æ –≤—Å–ø–æ–º–Ω–∏—Ç—å —Å—Ç—Ä–∞—Ç–µ–≥–∏–∏ —Å–µ—Ä–∏–∏ Battle For Middle-Earth , –Ω—É –∏ –Ω–∞ —Ö—É–¥–æ–π –∫–æ–Ω–µ—Ü War In The North , –∑–∞–∫—Ä—ã–≤–∞—è –≥–ª–∞–∑–∞ –Ω–∞ –º–Ω–æ–≥–∏–µ –µ–µ –º–∏–Ω—É—Å—ã. –ù–æ –µ—Å–ª–∏ —Ç—É –∂–µ WITN –µ—â–µ –º–æ–∂–Ω–æ —Å–≤—è–∑–∞—Ç—å —Å –∫–∞–Ω–æ–Ω–æ–º , —Ç–æ Shadow of Mordor –Ω–∞–¥–æ —Ä–∞—Å—Å–º–∞—Ç—Ä–∏–≤–∞—Ç—å —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –∫–∞–∫  —Ö–æ—Ä–æ—à–∏–π —Ñ–∞–Ω—Ñ–∏–∫, –Ω–æ —ç—Ç–æ –≤–æ–≤—Å–µ –Ω–µ –¥–µ–ª–∞–µ—Ç –µ–µ –ø–ª–æ—Ö–æ–π, –∞ —Å–∫–æ—Ä–µ–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç. –°–ª–µ–¥–æ–ø—ã—Ç –ß—ë—Ä–Ω—ã—Ö –í—Ä–∞—Ç –¢–∞–ª–∏–æ–Ω —Ä–µ—à–∏–ª—Å—è –≤—Å–µ–≥–æ —á—Ç–æ –∏–º–µ–ª –≤ –æ–¥–∏–Ω –º–æ–º–µ–Ω—Ç. –ß—ë—Ä–Ω—ã–µ –í—Ä–∞—Ç–∞ –∑–∞—Ö–≤–∞—Ç–∏–ª–∏ –æ—Ä–∫–∏, –µ–≥–æ —Å–µ–º—å—è —É–±–∏—Ç–∞, –≤–ø—Ä–æ—á–µ–º, –∫–∞–∫ –∏ –æ–Ω —Å–∞–º, –Ω–æ —Å—É–¥—å–±–∞ —Ä–∞—Å–ø–æ—Ä—è–¥–∏–ª–∞—Å—å –∏–Ω–∞—á–µ. –ü–æ—Å–ª–µ —Å–º–µ—Ä—Ç–∏, –≤ –¢–∞–ª–∏–æ–Ω–∞ –≤—Å–µ–ª–∏–ª—Å—è –º–æ–≥—É—â–µ—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–π –¥—É—Ö –≤–µ–ª–∏–∫–æ–≥–æ —ç–ª—å—Ñ–∏–π—Å–∫–æ–≥–æ –∫—É–∑–Ω–µ—Ü–∞ - –ö–µ–ª–µ–±—Ä–∏–º–±–æ—Ä–∞ . –¢–∞–ª–∏–æ–Ω–∞ –∏ –ö–µ–ª–µ–±—Ä–∏–º–±–æ—Ä–∞ —Å–≤—è–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç –ª–∏—à—å –æ–¥–Ω–æ - –±–æ–ª—å –∏ –∂–∞–∂–¥–∞ –º–µ—Å—Ç–∏. –°—é–∂–µ—Ç –≤ –∏–≥—Ä–µ —è –±—ã –Ω–µ —Å–∫–∞–∑–∞–ª —á—Ç–æ –æ—á–µ–Ω—å –¥–ª–∏–Ω–Ω—ã–π, –æ—Å–æ–±–µ–Ω–Ω–æ –µ—Å–ª–∏ —É–±—Ä–∞—Ç—å –º–∏—Å—Å–∏–∏ –ø–æ —É–Ω–∏—á—Ç–æ–∂–µ–Ω–∏—é –≤–æ–∂–¥–µ–π —É—Ä—É–∫–æ–≤ , –Ω–æ —ç—Ç–æ –Ω–µ –∑–Ω–∞—á–∏—Ç —á—Ç–æ –æ–Ω —Å–∫—É—á–µ–Ω. –°–æ–±—ã—Ç–∏—è —Ä–∞–∑–≤–∏–≤–∞—é—Ç—Å—è –¥–µ–π—Å—Ç–≤–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ –æ—á–µ–Ω—å –±—ã—Å—Ç—Ä–æ, –¥–∞–∂–µ –µ—Å–ª–∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å —Å—é–∂–µ—Ç–Ω—ã–µ –º–∏—Å—Å–∏–∏ —Å –ø–µ—Ä–µ—Ä—ã–≤–∞–º–∏ –Ω–∞ –≤—ã–ø–æ–ª–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è —Ä–∞–∑–ª–∏—á–Ω—ã—Ö –¥–æ–ø –∑–∞–¥–∞–Ω–∏–π ( –æ –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã—Ö –ø–æ–∑–∂–µ ) . –ü–æ —Å—é–∂–µ—Ç—É, –¢–∞–ª–∏–æ–Ω –≤—Å—Ç—Ä–µ—Ç–∏—Ç—Å—è —Å —Ä–∞–∑–ª–∏—á–Ω—ã–º–∏ –ª–∏—á–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—è–º–∏. –¢—É—Ç –≤–∞–º –∏ —Ç—Ä—É—Å–ª–∏–≤—ã–π –æ—Ä–∫ –ö—Ä—ã—Å–∞—Ä–∏–π, —á—Ç–æ –º–µ—á—Ç–∞–µ—Ç —Å—Ç–∞—Ç—å –≤–æ–∂–¥—ë–º , –∏ –≥–Ω–æ–º –æ—Ö–æ—Ç–Ω–∏–∫ –¢–æ—Ä–≤–∏–Ω , –¥–∞ –¥–∞–∂–µ –≤—Å–µ–º –∏–∑–≤–µ—Å—Ç–Ω—ã–π –ì–æ–ª–ª—É–º —Ç—É—Ç –∑–∞—Ç–µ—Å–∞–ª—Å—è, –ø—Ä–∏—á–µ–º –∏–≥—Ä–∞—é—â–∏–π –¥–∞–ª–µ–∫–æ –Ω–µ –ø–∞—Å—Å–∏–≤–Ω—É—é —Ä–æ–ª—å.  –¢–µ–Ω–∏ –ú–æ—Ä–¥–æ—Ä–∞ –ø–æ—Ö–æ–∂ –Ω–∞ –Ω–µ—á—Ç–æ —Å—Ä–µ–¥–Ω–µ–µ –º–µ–∂–¥—É  –ê—Å—Å–∞—Å–∏–Ω–æ–º –∏ –ë—ç—Ç–º–µ–Ω–æ–º ( —ç—Ç–æ –≤—ã–¥–µ–ª—è–ª–∏ –ø–æ—á—Ç–∏ –≤—Å—ë ) , –Ω–æ –µ—Å—Ç—å —É –Ω–µ–≥–æ –æ–¥–Ω–∞ —Ñ–∏—á–∞, –≤—ã–¥–µ–ª—è—é—â–∞—è –µ–≥–æ –Ω–∞ —Ñ–æ–Ω–µ –Ω–µ —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —ç—Ç–∏—Ö –∏–≥—Ä, –Ω–æ –∏ –æ—Å—Ç–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã—Ö - –°–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º–∞ –ù–µ–º–µ–∑–∏—Å. –í –ú–æ—Ä–¥–æ—Ä–µ –∏–¥—ë—Ç —Å–∞–º–∞—è –Ω–∞—Å—Ç–æ—è—â–∞—è –≥—Ä—ã–∑–Ω—è –º–µ–∂–¥—É —É—Ä—É–∫–∞–º–∏ –∑–∞ –≤–ª–∞—Å—Ç—å : –æ–¥–Ω–∏ –æ—Ö–æ—Ç—è—Ç—Å—è –Ω–∞ –∫–∞—Ä–∞–≥–æ—Ä–æ–≤ –∏ –æ—Ä–≥–∞–Ω–∏–∑–æ–≤—ã–≤–∞—é—Ç –ø–∏—Ä—ã, –¥–∞–±—ã –ø–æ–¥–Ω—è—Ç—å –∞–≤—Ç–æ—Ä–∏—Ç–µ—Ç, –¥—Ä—É–≥–∏–µ –∂–µ —É—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—è—é—Ç –∫–æ–Ω–∫—É—Ä–µ–Ω—Ç–æ–≤ –∏ –≤–µ—Ä–±—É—é—Ç —Å—Ç–æ—Ä–æ–Ω–∏–∫–æ–≤. –ö–∞–∂–¥—ã–π –æ—Ä–æ—á–∏–π –∫–æ–º–∞–Ω–¥–∏—Ä - –ª–∏—á–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å, –ø–æ–º–Ω—è—â–∞—è –ø–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø–∫–∏ –¢–∞–ª–∏–æ–Ω–∞. –ï—Å–ª–∏ –≤—ã –ø–æ–≥–∏–±–ª–∏ –æ—Ç —Ä—É–∫–∏ –∫–æ–º–∞–Ω–¥–∏—Ä–∞  , —Ç–æ –æ–Ω  –æ–±—è–∑–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ –Ω–∞–ø–æ–º–Ω–∏—Ç –≤–∞–º –æ–± —ç—Ç–æ–º - —ç—Ç–æ —Å–∞–º—ã–π –±–∞–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã–π –ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä. –°–Ω–∞—á–∞–ª–∞, –¢–∞–ª–∏–æ–Ω —Å–º–æ–∂–µ—Ç —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —É–±–∏–≤–∞—Ç—å —É—Ä—É–∫–æ–≤, –Ω–æ –±–ª–∏–∂–µ –∫ –∫–æ–Ω—Ü—É –∏–≥—Ä—ã –æ–Ω –Ω–∞—É—á–∏—Ç—Å—è –ø–æ–¥—á–∏–Ω—è—Ç—å —Å–≤–æ–µ–π –≤–æ–ª–µ –Ω–µ–∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã—Ö –∫–æ–º–∞–Ω–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤  –∏ –≤–æ—Ç —Ç—É—Ç –Ω–∞—á–∏–Ω–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è —Å–∞–º–æ–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–µ—Å–Ω–æ–µ. –í–∞–º –ø—Ä–∏–¥–µ—Ç—Å—è –ø–æ–º–æ–≥–∞—Ç—å –∏ –∑–∞—â–∏—â–∞—Ç—å —Å–≤–æ–∏—Ö –ø–æ–¥—á–∏–Ω–µ–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö , –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã–µ, –≤ —Å–≤–æ—é –æ—á–µ—Ä–µ–¥—å , —Ç–∞–∫–∂–µ –ø–æ–º–æ–≥—É—Ç –≤–∞–º –≤ —Ç—Ä—É–¥–Ω—ã–π –º–æ–º–µ–Ω—Ç. –ó–¥–µ—Å—å —è —Ä–∞—Å—Å–∫–∞–∂—É –æ —Ç–æ–º, –∫–∞–∫–∏–µ –∑–∞–¥–∞–Ω–∏—è –≤—Å—Ç—Ä–µ—á–∞—é—Ç—Å—è –≤ –¢–µ–Ω—è—Ö –ú–æ—Ä–¥–æ—Ä–∞. 1) –°–±–æ—Ä –≠—Ç–∏–ª—å–¥–∏–Ω–æ–≤ –∏ —Ä–∞–∑–Ω–æ–≥–æ   –¥–æ–±—Ä–∞ - –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–µ –∫–æ–ª–ª–µ–∫—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä–æ–µ –ø–æ–æ—â–µ—Ä—è–µ—Ç—Å—è –º–µ—Å—Ç–Ω–æ–π –≤–∞–ª—é—Ç–æ–π , –æ–ø—ã—Ç–æ–º , –∞ –≤ —Å–ª—É—á–∞–µ —Å \"–∞—Ä—Ç–µ—Ñ–∞–∫—Ç–∞–º–∏ \", –ø—Ä–∏ –Ω–∞—Ö–æ–∂–¥–µ–Ω–∏–∏ —Ç–æ—á–∫–∏ –≤–æ—Å–ø–æ–º–∏–Ω–∞–Ω–∏—è , –ø—Ä–æ—Å–ª—É—à–∏–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ —Ä–∞–∑–≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä–∞ –º–µ–∂–¥—É –ª—é–¥—å–º–∏/—É—Ä—É–∫–∞–º–∏ –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã–º —ç—Ç–∞ –≤–µ—â—å –ø—Ä–∏–Ω–∞–¥–ª–µ–∂–∞–ª–∞. 2) –û—Ö–æ—Ç–∞ –Ω–∞ –º–µ—Å—Ç–Ω—É—é —Ñ–∞—É–Ω—É –∏ —Å–±–æ—Ä —Ç—Ä–∞–≤ -  –∑–∞–¥–∞–Ω–∏—è, –Ω–∞–∑–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã—Ö –≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä–∏—Ç —Å–∞–º–æ –∑–∞ —Å–µ–±—è. –ó–∞–¥–∞–Ω–∏—è –≤–µ—Å—å–º–∞ –ø–æ–ª–µ–∑–Ω—ã–µ, —Ö–æ—Ç—å —Å—Ä–∞–∑—É –∏ –Ω–µ —Å–∫–∞–∂–µ—à—å . –û—Ö–æ—Ç–∞ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–µ—Å–Ω–∞ —Å–∞–º–∞ –ø–æ —Å–µ–±–µ , –Ω—É –∞ —Å–±–æ—Ä —Ç—Ä–∞–≤...–Ω—É —Ç—É—Ç —É–∂ –Ω–∞ –ª—é–±–∏—Ç–µ–ª—è. –î—É–º–∞—é, —É—Ä—É–∫–∏ –±—É–¥—É—Ç –ø—Ä–µ–±—ã–≤–∞—Ç—å –≤ —Å–æ—Å—Ç–æ—è–Ω–∏–∏ —à–æ–∫–∞ , –≤–∏–¥—è –∫–∞–∫ –¢–∞–ª–∏–æ–Ω —Ç—É–ø–æ –±–µ–≥–∞–µ—Ç –ø–æ –æ–∫—Ä—É–≥–µ –≤ –ø–æ–∏—Å–∫–∞—Ö –Ω—É–∂–Ω–æ–≥–æ —Ü–≤–µ—Ç–æ—á–∫–∞. 3) –õ–µ–≥–µ–Ω–¥—ã –ú–µ—á–∞/–ù–æ–∂–∞/–õ—É–∫–∞ –¢–∞–ª–∏–æ–Ω–∞ - {"text": "First, this game should come with a hazard warning. I've already broken a controller thank ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and had myself nearly smashed into my kitchen wall playing this. It's that immersive and adrenaline pumping. I've actually decided not to play this game until I can expand my play area because otherwise there won't be anything unbroken in my room before long. Second, be prepared to face the hidden devil in you, because this game will bring out the worst of you. I don't care if you are a little white bunny or a fluffy little kitten, this game will turn you into a blood-thirst mindless man-slaughtering monster. That feeling of grabbing someone's head and stabbing his chest with a dagger in your hand or cutting someone's leg right off with one single sword slash is ... disturbingly satisfying. When you are in that setting, you just couldn't help but enjoy killing people and hearing the sound of your sword piercing their body and the blood bursting out. There's something about it. Maybe it activates the reptilian part of your brain or something. The game is pretty bare-bones at the moment (even after a year and a half in EA), with 4 'sandbox' maps where you can fight waves after waves of AI enemies using different weapons (and one spell). That's it. Zero story, quest, progression. Nothing. So, don't expect anything beyond a basic VR gladiator simulation for now. For future development, I would suggest adding sex, drugs, alcohol and gambling into this game, and making it the best all-round debauchery simulator with a bit of RPG elements and a light storyline. Just imagine that: You are a gladiator in Rome or a medieval mercenary, having just slain your enemies in an epic battle with their blood fresh on your hands, and then get drunk at the local tavern and have a blast with a wench of your choosing. Oh yeah, give me some of that. Still a fun game in its current shape though. {"text": "I have played a lot of the xbox 360/ps3 versions of Just Cause 2 as well as the PC version so the comparisons are well educated. Ok this game franchise is not known for its deep story and this is no exception. The story is over the top and absurd yet that is also what I like about it. Some of the characters are quite fun and entertaining while others just kind of float into the background. The dialogue and voice acting is over the top and cheesy and some moments in the cutscenes are actually quite funny. However, the story is still pretty half baked and more annoying than intriguing. I should just re-name this whole section to, ' ' as that sums up the gameplay pretty accurately. Following the themes of the JC series, there is a lot of blowing stuff up in this game and I have to admit the in-game explosions and dynamic physics is absolutely stunning and when a bunch chain together I cannot help but marvel at the scope of it! What makes this better is the fact that you can WINGSUIT. THEY ADDED A WINGSUIT. This is probably the most fun I have ever had just traversing the environment in a game and I rarely used fast travel. Along with the wingsuit there is the traditional parachute and grappel hook which have all ben improved massively to increase the fun factor. The grapple hook system has taken a few hints from modders as now you can have multiple tethers and even retract them which combines for some devestating fun! Whether it's tethering cars and people to explosive structures or a helicopter to the ground, it is definately the most fun way to engage enemies in combat. Seeing as the shooting is pretty average with not very many guns and they don't even feel that different from one another. Now one thing that I hated was the gear mod system. To unlock better skills you need to complete challenges (races, shooting galleries, etc) to unlock gear mods. The challenges are frustrating and not fun (most of the time) and I just ended up getting more frustrated than thrilled. However, the speed and exhileration you get from the wingsuit in the challanges meant that I always tried them! The vehicle controls are also absolutely shocking and no fun at all! They handle awkwardly and swerve uncontrollably. The game looks amazing and I am playing this on ultra and high settings 1080p FXAA at a solid 70-75 fps and the game looks amazing. The lighting and reflections look stunning with brigh colours and stunning country sides. Every area is fantastic to explore and I never tired of these areas and environments. However, the performance significantly drops during explosions to about 45 FPS during the MASSIVE explosions which is quite understandable but also makes me question why they made them so big anyway (it is almost excessive). The character models are quite detailed and well animated too with pretty medicore voice acting. Overall, the game has fun gameplay of shooting and taking over settlements but can get quite repetitive. The movement is fast and fun and this game is great to play when you just want to switch off.", "appid": "225540", "steamid": "profiles/76561198058876618", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1460030400.0}

{"text": "EDIT:  OK...so I changed my recommendation to Thumbs Up after consulting a video to get un-stuck.  As is usually the case when I get stuck in a game, the solution was  face-palming simple, and once I figured that out, I realized that I actually enjoyed the game...alot.  I still hate side-scrollers, but for me, Little Nightmares is less of a game per se, and more of an experience.  As I said in my original review, the game is an apple pie alamode treat for the senses.  And on that basis alone, I would recommend a purchase (but only on sale).  EDIT If side-scrolling baby-eating is your thing, this is your game.  Otherwise, get a Big Mac...dollars better spent. Allow me to elaborate.  It's important to remember that the thumbs up or down is NOT an assessment of whether I think this is a good or bad game.  It's whether or not I would recommend it to others; or in other words, would I tell my friends to spend their money and time on it.   When I bought Little Nightmares, I didn't realize that it's basically a side-scroller.  And I hate side-scrollers...absolutely HATE them.  Movement direction is all thru the WASD keys, and frankly...I hate it.  Right now I'm stuck at a point where I have to navigate my little waif down a long banquet table while evading the fat, greedy hands of the dinner guests.  Fifty attempts and I always end up a canape. I realize that's on me...it's not the developers fault that my button-mashing skills are sub-par.  But to friends (and anyone else) of like mind, I can't recommend a purchase.  I'm not saying it's a bad game...it's not.  In fact, the artistic style is amazing.  The developers have successfully combined 'cute' and 'grotesque' into a unique visual treat.   BUT...it's a SIDE-SCROLLER! Bottom line...if you enjoy side-scrollers, Little Nightmares definitely belongs in your collection. {"text": "Wildlands has its issues but I think the good outweighs the bad. Graphically it‚Äôs one of the best looking games on the market at the moment, almost photorealistic at times. The draw distance is amazing, flying in a helicopter and seeing trees, roads and towns kilometers away is great and it makes the game world feel massive in scope which it already is but it‚Äôs nice to actually be able to see how big it is physically without things popping in from the distance. The game has the ubisoft formula where the map is cluttered with all kinds of things to extend the length of the game and it‚Äôs to a massive extent in this game because the map is so huge. There is an abundance of side missions, upgrades and collectables in each area/region of the map making this a really long game. A lot of the game is collecting weapons and weapon mods, skill points and doing side missions which make the game feel like its on auto pilot mode at times but because I played in coop it lessened that feel quite a bit because we often found our own way to keep the game fun. I think this is a really good coop game because there is a lot of ways to cooperate and play the game together like the way you approach missions together or the way you navigate around the world together. The game also has that unpredictability and randomness feeling that open world games often do which leads to a lot of fun, weird and unscripted moments.  I think the gameplay is pretty good overall, the shooting feels great, headshotting feels great, especially with a sniper and syncing shots together with your coop mates is awesome. The game feels really satisfying when you complete a mission in stealth but it‚Äôs also fun to just go loud at times and I love the amount of equipment and customization that‚Äôs available. The vehicles feel and handle pretty good, the animations are good but the transitions between first and third person and changing between the two when aiming can take a while to get used to and even when you are used to it it‚Äôs not exactly a smooth tradition because you have to aim down the sights first before you can change perspective and then once you do you have to check if you have to change the shoulder position of your character, doing this while in a gunfight can feel pretty clunky. I like how challenging the game is overall and how relentless the enemy ai is but there are times where the bulls*it meter goes up like an enemy having perfect accuracy from a hundred meters away while dual wielding uzi‚Äôs. We started saying ‚ÄòI got lazered‚Äô at times when we got downed because sometimes the enemy feels like its shooting lazers at you that can‚Äôt miss, it can get pretty annoying. Overall if you‚Äôre looking for a coop game to play with the bois this is one worth playing through and one that you can spend a lot of hours in.  7/10", "appid": "460930", "steamid": "profiles/76561197961143209", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "29", "votes_funny": "2", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1546344000.0}

{"text": "I love it when a game comes out of nowhere and blows you away with how unique it is. An open world murder mystery in a world which is something like if Charles Stross' The Laundry Files were set in a neon-lit drugs&alcohol fueled 80s LA beach. You play as Lady Love Dies, official investigator for the Syndicate, which is the fancy name for the corporation/cult of blood-magic wielding immortals who have created a pocket universe. In this dimension they have created their perfect little beach paradise and also incidentally worship dangerous inter-dimensional alien gods. Someone has killed all the members of the ruling council of the Syndicate, and everything points to the perpetrator being a demon-possessed Citizen named Henry. Henry is one of the many enslaved normal human beings who have been kidnapped from earth do menial and dangerous jobs in \"paradise\", and also to be sacrified to the gods, so Henry certainly has a motive. The case looks a little bit too open&shut and the suspect a little too convenient though for the being called Justice, and Lady Love Dies is allowed to return from exile so she can walk around the island and find clues, interview suspects and gradually uncover the truth. Gameplay is split between first person 3D open world point&click adventuring with some light platforming, and visual-novel style dialogues as you interview Dr Doom Jazz, Crimson Acid, Witness-to-the-End and the other Syndicate members who still remain in paradise. The gameplay is fine, but it is the soundtrack and unique setting that sets this game apart. If you liked Obra Dinn I think there is a fair chance you will like this too. Don't miss it.", "appid": "1160220", "steamid": "profiles/76561197970369196", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1599998400.0}

—á—É–≤—Å—Ç–≤–æ —Ç—Ä–µ–≤–æ–≥–∏, –∏ –∫–∞–∫–æ–≥–æ-—Ç–æ —Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–≥–æ —É–º–∏—Ä–æ—Ç–≤–æ—Ä–µ–Ω–∏—è. –î–∞–∂–µ –≤ –∫–∞–∂—É—â–∏–µ—Å—è –º–æ–º–µ–Ω—Ç—ã –æ–ø–∞—Å–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ —ç—Ç–æ —á—É–≤—Å—Ç–≤–æ –Ω–µ –ø–æ–∫–∏–¥–∞–µ—Ç. –í –æ–ø—Ä–µ–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–π —á–∞—Å –≤–æ–ª—à–µ–±—Å—Ç–≤–æ –¥–æ—Å—Ç–∏–≥–∞–µ—Ç —Å–≤–æ–µ–≥–æ –∞–ø–æ–≥–µ—è –∏ –ø—Ä–æ–∏—Å—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç —Å—Ç—Ä–∞—à–Ω–æ–µ - –≤–∞–º –≤–æ–æ–±—â–µ –Ω–µ —Ö–æ—á–µ—Ç—Å—è –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–æ –≤–∏–¥–µ—Ç—å: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤—ã, –æ–∫–æ–º–æ—Ç–∏–≤ –∏ –±–µ—Å–∫–æ–Ω–µ—á–Ω—ã–µ –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç–æ—Ä—ã, —É—Ö–æ–¥—è—â–∏–µ –∑–∞ –≥–æ—Ä–∏–∑–æ–Ω—Ç. –°—Ç–∞–Ω–æ–≤–∏—Ç—Å—è –ø–æ–¥–æ–∑—Ä–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ, –ø—Ä–µ–¥–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å—Å–∫–∏ —Å–ø–æ–∫–æ–π–Ω–æ —Å—Ä–µ–¥–∏ –æ–±–ª–æ–º–∫–æ–≤ –º–∞—à–∏–Ω –∏ –æ—Å—Ç–æ–≤–æ–≤ —Ä–∂–∞–≤–µ—é—â–∏—Ö —Å—É—Ö–æ–≥—Ä—É–∑–æ–≤ –Ω–∞ –æ–∫–µ–∞–Ω—Å–∫–æ–π –æ—Ç–º–µ–ª–∏, –ø–æ—Å—Ä–µ–¥–∏ –ø–æ—Ä–æ—Å—à–∏—Ö —Å–æ—Ä–Ω—è–∫–∞–º–∏ –∏ –ø–æ–ª—ã–Ω—å—é –ª—É–≥–æ–≤ –∏ –∑–∞—Å—É—à–ª–∏–≤—ã—Ö –ø—É—Å—Ç—ã–Ω—å, –≥–¥–µ –∫–æ–≥–¥–∞-—Ç–æ –±—ã–ª–∞ —Ü–∏–≤–∏–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏—è –∏ {"text": "forte smecher", "appid": "381210", "steamid": "profiles/76561198249103916", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1592827200.0}
{"text": "If you are the type of Call of Duty fan that I am, you most likely enjoyed the Black Ops (except the third installment maybe) and Modern Warfare games the most. And that's good! Because, for most of us, this is where the franchise peaked, both in quality and story-wise (if you play games like Call of Duty for the story). So now with possible rumours of Black Ops 4 on the way in 2018, I embarked on the quest of reviewing the series, and hopefully help some of you who still haven't made up your mind about your opinion on Call of Duty. I will say it straight from the beginning: the Black Ops series is worth it at the very least. Let's see why. So... you liked the story of Alex and David Mason? You liked the way those characters were built and the intense narrative? You want more of the soldiers you know and love? Lol, no, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you. Treyarch decides to throw all of that in the trash and start anew with a story that has absolutely no link to the previous Black Ops games. I'm gonna be 100% honest with you here, I didn't understand a single bit of Black Ops 3's tale that it's so desperately trying to deliver in an interesting way. Spoiler alert, it's not interesting at all. While the other games were engaging and had deep, beautifully constructed plots, BO3 is a story about... ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• if I know. You basically play as a custom character (don't expect any depth to the level of customization, it's about 3 faces and 2 caps and that's it) which loses his/her limbs in an operation that goes terribly wrong. Then you get on a mission to destroy...the...Illuminati or something. Honestly it's quite twisted. What I'm trying to say is that the campaign isn't in the last bit memorable. Not the characters, not your motives, not anything. It's just a big mess. That's probably why you see so many \"Train go boom\" memes and \"Black Ops 3 ending explained\" videos on Youtube. But the gameplay of the campaign in itself is alright. The new thing is that you have some new, enhanced abilities which are actually pretty fun to use. While many people don't take this game seriously because of the new movement mechanics, I can tell you the multiplayer here is quite solid. Unlike other CoD games, here you have specialists you can use in multiplayer instead of random/perk specific character models. These specialist have some abilities which give you an edge against other players, for example a bow with explosive arrows, invisibility, traps with nano-bees that kill any enemy that steps in them (it sounds ridiculous, I know), or some portable seismic charges that insta-kill nearby enemies (it may sound overpowered but you mostly get 1 or max 2 kills with it because of the short range and the fact that sometimes you don't even get to use them since you have to jump to trigger them and the enemy can kill you in mid-air). The new movement system with sliding and thrusters which allow you to glide or jump higher is actually well-implemented and smooth. It can make for some interesting plays or can be very frustrating at times, depending on the situation. But overall, it's a nice experience. This is the part where Black Ops 3 shines the most. This is, without any doubt the best CoD game for zombies mode. Yes you have the classic 4 dlc formula for unlocking the current zombies maps, but there's also a dlc called \"Zombie Chronicles\" which allows you to play better, remastered versions of almost all of the zombies maps in previous CoD games. That is just awesome. Besides the fact that, in the age of Steam Workshop, you have hundreds of user-submitted maps at your disposal, maps which are pretty damn good most of the time. Even if you don't buy any dlc, the user maps and Shadows of Evil (the zombies map you get by default) are still gonna ensure you have a blast if you buy this game only for this mode. My respect to Treyarch for this amazing, top-notch zombies experience.  Black Ops 3 is overall a pretty good game. Being the best Call of Duty for zombies mode and having a fun multiplayer mode, I say it's still worth the 60$ price tag. Just don't expect wonders from the campaign or, even better, don't even play it. PROS: +Steam Workshop allows for countless hours of fun with zombies maps +modifications to the multiplayer are a nice change of pace +Zombie Chronicles dlc is worth every single penny CONS: -horrible story  My Black Ops 1 review:  My Black Ops 2 review:", "appid": "311210", "steamid": "profiles/76561198056739666", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "66", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1518091200.0}

{"text": "10 / 8", "appid": "8980", "steamid": "profiles/76561198412857275", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": "2", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1531569600.0}
{"text": "Reviewed at 6th of August 2017, Immediately after Early access release. (Will update as necessary.) I was a kickstarter backer for this game. Positive recommendation based on understanding these pointers: 1. Only buy the game if you are into experiencing the long term route of seeing how it develops! As of right now, there isn't that much content to experience, the game is very bare bones as well as has a lot of glitches and roughness. I am on a very high end PC and am experiencing occasional performance issues. Lower end machines will likely struggle. 2. The game is dependent on simulation of life gathered from currently known scientific fact and as such relies heavily on a \"make your own adventure\" style gameplay experience. A lot of it's charm comes from as accurately as possible depicted dinosaurs. If you're not into the abovementioned thematics, or want a more finished product, this might not be a game for you right now. Wait until it's further into development. That being said, if you're a hardcore dinosaur fan, you'll probably have a good time. Now that's out of the way, here are some of my opinions: The game is very atmospheric, you feel constantly on your guard which gives you a sense of belonging into the game world. Night time can even be a bit spooky, since it gets hard to spot any predator that's hunting you... And at first you also don't know all the things that are out there, so you're especially wary. Immersion is already rather good! I think going forward the game needs to push this angle to keep a grip on the player. That being said, one thing that breaks the immersion are the way the controls respond as of right now. They're not terrible by any means, but very rough in some spots. You don't always feel in tune with your character, and especially at times some input may lag or not register at all and you're not sure why it happens. Did I do something wrong as a player, or did the game just buckle. These are minor complaints all in all, but do erode the immersion aspect of the game ever so slightly, when at times you feel like you're struggling to get your character to do what you need it to do. Some more fluidity and responsiveness would go a long way. My other bigger issue with the game right now is the map. Meanwhile it's not terrible, it doesn't particularly stand out in any spots either. There doesn't feel to be much to see, which in turn doesn't make you feel like exploring. I understand the importance of keeping it close to real life simulation to hold true to the game's intent, but looking around, life has a lot of variety. I hope going forward the developers will add a bit more character to the environment. Some more distinct landmarks, small streams, boulder formations strewn around and that kind of thing...  I'm not sure if I'm expressing my thoughts on this matter very well, but let me summarize by saying that the world needs to feel a bit more full and alive. The feature for using scent to hunt is currently a bit underwhelming and I find myself playing mostly without it, relying more on watching my character's head movements and listening for skittering sounds. Both of which, are actually very neat ways of incorporating your senses into gameplay. Saurian is definitely worth your try if you're open minded towards experimental games and don't mind it if things aren't running smoothly straight away. The models for the animals are very beautiful as are their animations, so I got myself a bunch of good time from just admiring those. Saurian is trying to make an educational piece in a way that has quality as well as entertainment incorporated, and for these reasons alone it already deserves praise.", "appid": "587450", "steamid": "profiles/76561197977071031", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1502020800.0}

You will laugh at all the hysterical nonsense that is quickly woven together by the many communities inside this game, you will get angry at all the features they lock behind paywalls, and you will cry when you kiss your $10 dollars goodbye. {"text": "It's hard to explain how this game totally pulls you into its world in the way that only classic adventure games can. Its strengths are beautiful backgrounds and objects, well-developed characters, and a great mystery story that keeps you guessing until the very end. There aren't many puzzles that will stump you; the focus is on exploring this fictional Oxford and discovering the next part of the story. Sam, the protagonist, can use magic tricks to manipulate people, but this mechanic doesn't let you be as creative as I first imagined; you just choose tricks from a book and execute them according to the instructions. Still, it's a nice way to continue the themes of the game--illusion, deception, and magic--into the point-and-click gameplay. Now that I've finished the game, I find myself really missing the atmosphere and the characters. (FYI, one character is a bit of a \"funny Jewish guy\" stereotype, and the main romance in the game isn't developed at all, but these are small complaints.) The voice acting is solid; the soundtrack is great; the animations leave a bit to be desired, but the still art is fantastic. The game is broken up into chapters, and two chapters equal one in-game day: first you play in the morning as Sam, then in the afternoon as Dr. Styles, another neat feature.  Overall, Gray Matter is definitely worth purchasing for anyone who likes the sound of adventure-game-meets-graphic-novel. It has some of the best writing of any modern game, and boasts a surprisingly complex plot that takes time to unravel. Lots of buried clues and rewards for an observant player. I was surprised to find that this game hasn't reached a more general audience, because it's fantastic. Both sad and funny at times (sometimes unintentionally funny), it's also a great experience to share with a friend. P.S. I ran into a bug where cutscenes at the end of the game kept repeating, but was able to choose \"skip scene\" in options to overcome this.", "appid": "260570", "steamid": "profiles/76561198031826746", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "13", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1407844800.0}

{"text": "2020 will probably stay in the memory of first person shooter fans as the Doom Eternal year, but I'd contend that Serious Sam 4 also deserves some love, if anything, because of how committed to fun it is. Sam Stone's latest outing (though canon-wise it's his first) is Croteam firing in all cilinders, with some pretty excellent shooting backed up by Damjan Mravunac's masterful work with the soundtrack. It's obvious that the developers have taken into account the criticism for Serious Sam 3's boring setting and weird attempts at being a modern military shooter, because this game will take you to varied locales, while at the same time laughing in the face of MMS mechanics (though for some reason they kept ADS on the pistol and the assault rifle).  I'd say that my only complaints would be that performance isn't as good as it could be (though Croteam is working on patches, and have already released a hotfix that improved things on my end) and that the Legion System is only used in two specific parts of the game (though it's as impressive as expected). Otherwise, I'm more than happy with Serious Sam 4. It's rough around the edges, but packed to the brim with action, fun and surprisingly sweet moments. {"text": "Amazing Rogue-Like game, fast gameplay for a turn based card-builder genre. Note my hours arent correct, had an issue where steam wasnt tracking my ingame hours... (At time of review steam says: 1.1hours, but statistics in game say 25h 03m) Early-Access leaves me wanting more: -Only two characters available in \"Early-Access\" (or at least I havent unlocked more that I know of) -Pretty short but fun, reaching floor 51 and seeing the spire heart in an hour or so hours (Most likely going to be more content the more \"Damage\" you do to the spire heart) -Great Music adds perfect background setting -Repetitive but fresh gameplay, same monsters over and over but different encounters and AI playstyle is decent for first few hours of play -Unlocks are challenging but not un-obtainable -True Rogue-like form. Being overwhelmingly strong because you had a few good card draws or an AI decided to buff rather than finish you vs. Being trapped with no way out scenarios -Amazing late game/Higher floor gameplay. The more you progress the stronger you get (Should go without saying) but being able to outplay and progress late game is intergrated seamlesly without becoming too overpowering Would highly rate this game to anyone who likes rouge-likes alike. Best card-builder from my experience. Unsure why, but manually launching the game from steam library resolved it. -If you run the game in windowed boarderless in its current version it flickers but in windowed or fullscreen it runs fine. -Game doesnt regognize im launching it. {"text": "There are box-moving puzzles out there and then there is FullBore... I hope I won't sound very biased saying that FullBore stands a bit aside from most of such games. Granted, it did not invent absolute novelty in the old genre. Instead, it used a different approach to it. There is a quote floating out there, \"metroidvania with boars\". I guess you can say so, because FB features a lot of exploration aspects and freedom of movement. And more than that, a lot of puzzles with less platforming. You aren't forced to solve them (many of them are optional), but the way these placed and designed - simply attracts you like a butterfly to the light. What could be hard in simple box moving and dirt digging..? Don't even get me started on puzzles, these are simply fantastic. They make   sense that by the end of figuring out another one you will feel like a pure genius. They deliver insane amount of feel of accomplishment. Soon you will realize it is not about the gem or a secret you want to get or discover, it is about solving the damn puzzle that taunts you. And the most interesting part is that none of the puzzles require from you any special ability or an item - it is all knowledge and experience. The way blocks and boxes work or interact with each other and your understanding of this mechanism is the key to solve all the puzzles. But hey, a fun gameplay is not the only thing FullBore can be proud of. Quite lovely and pretty 2D graphics with awesome lighting and \"fake\" 3D effect will catch your attention at once. They fit the game surprisingly well, just like an amazing soundtrack by \"The Adjective Plural Noun\". But this is something you'd better to experience yourself, rather then read about in in a sloppy review. Long story short - FullBore was quite pleasant surprise of 2013 for me (The First Dig, part 1 of the game, was released earlier; Steam version features full game). It came out of nowhere and since then I fell in love with it. Really, how could you not love these adorable little boars? You won't get bored with Full Bore.", "appid": "264060", "steamid": "profiles/76561197995702460", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "78", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1399032000.0}

{"text": "Pros: +Detailed environment +Cyber Punk atmosphere +Great sound & voice acting +Interesting storyline +Mixture of combos Cons: -Combat was lackluster -Lengthy boss fights -QTEs (Quick Time Events) -Wonky Controls  -Clones From a perspective point of view from seeing Paris from the skylines to the sewers it was all beautifully detailed, bright colors, detailed, fleshed out and was amazing for cyber punk atmosphere. I‚Äôd walk around and just look at all the arts and the finer details of Paris. It felt solid. When it came to voice acting and the sounds, I felt like I was in the streets of Paris overhearing people talk, androids assisting others, garbage can falling over; or even the sewers with water dripping and footsteps in the sludge. It was done very well and I felt immersed in the game. If you‚Äôre getting creepy vibes when going through the sewers and trying to get out because you know you‚Äôre being watched, then it was a good feeling of a well detailed game. I find the story to be interesting because it shows us how fragile our own mind, our own secrets, and how our thoughts from happiness to anger to sorrow are our own and makes us the person we are today. It had that sense of storytelling throughout the game and even at the ending. It solved the why, the what, the how, the who, the shebang. Honestly, at first I thought the game wouldn‚Äôt cover some of the questions I had, but at the end it reassured me, so I‚Äôm glad and it was a well put story even if it was short. I think they could have added more content, more history or even just thrown more cyber punk lore into the mix. The combos are a nice touch. You get new fighting abilities the more points you get from killing enemies and bosses. You‚Äôll get a sequence to start off with such as punch, punch, and punch. In this sequence you can add a punch that does damage, heals you, and helps you on your cooldown abilities that hastens it cooldowns, or helps chain the sequence into itself for even stronger attacks and higher combos. It‚Äôs fun and interesting to test out all the sequences and moves. At times though the fighting wasn‚Äôt always fluid and I‚Äôd dodge in a direction that wasn‚Äôt intended or leap frog away from someone and still get hit. Which made the combat stressful and irritating at times; you punch and kick someone, dodge their missiles or punches and then somehow still get hit. It was irritating since I‚Äôm not a big fan of these fighting styles. With the combat being shady at times that means what? The controls. The controls were clearly made for a controller hands down. They did a good job for the most part, but rewinding a memory, or moving around while hitting someone wasn‚Äôt as fluid compared to Batman titles using a mouse and keyboard. With that being said brings in the QTEs or also known as Quick Time Events. I‚Äôm not a fan of this and never will be. Does it add style, hype and make you act quickly to what‚Äôs currently going on? Yes, but I‚Äôve never been a fan; just MY opinion on the matter. The boss fights were lengthy. They weren‚Äôt really hard they were more of a time waster until the next chapter and you basically kept using the same sequence to make your cooldown abilities kick off that much faster so you can use them on the boss (DDoS on Warden lady, UGH!). The other problems were the lack of enemies and clones. Clones for days. Clones, clones everywhere. I mean, for how detailed the game is they could have mix and matched or added different degree of detail on some of the uniforms (Total War series).  All and all it was a great game. If you‚Äôre into QTEs, using a controller for combo fights, a good visual and audio experience with a fascinating storyline, then I would suggest you buy this title. 7.5/10. Now for the Multiplayer that most of the Call of Duty players play anyway. I enjoyed it most of the time i played it, the maps were average in size, not to small and not to big. Most of the guns feel similar and the perks is pretty balanced except you are forced to use Assassin because of the UAV spam. (Jugabilidad Realisticas) (Partidas Sin \"Hacks\") (Efectos exelentes y muy reales.) (Optimizacion, es un juego bastante optimizado,claro no creo que corras en un pc de 2GB de ram y una tarjeta grafica mala,pero si esta bien optimizado.). Sus contras: (Jugadores,aver si que es cierto que hay aveces que te dan dolor de cabeza los camperos, pero es un juego con mucho campers) (Ping, si lo malo es que si no estas en Europa no tendras buen ping.) (Servidores, esto es casi igual lo del ping,muchos servers con 200 de ping para arriba hay algunos con 198 pero nunca entra nadie. PD: soy de Uruguay.) {"text": "+The game gives you a lot of options. For example you can create your own kingdom, join another kingdom, lead a bandit group, be a merchant and invest in enterprises, support someones claim to the throne and much more +Unlike the total war games, in this one you control your character while at the same time giving orders to your troops. This allows for much fun to be had and the combination of combat and strategy is fantastic +There are a lot of weapons to choose from +The leveling system is extensive +It's very addictive -graphics look outdated -basic lore -companions can be annoying -if you create your own kingdom you dont get enough recognition -the diplomacy system is preety much non-existent", "appid": "48700", "steamid": "profiles/76561198133961254", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": "2", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1507723200.0}
{"text": "D4: Dark Dreams Don't Die is a true hidden gem. I consider it to be a masterpiece. It is among my favourite games, and one of the finest examples of the interactive movie subgenre. It's also among the most immersive games, both overall and specifically due to how great it is with giving you a lot of different emotions. It's sad, mysterious, weird, funny, and somewhat scary. It has a great balance of brightness and darkness, and not because it only plays on contrasts, but because it has bright, dark, and in-between moments, and they are placed appropriately, as well as equally good at what their purposes are. While some might claim the game is unfinished, it's not exactly so, it's more of a somewhat unfinished game, but worth it without a doubt. You can see it this way - even if a truly beautiful painting is unfinished to some degree, it still remains beautiful. Now let's talk about the essential video game aspects.  \"This is the story of a man with a very strange fate\". The protagonist, David Young, lost his wife, her last words were \"Look for D\". Now he investigates the past to find out who is D, reveal the mysteries of vicious Real Blood organization, and take his revenge on this D. We have a lot of different characters with very interesting, memorable, and often unusual personalities. They all play at least important enough role, some are true mysteries while others are closer to more obvious but nonetheless fascinating kind. The protagonist himself is quite a mystery, and we don't know exactly whether what he experiences \"real\" or not, or to what degree. But that's enough details. The story itself is awesome in both quality and how interesting it is. I can recommend this game even solely for story for anyone who likes mysterious, emotional, unusual, and immersive stories. Another huge plus is how many theories about who is who and who did what this game can give you, and there are a lot of such mysterious things. One such thing is the very nature of what's happening. And a lot of others related to the characters, who are far from poorly written or uninteresting, they are the opposite of it. It's so sad that the story of D4 likely will never be finished. But it's not an uncommon thing for interactive movies and TV shows. They are not finished in terms of the story until the last game or season, or at least only somewhat finished. Yet a lot of such arts are still awesome or at least just good creations that for sure worth experiencing. This game and its story is one such example. But there is more to this game. My rating to the story aspect - 10/10. I don't have any major problem with it. Only very few minor ones, but they don't harm the game in any serious way. The game has both rather unusual and typical gameplay for interactive movies, it has a lot of unique or not commonly used mechanics, but at the same time it's not too far away with its gameplay from Telltale Games' interactive movies. I like both exploration parts of gameplay and stunt scenes, it's not hard to play this game yet it provides you with challenges. One of the things about gameplay is that the game is designed for at least two playthroughs. Because you can't unlock all achievements in one playthrough, and the game will be a bit different during the second and further playthroughs. It's a cool feature, although the fact that during second and further playthroughs you can't leave the game without losing your progress (of each episode, plus prologue). It's not too big of an issue with episodes not being too long, but it can be an issue, so it's better not to exit the game if you want to keep your progress during replays. It has a high replay value, but not very high. Overall the gameplay is not one of the most important aspects of D4: Dark Dreams Don't Die yet it's great and lacks any serious problem. 10/10 The hardest one for me to judge, because of how in-between it is in terms of quality. Visuals could have been a bit better, more polished. Yet I find them beautiful and very fitting nonetheless. Besides, it's an interactive movie, and many games of this subgenre have neither realistic nor too beautiful visuals in the usual sense, but still wonderful for what they are. I really like facial animation, I really like the whole style of this game. So while it's not the strongest aspect of it, I can give it 10/10 rather easily because for me there is no serious issue with it and it's very well done overall.  The aspect that it's the hardest to describe, the deepest one, as well as something that is directly connected to you personal experience. What I can say is that it's one of the strongest games in terms of atmosphere, it is one of those games that feels right, its atmosphere makes you feel better, although often not in that typical way, I didn't expect it to be as good in this aspect yet it turned out to be super good. A truly wonderful atmosphere. 10/10.  Here we are, the final aspect of the five, and in this case, the strongest one. Because unlike the story, it is not unfinished in any way, in fact, both the sound and music are very rich, very diverse, very fitting, and awesome even if we experience them outside the game. A String and Salvation are among the most beautiful pieces of sad and calm soundtracks I heard, Drunk Dead is a catchy heavy song, Only Love and My Little Peggy are top notch romantic songs, both musically and lyrically, Theme of D4 is an atmospheric and memorable theme song. Detective of the Past is a very cool character song. Overall, it's truly superb in this regard, certainly among the best games I played if we take Sound & Music aspect. For sure 10/10.  So if we combine the ratings of each five aspects and find mathematical average, it's a solid 10/10. Doesn't mean it's perfect or has no issue at all. No game is like that. Perfect for me is  something that is so good that you really feel it's something special to you, as well as something super good that you enjoyed experiencing a lot. This game is certainly perfect for me, if we take this definition.  It's definitely something you should play, no matter what your preferences are, it's worth a buy even for a full price, even more so with a big discount. A worthy experience without a doubt, and perhaps a game that will truly give something unique to your mind and your heart.", "appid": "358090", "steamid": "profiles/76561198357077837", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "34", "votes_funny": "3", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1595160000.0}

{"text": "Honestly. Where to begin? The game is brilliant. A VR experience you should have if you own a VR headset. This is hands down one of the best Early Access VR Games you could buy right now. So much tender love and care has been put into every little nook and cranny of the guns you can use that it brings a tear to my Patriotic striken eye. (And I'm not even American!) The developer - Anton - is so dedicated to this project and so happy to work on it with bi-weekly updates with new content, bug fixes and as so heavily active in the community that he should be a Role Model for how you develop and run an Early Acess title. Enough sucking the developers ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. Lets get into the meat of it. (eheheh... meat... puns...) Pros: - Multiple scenes for you to explore, play in and test weapons in the game alongside a few very fun objective based maps with interactables. Such as AI spawning, target practice (With multiple settings and variations to play.) - Over a hundred guns to play with. And as advertised, each is accurately modelled and functions like the real life counterpart. {"text": "Íµ¨ÏäµÍ≤© „ÖàÍ∞ôÎÑ§", "appid": "271590", "steamid": "profiles/76561198836460365", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1586520000.0}
{"text": "When I first saw this game, it was not how I expected after watching a few videos before I get my hands on it. The game is pretty easy to play at first. But if you rush things up without getting prepared first, you ended-up dying over and over again, surrounded by 20 mobs shooting you from every direction or stabbing you with stingers or swords. Or you ended up getting your butt handled by an AI player just randomly sliding in and kicking you in the face because you were not paying attention to your 6 or the mini-map due to how small it is. The game is pretty much a third-person shooter rather than your average hack & slash RPG game until you can finally get your hand on a photon blade, then it changes everything. But if you're thinking about only carrying a sword with you as Kirito does, then you will be in for a big surprise once you realize that not every enemy are reachable from the ground. And don't think for a second that you can just jump and slash your enemies that way, because this doesn't feel like Devil May Cry when you do it. You can't defy the law of gravity when doing it as Dante or Nero does. You can do a couple of activities and side quests to kill time and boredom such as bounty hunting, collecting bounties by eliminating some awfully mean AI players for money, experience points, weapons, accessories, blueprints for outfits and materials for weapon upgrades. Or becoming a player killer yourself by locating them on the map for experience, combat ranks, and money, etc. There are boss hunting missions that you can get from the PVE squadron and hunt down unique bosses. You can do a dungeon assault which involves shooting down or slashing everything inside to collect rare loot, tons of experience points and materials. If combat becomes slightly boring for you, there's still treasure hunts. The world map is still pretty big after all. Somewhere on the map, there are a few treasure chests waiting for you to be looted in places you probably never thought looking. You could always go on a date with your favorite original character and see what they think of you and your reputation. Buy or craft an outfit of your choice and gift it to somebody you would like to see wearing permanently or temporarily through the game. The game itself got a pretty huge completion ladder for you to climb and keep you busy for a while. There's an affinity rank that you can increase for every original characters and also non-original characters to unlock some hidden events. Some can be pretty useless, but they're there for you to complete if you feel like completing every single thing in the game, no matter how useless they are. There's also various weapons, skills and gadget proficiency that you can increase as well to improve their efficiency. You could always join a co-op mission with other players and go hunting unique bosses or engage yourself in a PVP against other players to show off your skills or see who's the best! Edit: With the new downloadable contents added to the game, I have to say that it's really completing the game this time. There's just so much stuff to do now, I don't know where to begin. The grind is real however. If you're hoping to get loots and materials easily, you will be disappointed. Other than that, the game is not perfect. No games are perfect as far as I know. Sometimes you will encounter some bugs, especially for photon blade users. Switching from a firearm to a sword while aiming will get you stuck in an aiming position while wielding a photon blade. You can luckily fix this little issue by jumping or rolling. Charging towards your enemy at full speed with a certain skill while you're near to an obstacle like a wall or a rock can cause your character to be stuck in a falling state for an indeterminate amount of time, making you look like you're floating while moving around. It can be very annoying. Sometimes, skills won't active due to multiple reasons, costing you a cooldown anyway. The game doesn't like it when I tab out, causing some spike-lags and stuttering, leaving me with two choices, restart the game or deal with the pain which can also affect the gameplay greatly. Like while running, a random spike-lag occurring just at the right time could boost your running speed immensely until you stop running. And finally, the AI teammates. Their behavior is somehow questionable. Most of the time, they act like they know what they're doing, kicking butts and getting you back on your feet like some pro. But other times, if you are down, they tend to roll around your downed body even though nothing is attacking them. And there's a certain character which is a personal AI you will get at the beginning of the game. He or she is very particular, full of happiness and awkwardness most of the time. If you are down on the battlefield, this one will not just roll around you, but also take time to wave at you for some reasons. Fortunately, this can be changed from the AI emotions settings. Before I end this review, I'd like to say that the game is in Japanese with English subtitles. If you are fluent in Japanese, then the game is very interesting to follow. But if you don't understand Japanese at all and you don't like reading subtitles, then you will be disappointed because there are about 60 hours if not more of pure voiced dialogs that you need to go through. You can always skip them all entirely with a single press of a button/key, but then you could miss some important or funny moments. Well, I believe that's pretty much it for now. I think I covered the most important parts of this review. If there's anything I am missing, just let me know and I will try to add it here. Thank you for reading this review. I hope it was worth your while. Keep being awesome and have a fantastic day!", "appid": "626690", "steamid": "profiles/76561198088996579", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "68", "votes_funny": "2", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1521892800.0}

You play as captain Blascowich and, of course, your biggest desire is to overthrow that horrible, fascist regime.  Without spoiling too much: The story is kind of predictable and the characters are (for the most part) very one-sided.  The game lifes, without question, of the action or (if you want) silent operations. Because you can, most of the time, choose wether you want to engange the enemy head on with explosives and shotguns or the silent way with knifes and silenced pistols. Batman via Kevin Conroy and Joker via Mark Hamill both who originally voiced the characters from the Batman Animated Series where Harley Quinn was born to later become officially part of the comics back in the 90's. The story keeps you wanting more, Catwoman keeps you hooked with her mini missions within the story, Joker's sitatution in Arkham city keeps you wondering from start to finish.  I laughed, I cried, I shouted in victory, and even hid in fear from enemies sometimes especially one particular boss I will not spoil just incase anyone is trying this game for the first time.
