{"text": "yes", "appid": "730", "steamid": "profiles/76561199063853475", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1593864000.0}
{"text": "1st of all if I could I would give DayZ a mixed review. Since I cant do that, I have to give it a thumbs up, because even though it is a very flawed game, its positives outweight negatives, mainly thanks to mods. Anyway DayZ is definitely not a game for everyone. I would mainly recommend it to players that are willing to sacrfice hours to boredom, frustration and anger in order to experience one of most unique games that is out there. Before you begin, please get a microphone. DayZs biggest charm is in encounters you have with other players and without microphone, you will be a kill on sight target and most of DayZs unique appeal will be lost to you. Meeting other players and interacting with them is one of few things that will keep you playing.Anyway In DayZ your main goal is to survive. You do that by scavenging same looking houses, cities and airports. You have to take care of your hunger, thirst, get weapons and various equipment - if you ever played a survival game, you know what I am talking about. In DayZ it is not easy to find stuff and it might take you hours to get anywhere, but you have to prepared for that. Once you get some gear and are not killed by zombies, enviroment or other players, you have few options - get even more gear, go to an airport for some PvP action, try to find some friends or enemies at coast, build a base, repair a car or just explore your surroundings. There is no concrete goal here, you can do whatever you want and while that may sound appealing, it is not nearly as good as it sounds. Most of time you will be searching for food, ammo and other basic necessities, getting shot from behind or dying to some weird bug. Things like repairing a car or base building take too much time and can be easily ruined by one stray bullet to your face. This will get boring after some time and thats when you will realize that there isnt really that much to DayZ in terms of content. So whats the point? Why do people keep coming back? Its other people. Like I mentioned in the beginning, encounters and interactions are what makes this game interesting. Once you get spend hours building your character, every encounter will be a dangerous one. Will that guy you see be friendy or will he shoot on sight? Should I risk it, or take him out before he sees me? Or maybe he will be friendly and we can be friends. OR I might  pretend I am friendy and then shoot him in the back. There are endless posibilites on how each encouter plays out. Most of time it ends in firefight and thankfully DayZ has pretty good shooting mechanics, along with great sound effects so you can hear every bullet for miles away and even ones that just barely missed you. Each PvP moment will be filled with adrenaline, where you have to think about what enemies next move and try to outsmart them. These moments are why everyone keeps coming back, even if they say they hate the game, unfortunately you cant get this feeling anywhere else outside of DayZ. I say unfortunately because DayZ is plagued with bugs, boredom and hollow content. The thing is, you are gonna be interacting with others for minutes, but scavenging and running around for few hours in between. Also mods are great and I would recommend trying them out, if you decide to buy DayZ, they offer a lot of cool features, like new maps, traders, new guns, clothing and a lot more. So overall DayZ is a unique game that can offer you someting no other game can, along with hours of boredom and frustration and it is up to you to decide if you it worth your time. Full Review here:", "appid": "221100", "steamid": "profiles/76561198044956970", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "49", "votes_funny": "7", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1578571200.0}

{"text": "A game which manages to balance on the edge of being extremely annoying, yet somehow still extremely addictive. Playing with a good group of friends lets you talk trash while looting, and then ramp up the action and focus on strategy when the bullets start to fly. Using the environment to your advantage is the key in this game, and this in combination with the realistic gunplay makes PUBG my favourite BR game out there today. The biggest downside of this game seems to be the knock out and revive function. Or rather, the way the players \"abuse\" it. Getting knocked almost always results in you being instantly flushed (permanently killed), which makes for some increadibly annoying gameplay. This means you now have to sit around watching your teammate(s) play out the rest of the round, if they don't decide to instantly kill themselves so that you can start another round together. I wish there was another way to handle this mechanic, but PUBG Corp seems adamant about keeping the game as it is.  Another drawback are the patches, or rather the sometimes game breaking bugs that each patch seems to bring.  Negatives aside, I still find myself coming back to this game ever so often, simply because the core is very well crafted.", "appid": "578080", "steamid": "profiles/76561197977230237", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1574942400.0}

–ø–µ—Ä—Å–æ–Ω–∞–∂–∏). –ù–µ—Ç—Ä—É–¥–Ω–æ –ø—Ä–µ—Å–µ—á—å —Ö—É–ª–∏–≥–∞–Ω—Å–∫–∏–µ –ø–æ–ø–æ–ª–∑–Ω–æ–≤–µ–Ω–∏—è –æ—Ä–∫–æ–≤, –Ω–æ —á—Ç–æ –¥–µ–ª–∞—é—Ç —ç–ª—å–¥–∞—Ä—ã –Ω–∞ –∑–∞–¥–≤–æ—Ä–∫–∞—Ö –ò–º–ø–µ—Ä–∏—É–º–∞? –ù–µ—É–∂–µ–ª–∏ –∑–µ–ª–µ–Ω–æ–∫–æ–∂–∏–µ –¥—É—Ä–Ω–∏ –ø–æ–ø–∞–ª–∏ –ø–æ–¥ –∏—Ö –ø–∞–≥—É–±–Ω–æ–µ –≤–ª–∏—è–Ω–∏–µ? –û—Ç–≤–µ—Ç—ã –±—É–¥—É—Ç –Ω–µ —Å—Ä–∞–∑—É ‚Äî –∏–≥—Ä–µ –ø—Ä–∏—Å—É—â–∞ –Ω–µ–¥–æ—Å–∫–∞–∑–∞–Ω–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å. –ì–ª–∞–≤–Ω—ã–π —Å—é—Ä–ø—Ä–∏–∑ –±—ã–ª –∏–∑–≤–µ—Å—Ç–µ–Ω –∑–∞–¥–æ–ª–≥–æ –¥–æ –ø—Ä–µ–º—å–µ—Ä—ã: –∫ –∫–æ—Å–º–æ–¥–µ—Å–∞–Ω—Ç—É, –æ—Ä–∫–∞–º –∏ —ç–ª—å–¥–∞—Ä–∞–º –≤ Dawn of War 2 –ø—Ä–∏—Å–æ–µ–¥–∏–Ω–∏–ª–∏—Å—å —Ç–∏—Ä–∞–Ω–∏–¥—ã. –ñ–∞–ª—å, —Å–æ–∑–¥–∞—Ç–µ–ª–∏ –º–∏—Å—Å–∏–π —Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∞–ª–∏ –±–µ–∑ –≤–¥–æ—Ö–Ω–æ–≤–µ–Ω–∏—è. –¢—É—Ç –Ω–∞—Å –≤—Å—Ç—Ä–µ—á–∞–µ—Ç –æ—Å—Ç–æ—Ä–æ–∂–Ω–∞—è –∫–∞–ª—å–∫–∞ —Å Dark Crusade –∏ Soulstorm, —Å —Ç–æ–π —Ä–∞–∑–Ω–∏—Ü–µ–π, —á—Ç–æ –∏–≥—Ä–∞—Ç—å —Ä–∞–∑—Ä–µ—à–µ–Ω–æ —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –∑–∞ –ö—Ä–æ–≤–∞–≤—ã—Ö –≤–æ—Ä–æ–Ω–æ–≤(–Ω–µ —Å—á–∏—Ç–∞—è DLC). –¢—Ä–∏ –ø–ª–∞–Ω–µ—Ç—ã, —Ç—Ä–∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Ç–∏–≤–Ω–∏–∫–∞ –∏ –±–µ—Å—á–∏—Å–ª–µ–Ω–Ω–æ–µ –º–Ω–æ–∂–µ—Å—Ç–≤–æ –æ–¥–Ω–æ—Ç–∏–ø–Ω—ã—Ö –∑–∞–¥–∞–Ω–∏–π (–ø–æ–ª–æ–≤–∏–Ω–∞ ‚Äî –Ω–µ–æ–±—è–∑–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω—ã–µ). –ö–∞–ø—Å—É–ª–∞ —Å —Å—É–ø–µ—Ä—Å–æ–ª–¥–∞—Ç–∞–º–∏ –ø—Ä–∏–∑–µ–º–ª—è–µ—Ç—Å—è –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–±–ª–µ–º–Ω–æ–º —Ä–∞–π–æ–Ω–µ, –∏ –Ω–∞—á–∏–Ω–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –∂–µ—Å—Ç–æ–∫–∞—è –∑–∞—á–∏—Å—Ç–∫–∞. –ê—É–¥–∏–æ—Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º–∞ –¥—Ä–æ–∂–∏—Ç –æ—Ç –≤–∑—Ä—ã–≤–æ–≤, —ç–∫—Ä–∞–Ω –∑–∞–±–∏–≤–∞—é—Ç —Ä–∞–∑–Ω–æ—Ü–≤–µ—Ç–Ω—ã–µ –≤—Å–ø–æ–ª–æ—Ö–∏, —Ö–ª–µ—â–µ—Ç –∫—Ä–æ–≤–∏—â–∞, —Ä–∞–∑–ª–µ—Ç–∞—é—Ç—Å—è –æ—Ç–æ—Ä–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∫–æ–Ω–µ—á–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏.  –û—Ç—Å—É—Ç—Å—Ç–≤–∏–µ –±–∞–∑—ã –∫–æ–º–ø–µ–Ω—Å–∏—Ä—É—é—Ç –∫–æ–º–∞–Ω–¥–Ω—ã–µ —Ç–æ—á–∫–∏ –∏ —Å–ø–µ—Ü–∏–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã–µ –∑–¥–∞–Ω–∏—è ‚Äî –∏—Ö –∑–∞—Ö–≤–∞—Ç –≥–∞—Ä–∞–Ω—Ç–∏—Ä—É–µ—Ç –±–µ—Å–ø–ª–∞—Ç–Ω–æ–µ –ê–≤–∏—Ç—É—Å —Å –¥–≤—É–º—è –ø–æ–º–æ—â–Ω–∏–∫–∞–º–∏ –ø—Ä–∏–∫—Ä—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç —Ç–æ–≤–∞—Ä–∏—â–µ–π –æ–≥–Ω–µ–º –∏–∑ —Ç—è–∂–µ–ª–æ–≥–æ –ø—É–ª–µ–º–µ—Ç–∞, –§–∞–¥–¥–µ–π –ø—Ä—ã–≥–∞–µ—Ç –Ω–∞ –¥–∂–µ—Ç–ø–∞–∫–µ –∏ {"text": "–°–∏–º—É–ª—è—Ç–æ—Ä –î–∂–µ–∫–∏ –ß–∞–Ω–∞", "appid": "307690", "steamid": "profiles/76561198046239764", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1561809600.0}
{"text": "Good Pizza, Great Pizza is an addictive yet simple cooking simulator which promises endless hours of fun for fans of the genre.  Originally being released on iOS/Android with issues of micro-transactions and frustrating advertisements, its debut on Steam has brought back the original core gameplay that everyone can adore and enjoy. + Simple, stress-free gameplay, only focusing on 1 order at a time. + Cute, wholesome characters and art. + Special events. + Customizable shop decorations, useful items and equipment upgrades can be bought through profits made.  + New toppings and recipes introduced throughout the game. + Steam achievements and trading cards (also includes in game achievements). - Can become very repetitive. As a casual cooking game,  the story is rather limited but is depicted in a very inclusive way, giving players the choice to skip it or not. This is particularly ideal for enthusiastic fans who are just looking for the gameplay of making some pizzas and aren't interested in any background information. The story is cleverly narrated and told mostly through the comedic Pizza News Network (PNN) which keeps players up to date on the town events that will impact the next day‚Äôs business as well as updates on our own shop and how it's perceived in the community. At the beginning, we start our adventure with a bare shell of a pizza shop and must work our way up from there, with the ultimate goal of surpassing our greatest rival, Alicante, who has an already successful pizza shop, just across the road.  The one element that stood out above most other cooking games I've played is its simplicity and relaxation qualities. I am used to juggling multiple orders, severe time pressures and seeing the constant barrage of unsatisfied customers pouring out the door. Good Pizza, Great Pizza is not that game at all, although there are some time pressures when baking the pizzas, only one order is accepted at a time and allows players to focus solely on the task in front of them. Each day is rather similar, getting 5-10 customers a day (depending on your specific upgrades) and fulfilling orders until 10pm. Customers will come one by one into the store and in a short description, describe what they're after. It can be plain and easy, such as 'onions please' or a bit more complicated, asking for a supreme, minus certain ingredients or even more convoluted, requesting half pizzas or specifying cooking time etc. When accepting the order, players can click 'okay' or 'what' if the order is not properly understood. Pressing 'what' will nudge the customer to clarify their order and say it in a different, clearer manner. Players have the option to click 'what' around 3 times, each time the buyer‚Äôs satisfaction level will diminish, effectively giving us less time to make the pizza and will generally receive less tips.  The money earned in each level can be used to purchase store upgrades, decorations or even to repair old equipment. An element that I really enjoyed was that the more ingredients used, the more money it cost, which also makes logical sense. Leaving it up to players to decide if we wish to use less of an ingredient and risk the customers satisfaction in an attempt to gain more profits. As the days continue, new toppings and items become available in the shop, including 'topping helpers' that automatically place the topping on the pizza when clicked on, in exactly the correct spots which can be quite visually satisfying. Without the 'helper' upgrades, players must click 12 times to place ingredients (onion, pepperoni, olives etc) on the pizza in any fashion. There are also some celebrity or random pop-up clients with entertaining orders and story elements scattered throughout the days. Currently, there is a special event involving gardening and gives players access to pesto sauce and purchasing seeds (Farmville, anyone?).  Although these minor game change-ups keep things interesting for a while, the games monotony is unavoidable and will become tiresome, especially if playing for long sessions, which I suppose is not how the game was intended to be played, regardless. However, in short bursts, it is an excellent, almost brainless game to wind down to after a long day.  After initially being released as a phone app, the graphics are what one would expect. Nothing revolutionary nor necessarily unique, however everything is clear and effortless to understand. The items available for purchase have a great range and allow the shop to feel very personal, cosy and inviting. Admittedly, I was never a fan of the repetitive music, but I would also never use sound if I played this on an app. I always prefer to have my own music on in the background when playing similar types of games like these. Good Pizza, Great Pizza is an excellent, casual cooking simulator. I am still not finished the main campaign, at almost 10 hours in and with the addition of new updates, special events and more, it already demonstrates a lot of promise whilst being currently in Early Access. Despite the slight monotony of the gameplay which can occur after long sessions, I recommend this to indie enthusiasts, interested in laidback cooking games.", "appid": "770810", "steamid": "profiles/76561198004496223", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "23", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1600516800.0}

{"text": "this game was kinda interviewed by Rooster Teeth, a random loadout game for anyone that loves small action, weird stuff, random explosions and blood and bones.", "appid": "208090", "steamid": "profiles/76561198124717818", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1398600000.0}
{"text": "Courtesy of the Indie-developers ‚Äì who I call developers that perceive gaming as an art ‚Äì we‚Äôve had many challenging computer entertainments. These delightful creations have often satisfied our ‚Äúacquired‚Äù taste for gut-punching difficulty, while also respecting our intelligence. Mini Night Island is one such game. It‚Äôs a 2D combat-platformer that takes three elements: slide, attack and defend and gives us a gaming threesome that we can‚Äôt but help but go back to.   Though the game is not without flaws, Mackinn7, the lone developer behind Mini Night Island, has tried, tested and put forward all best elements of a combat platformer you can think of, and gave it a unique colour ‚Äì except jumping, but more about it down below.  Mini Night Island is 2D side scrolling action game. Your pixelated player character is a mylittlepony-ish humanoid who has to run to the right across the gaming world comprised of 7 stages. Each stage is divided into multiple sections ‚Äì generally 4 ‚Äì where you will encounter unique bosses. They range from mini bosses with mini guns, main bosses like explosives-throwing magical foxes, sword summoning princesses and even animals who use hard hitting power of synth music to deplete your health into oblivion.   There are 5 button prompts for controls: run, slide, attack, special attack and grenade (but no jump). You are alerted of each oncoming attack with streaks across the ground. The wider those streaks, the wider the attacks. You will use running and sliding mechanic to run or slide across those streaks. However, sliding will cost you stamina - giving you a twitch-based choice to either dodge with style or run away while maintaining your mana. Do them, get close to the boss and either use attack, special attack or grenade to take them down.  Complementing the controls and the mechanics is the difficulty. It took me around 20 to 30 minutes to clear the first 4 stages, but that doesn‚Äôt matter. Because you‚Äôll go back to the beginning as you die. But don‚Äôt worry, randomized enemies (other than big bosses) will keep you entertained as you try to master the craft of combat-platforming.  Attack, defense, power ups, health and I guess, life-metre, these are the stats you have to keep your eye on. The use of word ‚Äúguess‚Äù here means that not much has been explained. While I can argue that it‚Äôs a minimalistic game where you have to figure out what the stats mean, the textual prompts, although well-put, don‚Äôt tell the whole story - lacking any sense of real tutorial.  Sound is not just a synth-based background music that you hear as you move your way across the game, Mckinn7 has cleverly weaved it into a gameplay element: specifically, during boss fights. Every attack has a musical rhythm to it. As you figure out what it is, you have to anticipate and jedi-trick your way across levels.  As for the background soundtrack, it‚Äôs nothing to be excited for. It‚Äôs a generic synth-based music that gives you an innocent party like feeling. However, you won‚Äôt mind any of it as you fight your way against those cleverly designed bosses I mentioned.  Mini Night Island, a 2D platformer where if you are skilful enough, can clear it within an hour, is a mini game that costs mini too. At just $2.99, the game is a steal. And, considering the potential of this developer, I guess such a little investment will allow us to look into all that he/she is capable of.  It‚Äôs a 2D platform with pixelated graphics reminiscent of the early gaming years. However, the lighting, the screen shake during battles and the sound brings that 2D goodness to modern times. The performance is flawless, considering the graphical fidelity of the game doesn‚Äôt demand much from your computer.  Mini Night Island is a good side-scrolling action game that puts fast-paced combative action coupled with platforming above everything else. If you want to have a good-short-time, I recommend this game 100 percent. On that note, I give this game an 8 out of 10.", "appid": "1200780", "steamid": "profiles/76561198177260918", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "14", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1584273600.0}

{"text": "good game", "appid": "730", "steamid": "profiles/76561198042926253", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1600430400.0}
{"text": "–•–£–ô–ù–Ø –ö–†–£–¢–ê–Ø", "appid": "570", "steamid": "profiles/76561198402852886", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1600171200.0}
{"text": "I'm a sucker for a game with a unique premise, and with Halloween being just around the corner while we're living through a pandemic, I knew that there was no better time to sink my teeth into this unique RPG set in the Spanish flu-ridden London. After all the criticisms I had heard about the game being flawed and fairly mediocre, I kept my expectations low and was actually a little surprised. The criticisms are justified, but the game was still far more enjoyable than I thought. One area that   did not disappoint in was the visuals. While the game pretty much always takes place at night and in the darkness for pretty obvious reasons, I felt the game never got obnoxiously dark to a point where I just couldn't process any of my surroundings. The game's atmosphere consistently felt unnerving, which I find especially important to nail because of the game's setting. I also thought the character designs, which are also important because every NPC is supposed to matter in this game, were all visually distinct from one another and I did not have any issues with trying to figure out who's who. It was also pretty solid on a technical level, and I did not encounter any major visual bugs. Overall, this was one of the better points of   in my opinion. I don't think it's fair to compare the game to something like   simply because they share similarities in their dark, unnerving atmosphere and the structure of their combat, but what's here is unfortunately just passable. There's definitely a couple of good things, for example I liked how the game was tough without being cheap and unfair, even if you did a no-feeding run like I did. I also liked that you could still use your vampire powers, even when you couldn't level up as much from not being able to feed on people, so it fortunately doesn't suffer from   syndrome. The last thing I liked was how the world actually did change based off of who you killed and kept alive. Your choices are pretty much always morally grey, with their own sets of pros and cons. I was sitting there for ~20 minutes with two of the big decisions because of how complex they were, and I love that the game isn't afraid of making you experience the consequences of your actions, even if it was the most morally right option. However, there's also some things that didn't work. For one, the whole \"resisting the temptation to feed\" thing gets diminished when you're able to feed on basic enemies in combat with no consequences whatsoever. I also thought that the bosses, while not unfair to fight, had pretty dumb ways of inflating the difficulty. Of the three most difficult fights in the game, two of them had the same gimmick: AOE-damaging attacks randomly popping up with little warning and covering a large amount of the arena. The 3rd fight was only difficult because they summoned additional enemies to fight, and   can get tough when you're fighting more than 3 enemies at a time. I have no qualms with a challenging boss, I just wish there was a little more creativity put into making them hard. The combat, while it worked well enough, was a little unresponsive at times and the camera had a tendency to work against me. That unresponsiveness hurts, too, because games like this are pretty punishing if you aren't at the top of your game. While the gameplay isn't bad by any means, I wish it got a little more polish and creativity put into it. Certain things here work, and other things don't. The worldbuilding is one of   biggest strengths, as its success with the atmosphere really helped me feel immersed in this unsettling setting. I enjoyed how interconnected everything was, both with the world itself and how the characters all interact with one another. It makes picking your feeding targets especially important, since you have to consider how they're connected to other characters and what kind of effects that could have on them. As I said, there are consequences to your actions and I love it. It's not as simple as sparing or killing, since sparing them could still have a negative impact on the area, and there's usually a 3rd option to consider as well that isn't necessarily the \"best\" choice. I also thought the characters were pretty solid, in particular protagonist Dr. Reid was an interesting character, as well as vampire hunter Geoffrey McCullum, and the writing was also very good. So, what didn't work, then? While the writing itself was great, it had a tendency to feel disjointed, with side dialogue not really flowing with the main parts by assuming that Reid never goes out of his way to ask any of these extra questions about the world. The main story also needed some more time time in the sun (or moon). While the mystery about the city's supernatural underbelly was interesting, that plotline was basically thrown to the wayside after the big reveal and none of the members of this mysterious society were given any time to leave an impression on me. To make matters worse, the game tries to force a romance between Dr. Reid and another main character with little buildup, and didn't really develop in any way throughout the game. By the end, I just didn't care about the mystery anymore and I couldn't figure out why I was supposed to care about the reveals. In general, I think the game could've benefited from an extra chapter or two to help flesh out these things since a lot of story aspects felt undercooked. It's a shame, because the fascinating world was there, but the story didn't quite hit the peaks it should've outside of the difficult major decisions. On the bright side,   does do pretty well in the audio department. I thought the voice acting was pretty solid overall. I liked the voice of Dr. Reid, and he especially fit considering that he starred in NBC's Dracula and   though I will say there were times where he was a little too over-the-top with his lines. The music was great, and really fit the tone of the game. Video games about pandemics seem to LOVE string instruments (i.e.  ), but it works, so I'm not complaining. The sound design's a little iffy, as the sound effects for the blood-based attacks sounded very off for some reason, but it wasn't grating to the ears at least. Overall, I thought the game did pretty well in the audio department, though I think the music was the main reason for that. I think the game is just a little too short, as my playthrough took me around 16 hours. However, there are multiple endings and different ways the world changes with your actions, so at the very least there is some replay value if the game hooks you. There's also plenty of powers and difficulty settings to give you variety in other playthroughs, and it seems like it was designed with that intention in mind. If nothing else, at least you've got plenty of options. While I have criticized   plenty in this review, I should emphasize that I did enjoy the game. It's deeply flawed, yes, but I had more fun with it than I thought I would. Had the game been given more time in the oven, this absolutely could've shot up to be one of my favorite AA games. It's a 6/10 game, but in comparison to other stuff I've given a 6, this is a very good 6/10 game. It's worth a try on a deep sale.  - 9.0/10  - 6.5/10  - 7.0/10  - 8.0/10  - 8.0/10 + Interesting world + Great music + Fairly balanced gameplay + Choices have consequences - Generally unpolished - Bosses lack creativity - Underdeveloped story - Core \"feeding\" mechanic is downplayed by combat", "appid": "427290", "steamid": "profiles/76561198111631620", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "20", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1603368000.0}

Borderlands 2 ist stark auf den Koop-Modus ausgelegt, dennoch ist es ohne weiteres m√∂glich die Quests/Story auch im Singleplayer zu bestehen. Der Vorteil des Koop besteht darin, dass man mit bis zu vier Spielern auf Pandora unterwegs ist und zusammen die Quests/Story erledigt, was nicht nur wesentlich spa√üiger ist als alleine, sondern auch die Gegner fordernder werden, sowie bessere Item droppen. Dahl-Waffen lassen einen Feuersto√ü los, wenn sie √ºber Kimme und Korn abfeuert werden, und Maliwan stellt Waffen mit besonders hohem Elementarschaden her. {"text": "Great story (if you actually have the wherewithal and interest to finish it), terrifying enemies, satisfying build mechanics, immersive survival features, and surprisingly good sound design. Cons? Sometimes it's hella glitchy - I've been playing since the Alpha, and given the recent (~last several years) trend in developers to unapologetically release unfinished games, some of the features that were rough in Alpha were never really given enough attention. One example would be that collision of objects with AI or players is wonky at times. However, the complexity of AI aggression and fluidity as the story progresses, or even just as the player expands their build presence across the island, is an interesting enough mechanic to me that I can overlook the few bugs that remain. Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a holistic survival horror experience - if you like games like 7 Days to Die, DayZ, Stranded Deep, etc., this game is for you.", "appid": "242760", "steamid": "profiles/76561198060432569", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1562414400.0}

–ù—É, –¥—Ä–æ–≤–æ—Å–µ–∫–∏-–¥—É–±–æ–ª–æ–º—ã –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–≤–∏–Ω—Ü–∏–∏ –≤—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞ –±—ã–ª–∏ –Ω—É–∂–Ω—ã. –û–Ω–∞ –∫—Ä–∞—Å–∏–≤–∞, —É–º–Ω–∞, –ø—Ä–∏—Ç—è–≥–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–∞. –í—Å–µ–ª–µ–Ω–Ω–∞—è, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä–∞—è –º–∞–Ω–∏—Ç —Å–≤–æ–∏–º –≤–µ–ª–∏—á–µ—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–º –¥—É—Ö–æ–º –Ω–∞—Å—Ç–æ—è—â–µ–≥–æ –ø—Ä–∏–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è. –¶–µ–ª—ã–π –º–∏—Ä, –≥–¥–µ, –ø—Ä–µ–¥—Å—Ç–∞–≤—å—Ç–µ —Å–µ–±–µ, –º–æ–∂–Ω–æ –Ω–µ —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –¥—Ä–∞—Ç—å—Å—è, –≤—ã–ø–æ–ª–Ω—è—Ç—å –ø–æ—Ä—É—á–µ–Ω–∏—è –¥–∞ –º–µ–¥–≤–µ–¥–µ–π –Ω–∞ –º—è—Å–æ –ø–æ—Ç—Ä–æ—à–∏—Ç—å, –Ω–æ –∏ –∂–µ–Ω–∏—Ç—å—Å—è, –æ—Å–≤–æ–∏—Ç—å –º–∏—Ä–Ω—É—é –ø—Ä–æ—Ñ–µ—Å—Å–∏—é, –∫—É–ø–∏—Ç—å –¥–æ–º. –ê –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –Ω–∞—Ç–æ—á–∏—Ç—å –∫–ª–∏–Ω–æ–∫, –æ–¥–µ—Ç—å—Å—è –ø–æ—Ç–µ–ø–ª–µ–µ, –∑–∞–∫–∞–∑–∞—Ç—å –ø–æ–≤–æ–∑–∫—É –∏ –æ—Ç–ø—Ä–∞–≤–∏—Ç—å—Å—è –≤ –¥–æ–ª–≥–æ–µ –ø—É—Ç–µ—à–µ—Å—Ç–≤–∏–µ. –ï—Å–ª–∏ —Å—Ä–µ–¥–∏ –≤–∞—à–∏—Ö –¥—Ä—É–∑–µ–π –µ—Å—Ç—å —É–∂–µ —Ç–∞–∫–∏–µ –ø–µ—Ä–µ—Ä–æ—Å—Ç–∫–∏, –∫—Ç–æ –ø–æ–ª–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å—é —Ä–∞–∑–æ—á–∞—Ä–æ–≤–∞–ª—Å—è –≤ –∫–æ–º–ø—å—é—Ç–µ—Ä–Ω—ã—Ö –∏–≥—Ä–∞—Ö –∏ –∫–∞–∂–¥—É—é –Ω–æ–≤–∏–Ω–∫—É –º–∞—à–∏–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ –∫—Ä–∏—Ç–∏–∫—É–µ—Ç –Ω–∞–¥–æ–µ–≤—à–µ–π —Ñ—Ä–∞–∑–æ–π ¬´–≤—Å–µ —É–∂–µ –Ω–µ —Ç–∞–∫, –∫–∞–∫ –±—ã–ª–æ —Ä–∞–Ω—å—à–µ¬ª, —Ç–æ –ø–æ–∫–∞–∂–∏—Ç–µ –µ–º—É Skyrim. –ò –æ–Ω –æ–±—è–∑–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ –≤–µ—Ä–Ω–µ—Ç—Å—è –∫ –Ω–∞–º.", "appid": "72850", "steamid": "profiles/76561198065545788", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "6", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1419854400.0}

{"text": "The Forest is an eerie open world filled with deadly AI enemies elevates The Forest above a good number of survival horror experiences out there, especially because of its interesting story, inspired by horror movies like The Descent. Everything is here to remind you that the surrounding nature will do everything to destroy your morale and your life. Oppressive, stressful, but so exhilarating. In a genre that is filled to the brim with many different titles all competing to be the best, The Forest certainly sets itself apart. It's hard, terrifying, and grim but also rewarding in its own right. Each death taught me a new lesson such as; how many damages each cannibal does, how fast some of them are, and how some are them are \"fakers\" too. There's a ton of customization and crafting to be done, and the areas that can be explored are very well made. The best part of this is that there is no single right way to play as you can tackle the game's happening's in any way you want. {"text": "NBA 2K19 has been the best 2K in years but it comes with micro-transactions out the ying-yang. Most of the bugs of yesteryear have been fixed, and when on the right difficulty it hits the spot AI-wise. On Hall-Of-Fame difficulty, the computer cheats way too bad. Thing is, the progression points are upped on harder difficulties, so it was worth trying. Playing against other players is hit-or-miss, sometimes it's really fun, other times it's some laggy player you can't do anything about but lose quickly. Career mode is the best mode overall, but I also played a lot of the MyGM/Franchise mode -- like 'Basketball Manager.' Fun to just play around with trying to 'run' a franchise through simulated games. Downsides were the inconsistent pings/connections between players, micro-transactions for everything, and stupid achievements that you can only get by paying money, playing thousands of hours in one year, or winning the card lottery. These downsides can be somewhat avoided, so it's still worth it to get this game on sale. Just don't expect what it isn't. {"text": "*key provided by developer for review purposes* First off, let's get the genre question out of the way.  Elysium Blood Games (EBG) is not an RPG (though it uses RPG elements), nor is it a fighting game (though fighting is the central activity of the game).  As I hope you gathered from my cheeky header, EBG is in fact a sports management simulator.  It has much more in common with OOTP or FHM than it does with, say, Pillars of Eternity. Or with Skullgirls.   There. Trust me, you will enjoy the game much more if you know what you are getting into up front.  If you don't enjoy manager sims or casual games, you might want to think twice before purchasing so that you don't end up posting a thumbs-down review dripping with haterade the game doesn't deserve. The madness and decadence of \"the Empire Before the Fall\" is a well-known trope to scholars of history, and one that shows up often in video games.  It's an insane moment, during which the masses feel themselves lifted above foreigners and criminals, because the masses witness the bloody spectacle but need never fear they might end up in the ring themselves.  It's gluttunous and irrational, to take joy in another's suffering. But it became a tightly protected \"right.\" Seneca the Elder observes that \" \"  And so here we are to make our fortune by facilitating acts of brutish violence.  Gameplay is divided into seasons, and each season is divided into day-long turns.  As the manager, you get one stat point to distribute among your manager attributes at the beginning of each season.  These stats have global effects.  Then it's on to the stables. The gladiator population is randomly generated, so names, quirks, portraits, and stats will be different every game.  The fighters' attributes are of a type that will be familiar to sports management fans, including the ever-important \"potential\" attribute.  At any given time you may have 3 gladiators in your stable.  One gladiator must be designated as the fighter for the day's match.  For the other two, you can pay for them to train up attributes, or you may send them on a \"soul quest.\" The choice of quests are each a generated combination of three numbers: risk, reward, and time commitment.  They will usually take several days but your fighter will return with some cash and often some improved stats. Or they will get horribly injured or die. You can also use cash to purchase or repair weapons for your fighters, upgrade your stables with permanent buffs, upgrade the stadium to seat more people, bribe an opposing gladiator, or, my personal favorite, place bets on the day's posted matches.  The stadium provides odds for each bracket and you can bet 100, 250, or 500 on each match (or zero if you're not the betting type).   The game's secondary currency is influence, which you may use to publicize your fights in hopes to increase attendance and payout.  More importantly, you can use it to purchase randomly generated stable-wide buffs that last for a specified number of turns.  There are so many different combinations of these it makes for great fun. Now that all your stable business is concluded, it's time to fight! The fight is turn-based and you may recommend a technique each turn or you can give a general recommendation for the match and watch it play out.  These fights are heavy on the RNG, but instead of walls of math, each turn generates a blow-by-blow narrative of the fight.  It's a really nicely done feature.  I asked the dev about the lack of explicit math and they said that this technique encourages immersion and discourages min-maxers.  Though I sometimes like to see a game's math-guts, I do in general agree with them.  Certainly it was the right choice for this game. This goes on until the season has been played out.  If you've done well, one of your fighters might get to fight in championship rounds for big rewards.  Between seasons you get to use your stat point, and then try to get the fighters you want to keep to stay with you by flashing money under their noses.  Fighters who have had a particularly rough season or who feel they've outgrown your enterprise will refuse to negotiate and just leave your service. Then it all begins again! I have found that one season, depending on how many days you've optioned for it to be, lasts between twenty minutes and an hour, making EBG an excellent game to hop on when you only have a short time and still have a satisfying experience.", "appid": "430080", "steamid": "profiles/76561198105396345", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "31", "votes_funny": "2", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1456574400.0}

{"text": "As a dedicated Dota 2 player with over 4000 hours into that game, a dota-styled card game is perfect for me. However the launch was rough and the game was lacking many core-features. Valve listened to the community and quickly released a patch adding many important features and great changes. Artifact is similar to dota in so many ways; complex gameplay with strategic elements, different lanes, abilities, items and heroes. Gameplay is great - the effects, the music, the characters interactions with each other and the lore and voices behind the cards.  I would say that the business model is fair, I like that you can buy the cards you want without opening a lot of packs, but also the free gamemodes that don't require you to spend any money at all. I've been playing the \"call to arms\" event-decks and won a lot, resulting in higher level, earning more cards and tickets. RNG is a factor, yes, but it also keeps the game interesting for replayability. Just like with Dota 2 the developers keep updating the game and adding awesome features and improvements. Dota 2 is one of the most balanced and fair games on the market and Artifact is moving in the same direction.  I would highly recommend Artifact even to players that don't like MOBAS or Dota 2. Artifact is the best card game I have ever played and I'm excited to see all the upcoming patches, new cards and further improvements! As it stands Artifact is a great game, but could be further improved by adding more cards, more hero colours and some stats to the player profile. {"text": "Nice game Awesome cheaters", "appid": "730", "steamid": "profiles/76561198093226599", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1587211200.0}
{"text": "This is the admirably honest description on the Store page, a kind of honesty not easily found on the official description. First things first: a kinetic visual-novel is one in which the player can't interact with the (linear) story, so don't expect this to be a VN proper; in other words, this is not a game - rather, it's a non-interactive mixed-media experience, and a rather good one at that.  It takes about an hour to complete, more if going through the Wiki links (more on this later), and even more if you'll take your time to sit (sometimes quite literally) and enjoy some of the little... \"atemporalities\" (pardon me) it offers. The replay value is absent - because this is not a game, bear with my redundancy - but this doesn't mean you won't find yourself drawn to re-experience some of the aforementioned time bubbles. The story may appear a little plain/slow to the Westerner's eye, especially in the very beginning, but it catches up quickly; on the other hand, those acquainted with the East Asian cultural sphere and its peculiar mindset will take great pleasure on the many references - some rather obvious, others less so. This is why I strongly suggest to break the immersion and check out the Wikipedia links provided in-game (and perhaps follow up on those when the story is over).  The translation is decent both in English and German, there are some grammar errors and there's a certain ingenuity in the choice of words, with some nuances irremediably lost in translation. Both characters display some degree of na√Øvet√©, however, which makes that ingenuousness somehow fitting. The voice acting is fine as far as I'm concerned; 'tis certainly not the best I've ever heard, but it serves its purpose well enough. Another reviewer said that \"the protagonist is consistently lacking any sort of enthusiasm\", which can hardly be denied - but, given the plot, I think it may have been intended. As to the \"art\" department, I found the soundtrack remarkable, the sound effects rather good and their timing effective. The backgrounds are gorgeus, and most of them can be \"visited\" using Google Earth's street view; the artwork is solid, although some scenes have the protagonists overly-sexualised, and while I realise that some if not most will welcome such a thing, I found it rather out-of-place. An utter buzzkill, actually, although that's pretty much the only real downside I stumbled upon during the whole experience, and it is an understandable marketing (and cultural) choice. Thankfully such buzzkills are not that common, and they ultimately had little impact on my enjoyment. What else can be said? The controls are smooth and so are the transitions; the game can be run in fullscreen up to 1920x1080; 16:10 isn't supported, resulting in movie-like black bands on the top and bottom - not an issue due to the nature of the product (as in, a kinetic VN as opposed to a game). I suggest using headphones for a better experience, if only for the cicadas and thunderstorm. --- Did I enjoy it? Far more than I would've expected Will I go back to it again? Yep. Would I recommend it? Absolutely, and quite frankly I felt it was a steal at a 1,69‚Ç¨ sale, given that even with its shortcomings I'd still buy it at its full pricetag (4,99‚Ç¨), retrospectively.  But do keep in mind that this game is not for everyone, although I think I made that rather clear in this review.", "appid": "307050", "steamid": "profiles/76561198010077247", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "18", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1424520000.0}

{"text": "This game is great, althouygh not as good in terms of dialogue or overall story as the past editions, it was still nonetheless a fun game. I currently have 200 hours on in console, so i bought it to play here, and it wouldnt start. I figured it out, that if you have a laptop that has 300 hz display, that was your issue. Simply change your hz to 60. Then all I needed to do was make a few changes to an ini file to get it to run. Set all the graphics options you want in the launcher - I set everything to High/Ultra, but be sure to disable weapon debris as this implementation doesn't play nice with RTX cards. Then edit: C:\\Users\\YourUserID\\Documents\\My Games\\Fallout4\\Fallout4Prefs.ini Ensure the following values are set (don't add these lines, just find them and edit them): iSize W=1920 iSize H=1080 iPresentInterval=0 bFull Screen=0 bBorderless=1 Lastly switch back to 300 hz and it should work like it did for me!", "appid": "377160", "steamid": "profiles/76561198444233529", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "3", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1596196800.0}

{"text": "Top game, for funny", "appid": "488790", "steamid": "profiles/76561198177177023", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1576324800.0}
{"text": "Great exploration game with an exceptional and unique physics based combat mechanic. Traditionally, combat in a game means pushing a button or series of buttons that initiate an attack animation that, ideally, lands on the enemy. In Exanima, you use your mouse \"reticule\" to swing your characters weapon while simultaneously using the WASD controls to move your characters feet. You basically need to move your character into the swing in order to actually land a blow with some force behind the swing. When you first start playing, you'll be clumsy and probably get your ass kicked a lot in the arena. Exanima features a wide variety of accurately depicted medieval arms and armor. You'll also find great combat challenges and difficult environmental puzzles in the ever increasingly difficult dungeons below.  Honestly, smashing someone in the head with a sledgehammer has never felt quite so good as it does in this game. Being chased by higher level armored undead that know how to use their weapons better than you do has never been so terrifying. Exanima, an ambitious project by a small team with a single mastermind developer, is a precursor to a much larger project titled Sui Generis. The game is built using a unique engine that was created by Madoc (lead dev) specifically for this series. At the time of this writing, the game is still in EA, but I can attest that it is very well polished, and a clearly work made by people who are passionate about the project. You're not going to see sloppy, unpolished work here, and you're not going to find the canned leveling/grinding/farming/crafting/survival gimmicky crap that appeals to the masses either. Exanima is a bastion of light in an ever darkening world of mediocre sameness in the current gaming industry. I would say that this game isn't for everybody - but rather I'll remind you that Steam has a great 2 hour/2 week refund policy. Try this one out! It's not to be missed.", "appid": "362490", "steamid": "profiles/76561198041694226", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "2", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1562587200.0}

{"text": "While there are other credible contenders (like Quest for Infamy) -- and more to come in the next couple years as Hero-U and Mage's Initiation wrap up development -- Heroine's Quest not only the best Quest for Glory game in the past 20+ years, but in some respects the superior of the games that inspired it. First, let me get the shortcomings out of the way. The production values are not as strong as in the Sierra originals (the animations are a little choppy, the VO is a little amateurish, and the music is not as memorable) -- but those were commercial games made by seasoned veterans with a considerable budget. Heroine's Quest, unlike our Primordia or the majority of other AGS games you find on Steam -- is free, so it couldn't even theoretically recoup paying professional voice actors or the like. More fundamentally, the game seems to lack a little bit of the smoothness of the original QFGs: the grinding feels a little more grindy, the exploration a little too slow, the world somewhat less open and more driven by a linear plot. But to be clear, this is a *relative* comparison, and it is in relation to what I consider some of the best games of all time. Having cleared that underbrush, let me now sing the game's praises. Most fundamentally, it achieves what I consider the game developer's greatest duty: generosity. That comes through not just through the price (i.e., free), but through the sheer quantity and variety of content. Everywhere the developers could give us more, they have, optional solutions and little Easter Eggs aplenty. That generosity is conveyed through the timeless and sadly underutilized QFG marriage of RPG and adventure game elements. The challenge of that kind of gameplay is that it requires a lot of art, a lot of alternate paths, and careful balance and testing. Heroine's Quest succeeds in all those things. Earlier, I mentioned that the game exceeds QFG, and the way in which this is so (in my opinion) is the use of the Norse mythology and foklorica. It's not entirely consistent, and sometimes it mixes in modern fantasy elements or interpretations of the source material that don't quite work, but I found overall that it drew more deeply and broadly from this lore than did QFG, where individual elements were often cherry picked without their contextual elements.  (For instance, QFG introduced a whole generation to Baba Yaga and her chicken-legged hut, and what a gift that was, but she is hardly surrounded by other Slavic elements -- instead you encounter a hodgepodge of Greek mythological creatures and D&D monsters in a quasi-German setting.)  Heroine's Quest has greater consistency in this regard, though it suffers from the fact that Norse folk lore is more familiar so the characters feel less like \"discoveries\" than did, say, Baba Yaga. Anyway, the bottom line is that this is a charming labor of love, shared for free, which leaves you with the warm, full feeling of a childhood feast, for those who grew up on QFG, or will serve as a pretty good entry point to genre to those unfamiliar with it. Three cheers for, and many thanks to, Crystal Shard!", "appid": "283880", "steamid": "profiles/76561197989271430", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "29", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1513944000.0}

{"text": "Almost 36 hours and 400 save-scums later - it is done.  What a ride this game was, \"Best RPG of all-time\" get's thrown about a lot and it's hard to believe, you fire this bad boy up and take a look at the ageing gameplay and graphics, you see the minor headache of unofficial patches and updated renderers and you might be turned off, however, you're greatly rewarded for your persistence. You're rewarded with gameplay that is deep, engaging and entirely your own. The sneak, the brick ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•-house, the hacker-man and the dolphin are all equally valid options. It might take you 15 hours before you understand, like it took me, but it's worth it.  You're rewarded with player freedom. You can choose to kill basically any NPC you encounter. You're rewarded with writing, voice-acting and a story of quality that is rarely seen anymore. Some might say that the cyberpunk dystopia warning is trite but it's possibly my favourite genre and more valid than ever. The story is intelligent and the player can choose to engage with it more by optional dialogue, emails and readables in the world. You're rewarded with environments that are detailed, atmospheric, well-designed and complex. There is always at least two routes to an objective. At the price this game goes for it's basically a gift to anyone willing to put in the time to get into it. I've just finished this, but I know I'll play this again before long because there is so much to miss in a single run. Honestly having finished this I'm saddened that the prequel Human Revolution (which I played first and very much enjoyed) suffered from a marked decrease in scope and character. I played this with Steam Proton 5.13 under Linux and installed the DX9 renderer (OpenGL is much too dark), GMDX patch and it ran rather well. I had to fire up proton tricks to change the windows version to XP and tweaked the game config files to allow for more cache up from 4MB to 64MB to stop the infrequent crashes that would happen if you did too much loading. Not everyone has experienced this beauty - what a shame.", "appid": "6910", "steamid": "profiles/76561198009914771", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "13", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1605873600.0}

‚óÜ ‰∏äË®ò„Åó„Åü„Çà„ÅÜ„Å´ÁèæÂú®„ÅØ„Äé„Çø„É≥„ÇØ„Äè„ÄéDPS„Äè„Äé„Éí„Éº„É©„Éº/„Çµ„Éù„Éº„Çø„Éº„Äè„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜÂΩπÂâ≤„Åå„Åª„ÅºÂõ∫ÂÆö„Å´„Å™„Å£„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„ÄÇ„Åù„ÇåËá™‰Ωì„ÅØÂΩπÂâ≤„Åå„Åó„Å£„Åã„Çä„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Å¶ËâØ„ÅÑ„ÅÆ„Å†„Åå„ÄÅ„ÅÑ„Åè„Å§„Åã„ÅÆ„Ç≠„É£„É©„ÅØ„Çπ„Ç≠„É´ÊßãÊàê„Åã„ÇâËÉΩÂäõ„ÅÆÂÜÖÂÆπ„Åæ„Åß„Åª„Å®„Çì„Å©Âêå„Åò„Å™„ÅÆ„Å†„ÄÇÊâÄË¨Ç„ÄÅ„ÄéÂÄãÊÄß„Äè„ÅåÁÑ°„ÅÑ„ÄÇ {"text": "Mostly for Star Trek fans, but if you are a Trekkie and are willing to invest into a MMO timesink this is for you. One of the few truly F2P games. No game content is behind paywalls. Only premium equipment requires in-game purchases and even those can be grinded for free given enough time. In-game currency Dilithium can be converted into Zen which is used for purchases. Exchange rate at this time is about 1:200 (zen to dil, most premium ships cost 2500-3000 zen, which is about 20$ real money) and there is a daily refining limit of 8000 dilithium. So it takes a while, but can be done. Gets easier if you have several characters grinding dilithium as Zen pool is account wide. So Pay-to-Bypass-Grind is more accurate for this game. Only veteran awards require montly subscription (or Lifetime account) but those are mostly cosmetic upgrades and one endgame level ship. Only truly worthy perk is the 500 Zen montly stipend. As far as game mechanics go, this is an MMO like any other. Gather experience, level up, grind for gear, team up, form guilds (Fleets). Both ground and space combat are in the game, though the ground side isn't as interesting. It is the space combat which makes this game a little different from other MMO's. Much like SWToR, the single player missions, or Episodes, are the bread&butter for Star Trek fans. Featuring voice over acting from actual Star Trek actors, like the late Leonard Nimoy, one could not ask for more story wise. Especially the newer content is very well written, and every now and then older content gets revised, the latest 'update' being mid-gameish Romulan story arc, which is now much more story-like as opposed to being just a bunch of missions in sequence. Also features Denise Crosby as Romulan Empress Sela. Most of the game content is PvE. PvP exist, but hasn't been properly balanced or developed in years so not many people play it seriously. So hard-core PvPr's steer clear.", "appid": "9900", "steamid": "profiles/76561198010998879", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "23", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1428408000.0}

Finished it in under 100 minutes and i got the ending where my sister was my wife and ended up leaving me. The ending was so absurd and makes no sense which he ended up what i think was the inside of an eyeball and curled up on the surface, then cuts to when he appears to be what seems like an office reading a note from her 'wife' who apparently leaving him and that's exactly the whole ending. The credits immediately rolled up. The game itself felt plain and too linear. The gameplay was scary at the beginning but as it progresses, it gets extremely boring and repetitive. The controls are easy and simple. The main issue is you always end up seeing the same handful of rooms over and over to occasionally be interrupted by a psych ward or forest, but i wish more was done with the forest to change the monotony of the scenery. I understand the idea of a never-ending nightmare that loops, but there's far too little change in environment and setting to keep the players engaged. There are 3 different endings that completely answered no questions and left me even feeling more confused. I don't think they're worth finding out but if you want to waste your time, then go ahead. {"text": "Death Stranding is an odd game to talk about. I loved lots of things about it and I've enjoyed (most of) my time spent with it. I'm giving it a positive¬†review (and I never write these lengthy reviews, so that should tell you something..), but at the same time I can't really wholeheartedly recommend it to everyone. It's different, it's fresh and it's weird - if that's something you value highly then you should go for it. It can also be somewhat tedious and repetitive. You play a delivery guy in a post-apocalyptic world and delivering¬†is what you'll do. It's a pretty cool concept, one that involves driving vehicles¬†and walking - lot's of walking. However, to label this game a 'walking simulator' would be grossly taking it out of context. You navigate the treacherous terrain, balance the weight of your cargo, there's¬†even the weather conditions¬†to be taken into account. There's enough factors here to make your delivery routes fun and engaging.¬† If making deliveries is not really your thing and you're mostly in it for the story - well, that's when the whole game can feel a bit stretched out. There's lots of going back and forth. For instance, there's times when you'll be making a long trek from point A to point B to point C and then back to A...only for the game to tell you to actually go back to C again. And only then you get to progress the story further. There's also enemies to deal with - personally, I found them to be more of a hindrance than anything else. Thankfully you can avoid them, for the¬†most part. Yes, it takes perseverance to play this game, but I guess that's kinda the point.. The story itself, in my highly subjective opinion, is well worth¬†experiencing. It's definitely 'out there' for most of the time, but it was also compelling¬†enough¬†to keep me going and pushing through some long stretches. The way this story is being conveyed¬†to the player is where it gets a bit difficult. Expect (too) long cutscenes where characters dump a ton of confusing lingo on you, followed by long hologram messages where characters do more of the same and leave you with more questions than answers. There's also bits of lore and story elements buried¬†within countless emails and data logs that you can read. Granted, the game answers most of its¬†questions and clears things up in the last sections, but not everyone will have the patience¬†to see it through.  Death Stranding also looks freaking awesome. It's a visual masterpiece and probably one of the best looking games that I've ever seen. So there you have it, if you're into non conventional¬†gameplay and you don't mind Hideo Kojimas particular brand of weirdness - then you should check it out. There's nothing quite like it. The rest should proceed¬†with caution..", "appid": "1190460", "steamid": "profiles/76561197996148055", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "21", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1598011200.0}

{"text": "Gud Gaem", "appid": "379720", "steamid": "profiles/76561198035178838", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1561896000.0}
{"text": "Into the breach is a game where you try to save the world from Vek insects with 3 mechs at your command. There are total of 24 different kind of mechs available to play, once you have unlocked them all. You unlock mechs by doing steam achievements and this is a clever move by developers. You should think achievements as quests in this game and those quests usually give some hints how to use a particular mech efficiently. Every single mech have different abilities and playing style varies greatly between mech squads. The game world is divided to four different islands, which are all infested by Vek creatures. All the islands have different ecosystems, quests, enemies and hazards to deal with. They all feel unique and you have to alter your strategies a bit between islands to survive. Unfortunately one island takes only about 20 mins to complete and replayability is not that great because islands plays almost every playthrough the same. I hope we get a few more island as an update or dlc.   You have to clear two, three or all four islands from veks in order to start the final battle. I have to admit the final battle is my biggest disappointment in this game. I don't want to spoil anything so I just say it doesn't feel any epic at all. The basic gameplay is simple: use your 3 mechs with best of your abilities to complete island section's (a mission/level) goals. There are usually 1-3 goals per mission and not everyone is about killing enemies or protecting buildings. There are some great variety about mission goals, but they are island oriented and you repeat same goals many times during playthroughs. Island section is always sized 8x8 square like on a chess board and like on chess game, your mind is the ultimate weapon in this game. Even if island settings feels pretty known after a few game. Every game still feels fresh and fun, because there are some many different mechs with all the different ways you can handle the levels. It's hard to review Into the breach without even mentioning Subset games previous game FTL:faster than light. FTL is my in my mind the greatest indie game ever created period. For that reason my and many others hype about this game was off the scale. Currently Into the breach is no on the same level with FTL unfortunately. This game needs more different islands to play and enemies to defeat. The final level also needs a rework, make it more memorable and unique compared to the rest of the island missions. Into the breach is despite it's flaws definitely a good game on it's own merits. Justin Ma and Matthew Davis are also developers that are really commited to their work and I'm almost certain that story of Into the breach is not done yet. 10 - Perfect game 9 - Excellent game, best of the genre 7 - Average game, nothing really special 6 - Bad game, avoid 5 - Painful to play, completely waste of time 4 - Failed game, unpayable", "appid": "590380", "steamid": "profiles/76561197960337918", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "83", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1521288000.0}

{"text": "You don't get banned from this game (that you own) for altering the settings on your monitor (that you own).  Yay. If you're an old school fan of The Isle like I am, but now see The Isle for what it is (let's not get into that) then Beasts Of Bermuda is for you. Beasts Of Bermuda (or ‚ÄòBoB‚Äô) is everything The Isle has been promising for over three long years now, and they accomplished more in the span of 7 months than The Isle has in years. In my opinion, the only thing that The Isle has over BoB is the graphics. Apart from that one thing, it's no comparison. But I'll compare the pair anyway, because hot chips aren't the only thing I like to add salt to. The developers of Beasts of Bermuda have had the luxury of watching The Isle make mistake after mistake, and therefore have been able to avoid travelling down the same road. For instance: -The updates are regular and large in size, with many improvements within each one -The developers are extremely transparent and openly communicate with the community at all times -New game features are teased and then actually released -Developers don't p**s away their time by removing old features that you love for seemingly no reason and with no explanation (features that took, I assume, hundreds of man hours to create in the first place) -Old maps that are loved by the community aren't removed for seemingly no reason and with no explanation (see above point) -Developers don't spend precious time and money designing and implementing huge overpowered fictional monsters that only they can control (because f**k the community and the player-base that made all of this possible, right?) -Developers actively listen to the community and act accordingly, based on what their fans would like to see -Lead developer doesn't call his fans \"useless\" or openly say things like \"they don't know what they want\", \"they're idiots\", etc. -Not a single server is run by Anthomnia and his brigade of (some) power-crazed moderators -Community is genuinely a great place to be for the most part If it feels like I'm comparing the two, it's probably because I am. The Isle was supposed to be 'the' dinosaur game, and for a while it was heading that way. But The Isle let me down, more than once, and BoB was there to rekindle my hope for a great dinosaur game.  (TL;DR) Great game with cartoonish graphics, longer you play the bigger and stronger you get, actual benefits to working with other players, massive advantages to nesting and joining herds/ grouping up, and countless other positives ‚Äì Buy BoB. {"text": "This is a   and   about this game and   that most foxhole veterans think and feel. Also as a foxhole veteran my self and player that has been playing this game from BETA,   and come back after couple of months of taking a break. but i just had to write this review in hopes that one day devs will improve couple if not all of the things i mentioned but many more that i didnt mention but every player will encounter them once they start playing. There are many positive things about this game, but ill mention only 2 that i feel are most important because i am doing a negative review and there are already many positive reviews you can read. 1.  - Every couple months there is something new/different/changed, and its worth coming back and checking it out for couple of hours and then again taking a break for couple of months. 2.  - Meaning you want something done, you gotta ask someone to do it or do it yourself. and yes, EVERYTHING IS PLAYER CONTROLLED, defenses, outposts, town halls, city defense building, bridges, vehicles and fuel for them. i am just waiting for a moment when they will make us repair roads, paint buildings and even implement a food and drink system, so youll no more need to go play farming simulator and instead can do farming stuff and supply food to real players. after all, this game offers everything and you can be anything you want: Medic, builder, miner, driver, engineer, architect, even roleplayer that can take enemy players prisoners, but of course you gotta find an enemy willing to roleplay. -  - 1. With rifles you can see further when corner aiming(i believe about 40-50% more). 2. Big size monitor give you extra 10-20% view distance boost that honestly doesnt sound much, but trust me, its ALLOT in this game. 3. If you add all that and go to a hill, youll gain about 30-50% more view range. so there is no surprise if you see a player base/outpost that your friendly team decided to just go around it and ignore it the entire war.  -  - There are 20+ regions and you gotta drive and teleport in each one to come to the front line. on top of that, front lines sometimes have 10+ queued players and you gotta wait till a spot becomes free, the more players the longer queue, sometimes even 20-30+ minutes of waiting. -  - Entire cycle is 60 minute long, meaning 30 minutes day and 30 minutes night. at night you cant do anything(especially if you in a vehicle because enemies can see your car headlights at all times, but you cannot see them unless they come in range of them being able to throw a anti vehicle grenade and you are GONE), the night should be reduced to 10-15 minutes, because right now, as soon night falls you go afk, unless there is some special \"spec ops\" mission that you and your friends/clan doing, but those are very rare moments. -  - Each war big groups of 20-50+ people switch sides and war is always won if you follow what side they join and fight along side with them. you may think \"well 1 or 2 groups is nothing compared to thousand of players\" and you are right, but when 10+ groups of 20-50+ members change war sides, and all of them are veterans or at least know what they are doing. well you do the math. -  - Levels dont really give you any benefits or advantages, but its always nice to see when someone is a high level, in most games it means that player knows what he is doing. but sadly in this game high rank/level only means you are saving those leveling points to trade them with your friends/clan mates and other way around. -  - If you plan to go afk for short or even longer time(for example go sleep), just hide somewhere and leave your game ON, the next day youll find yourself still in game and ready to go(unless someone killed you and you went to main home page). many players do this because they are to lazy to wait to load into a game and wait for very long queues. -  - There are many players that take advantage of this, because its very easy to set your steam name and that name shows in game, and there isnt anything you can do about it, even devs dont care cause there is no \"report\" system that you can report that. Second thing is the signs that anyone can build anywhere on the map, you build a nice sign that says something nice, 2-3 people upvote it, then you change that sign into something very bad/rude/rac!st and not even 100 players that downvote it cannot destroy it. -  - This game doesnt really need an anticheat because even if you had aimbot, the aiming/shooting mechanic is so \"Broken\" that even aimbot would not help you to hit the target xD also second thing is you cannot even see a player name that killed you(unless you are downed and enemy player comes in melee range), and in order to report him you gotta know what he is using, what cheat and on top of all that video evidence of him committing what you state he is doing wrong. so there is not much point of going thru all that trouble. All the things written in this review(and many more) have been mentioned before and even discussed with devs in multiple occasions. but nothing has been done about many of this things and no plans on changing them. even devs them self said couple of this things i mentioned will never be changed/improved. or one of their popular quotes they like to say is \"thats not our priority\". if \"Unbalanced teams\", \"Tedious logistics\", \"Ghost shots\" and most important  \"Corner aiming\" is not a priority. then i dont know what is. but we are still left with a hope they will maybe one day think about improving/changing how some of this things work or think about them if/when they decide to create foxhole 2 or a similar project.", "appid": "505460", "steamid": "profiles/76561198056784623", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "11", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1589025600.0}

{"text": "Richard was a simple minded boy. As a kid, he liked to play video games, he liked that feeling of empowerment when he shot enemies left and right in the latest Call of Duty. He liked to have fun. Life was simple. Then Richard discovered achievements on Steam and his life took a turn for the worse. Now his games had this phallic bar below their titles, and as boys do he wanted it to be as long as possible. But it was often hard to get it fully erect, with no achievement left undone. All he wanted from video games was fun. Life was already challenging enough with a name like Richard after all. This changed some months ago though. Richard discovered that more and more cheap games appeared on Steam that featured a massive amount of achievements. And best of all, achievements you got for basically doing nothing at all! True, those games were not good or fun, but gaming had ceased to be about fun for Richard long ago. He wanted those numbers, he wanted them so badly. And now he could have them, more than he ever dreamed of, with little to no effort! In some of those games all he had to do was press a single key over and over again. Heck, not even press it manually, he just went out into his parents' garden and fetched a stone which he placed on the keyboard. At one time he even had a wet dream about that stone, after a fulfilling day of thousands of new achievements. Then Richard came across Drive-By Hero. More than 5000 achievements made him instantly buy it. And it was even a shooter! He used to like those. Of course the game was utter trash, cheap assets lazily cobbled together, the gun sounded like some stapler gone on a rampage, the gameplay was even worse than he expected. Three levels, one boss. The introductory message sounded like the dev had voice-recorded it himself with a cheap webcam. But he had stopped caring about things like that by now. He just wanted those achievements. So Richard played. His trusty stone wouldn't do for this though: every time he died, he had to press the mouse button to start firing again. He had already played for hours and still was only halfway through firing all those bullets. While he stared and mindlessly shot at the hordes of zombies approaching him, his mind entered a zen like dream state. He remembered those good shooters, the fun he had. After a while, with nothing else to do, he even began questioning the game's logic, how zombies running into his tank could cause him damage, or why he kept staring in the same direction although his tank made a turn. He moved the crosshairs up and tried firing at the full moon instead, to not have to look at the barren monochrome areas or the cheap zombies anymore, but the crosshairs stopped just a few pixels below the moon, unable to ever reach it, and he died too quickly that way as well. Richard fired away at those zombies for what was beginning to feel like an eternity. The image of the approaching hoardes of the undead dug deep into that simple brain of his. Once in a while, a tear would roll out of his unblinking eyes. Ever so slowly his mood would get worse and worse. What was he doing with his life? After a while the zombies and he became one in Richard's mind. Finally, his face expressionless, he stood up, grabbed that heavy, trusty stone and went into his parents' garden once more. It was night time by now, and as chance would have it, a full moon was up, forever unreachable in that beautiful, clear night sky. He slowly, mechanically got down on his knees and raised the stone above his head. With force he brought it down, time and time again. He fastened his grip in determination as the stone got slippery from his own blood. Then the deed was done. The pain was over. As his consciousness faded into the void between the stars, he was finally at peace. This is Richard's story. Don't let it be yours.", "appid": "640310", "steamid": "profiles/76561198059564514", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "91", "votes_funny": "48", "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1498478400.0}
{"text": "Okay where to start this game is \"Alright\" i mean Single-Player is really bad but Multi-Player is actualy pretty good. Single-Player is trying so hard to be like Call of Duty and Battlefield etc. but its so linear and scripted that i wanted so much to quit the game sometimes.The Story is so weak and full of cliches at the start of the game things are looking good but then its just shooting and running but with no fun.The characters oh boy they are so flat and uninteresting that at the end of the game i really didnt care about them.The Ai is actually decent nothing special but decent.And the end of the game was the worst thing ever, it was like punch in the face and saying to us \"wait for another game Haha\" i really dislike these types of endings.And the game is ONLY 4 HOURS LONG !!! {"text": "Like everyone else I had high hopes for this game. Unfortunately GreedFall was huge let down for me. I'm not gonna lie, first 5+ hours were actually fun, I had Dragon Age 2 and other older rpg feels.  But.  Soon after game become a chore and I dont remember when i was so drained out playing a game. If that game came out in early 2000 it would be a hit. For today standards it just doesn't deliver. (I know that this game was made by a small studio of 20-30+ people but my problems were not with graphic or flashy gameplay and action) I cannot recommend GreedFall at almost triple A price. Wait for 50% sale. Cons: - companions. I couldn't connect with anyone, all were uninterested without any ambition or goal and they didn't bring anything to the story. Even after loyalty missions I couldn't feel any connection. Also there were no memorable side characters. - battle system. Lazy and easy. Companion AI is dumb as f**k.  As a mage i was just smashing left mouse click, dodge is broken because it requires no mana or stamina, not once did I block or used any other skill beside Stasis and maybe one or twice that aoe stasis. I have play on hard mode. - character progression. Talents are useless. I have never touched crafting and alchemy (npcs can do that in towns) Lockpicking? From almost all chests you get 1-5 gold, some ingredients and 1-3 ammo, i think there is a chest or two where you find good gear. vigor? Useless. Only charisma and and maybe intuition are worth. Attributes are plain minimum like +100 hp, mana, +10% dmg etc. Skills. Again bare minimum.  - Gear. I have been using Vasco's chest armour from beginning to the end. Every time i got new wep i couldn't feel any difference. - environment. Not gonna lie it looks beautiful. BUT. Towns are too big and that wouldn't be a problem if there were things to explore. They just waste your time. Those 3 houses that you can enter are also huge and labyrinth like just to waste your time. People just stand around like from early ps/ps2 era. - quests. They have drained me the most with all that constant running from one part of map to another just to immediately run back. Some were interesting but that running around ruined (even with fast travel) especially quests where you have to wait for 24h. - conversation. Unlike Dragon age where you have multiple options to chose here you have Charisma answer, bribe or something like threaten/convince. - few types of monsters and copy paste bosses. - some minor bugs and fps drops Pros + Story is actually ok. + Refreshing setting. Not your typical fantasy with swords and magic.  + Environment is beautiful + Game makes you want to play older rpg classics + Not an open world.  Spider studio is on the right way. {"text": "Don't get fooled, this is NOT a souls-like game. Not even close. Yes, the bonfire system is similar, and the rolling mechanic to avoid damage too. But thats about it. The game looks amazing, great graphics and performance. However the maps are ramdomly generated, and the resulting designs are awful. It's basically empty corridors with not much to explore or do but to go forward. Even when you find a chest, the only thing inside is scrap (Money) and materials that you have to pick pressing the action button repeatedly without even minding what the hell you're picking. As said, this is not a souls-like game where every enemy is a challenge. You'll be facing hordes of minions here (defeated with a single shoot most of the time), while from time to time a \"special\" enemy appears, with a sound fx noticing you, and another sound fx anouncing his death... so, the gameplay in-between bosses is really really similar and inspired in games like Left4dead or Warhammer Vermintide. Despite what many people claim, the game is not hard at all, there's only a few bosses that require a bit learning, but nothing really complicated if you are a casual shooter gamer. At least in single player it's easy AF. I haven't tested the co-op, where the difficulty scales, so maybe thats the real challenge, I don't know. Also, the final boss is just boring and really tedious... is a long, long boring fight... Not hard, just long and boring, and you end up dying because you get distracted out of boredom. Don't get me wrong, the game is fun and well polished, but it's not worth it for the current price. {"text": "First of all, yes, this game is absolutely as bad as all the reviews say.  I had to see it for myself.  While I agree with the badness, I also found myself laughing...a lot.
