{"text": "It's like sitting in a theater in the very front seat... watching this movie. Cutting to the chase, the controls for this game are flawed. They are very sensitive and makes it troubling to be precise during gameplay. Options and optimization are pretty bare-bone, and as a result, you're stuck with very dated and unpleasant graphics and textures. While I give props for Disney Planes: The Video Game being basic (which is good for a game being targetted for a young audience in mind), the game is mostly just going from mission to mission and completing a few tasks. Aside from trying to get a higher score per level, the levels and missions are not interesting enough to go back to previous levels and play again. Overall, this game has a specific audience in mind. Although I think it is a good kids game for its simplicity, there are flaws that makes this game boring and bland, aesthetically and in design.", "appid": "286880", "steamid": "profiles/76561198055520449", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "29", "votes_funny": "9", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1418644800.0}
{"text": "Only buy this game if it's on sale. This game is not true to the original and it's very short. It has a lot of cut content. We don't have the Restaurant, Press Office, City Hall, and especially¬†Clock Tower¬†or¬†Raccoon City Park. There are some major changes to the story, like¬†RPD segment¬†given to Carlos and¬†Brad's death¬†being reimagined (for worse imo). Jill witnessing his death by Nemesis was an iconic moment in the original and it's not present anymore. Other minor changes that I dislike are: they changed the first encounter between Jill and Carlos, the subway section is at the beginning now, and they removed Barry from the game (he is the one who rescues Jill with the helicopter at the end of the original). But the¬†main problem¬†with this game is that¬†it doesn't feel like a classic RE game¬†and more like RE6 most of the time, particularly in the second half. And it's actually pretty simple to understand why. The reason why the original was so great was because it had (like every classic RE) a crazy amounf of puzzles - in fact the best puzzle in the original for me was the music box puzzle in the Clock Tower, which is no longer present. And it also had many key items that you needed to get in order to unlock previous areas that were blocked when you first passed them. This was also true for RE1 and RE2, which essence were perfectly captured by their remakes. The amount of puzzles and key items in the original meant a lot of backtracking and having to pass narrow alleys multiple times, facing zombies each time. Simple things like going back to Dario's warehouse later on to use the crank and get precious ammo or realizing that Dario actually left his shelter, leaving behind free gunpowder for you. And the fact that you had to backtrack and at the same time run from a crazy stalker Nemesis made that game an amazing and satisfying adrenaline rush. There is NO adrenaline and desperation element with this Nemesis, because you don't have to backtrack nearly as much (or at all), so you encounter him very few times. And I'm only talking about the first half of the game obviously. Because in the second half Nemesis just becomes a dog-looking scripted mess, similar to the Ustanak in Resident Evil 6. This makes me almost shed a tear. Realizing that¬†they butchered the VERY essence of the original game. In most sequences, you can close a door on Nemesis and if you¬†immediately¬†open it again, he is no longer there. It's downright disheartening to realize how scripted he becomes. In the original, he could even appear in the restaurant OR the press office, depending on which location you visited first. Changing not only the fight completely, but also changing how you encountered Carlos for the first time (and if i remember correctly, even changing his dialogue with Jill). This critique has been given a million times, but I'd like to reinforce it. Not only the game lacks backtracking and puzzles (in fact it has only ONE real puzzle: the vaccine puzzle in the last segment), it takes even a step further and completely¬†blocks certain areas¬†from being revisited via scripted events. For example: once you enter the subway station after reactivating the subway system, JIll will roll down the metal shutter, making the city completely inaccessible and FORCING you to move to the subway, even if you forgot some items behind. Not that it makes any difference in this game anyway, since there are no key items that you absolutely need to get to solve puzzles or unlock areas. But nonetheless it's a very clear way to¬†force a linear path for the player, which goes ABSOLUTELY against the essence of the original (or any classic RE for that matter). The area that feels most like Resident Evil is the hospital. Especially in the Intense or Nightmare difficulties. Tight corridors teeming with all sorts of real threats, TONS of backtracking and key items that need to be obtained in order to unlock rooms. Funnily enough though, the worst part of the game is actually at the end of this hospital act, when there's (no joke) a HORDE gameplay where you need to hold your ground during a timer, spamming ammo and throwing grenades. This is SO Resident Evil 6 that I really question myself if Capcom actually learned their lesson. I also want to express my frustration about how this game feels like an insane wasted opportunity. Let's take a moment here and realize that the 3rd game is the final act for the iconic Raccoon City trilogy and could be so much bigger and groundbreaking. Granted, the original RE3 was designed at first to be a spin-off and had a very smaller team plus lower budget, thus resulting in a product that had a slightly smaller scope than the previous title (although, looking back, not as much as people usually say). But this is precisely what gave Capcom the opportunity to surpass everyone's expectations for this game, making an epic final act for the trilogy. Like, cmon, this is THE game that takes place in the streets of Raccoon City.¬†They could have made the city so big and scary to explore. Rather, Capcom not only didn't expand Raccoon City, they made it linear and therefore it feels significantly smaller than the older version. So, to sum it up: The reason why this game fails as a remake is not only the cut content, but also (and mainly) the fact that its essence was lost. IMO if Capcom wanted to have all this creative freedom, then they could just apply it to RE8 (RE7 was a great game btw) instead of butchering a classic one. And, of course, let me not finish this review without mentioning: -¬†No Mercenaries mode. RE3 was single-handedly the game that made this type of minigame a staple in the series. -¬†No live action choices¬†. Massively decreasing replayability. -¬†No Ink Ribbon. There are typewritters and chests EVERYWHERE (this is not an exaggeration). -¬†No Blue Herbs. Why blue herbs if they removed the spiders, right? They also removed crows. You can hear crow sounds in the game and they are even present in the concept arts, but removed from the game. Go figure. You can also clearly see this game was rushed when you realize the zombies are basically the same as the previous game (same models) and a ton (A TON) of assets were reused from RE2R, and yet the game is much smaller and less ambitions. Shame. This is not the first time Capcom puts a AAA price tag in a half-baked product. Cough Street Fighter 5 cough. This was my favorite RE game as a kid and it pains me to say this, but I'm giving this game a negative review.", "appid": "952060", "steamid": "profiles/76561198031992781", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1587816000.0}

{"text": "PLZ!!!!! i want asia servers because this game very good but bad server on asia", "appid": "506540", "steamid": "profiles/76561198348574881", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": "2", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1491480000.0}
{"text": "There is definitely something unique about Ferrari Racing Legends, enough that it made me buy it twice. A clever decision would be to mod an existing well established racing game, but...here we are. The reason behind that decision was authenticity, its the history of the brand, the details of the vehicles. Unfortunately this game was a massive failure. Not quite an arcade racer, far from an authentic simulation. In ways it showcases the issues of centering a game around one car brand, especially when that brand is Ferrari. Known for being rather emotional about its cars and imposing limitations on the product that includes them, as if it was entirely a piece of advertisement. From that we get a long campaign with non conventional difficulty spikes, that is absolutely tedious to complete. However in an unexpected turn of events, the brand itself salvage the product,from this developer. Shoddy work from Slightly Mad, driven worse by not being properly tested. An unfinished product with a few annoying bugs and glitches. The overall feeling is that they were confused in which direction to take, only that they would use Shift handling and physics. The presentation on Career mode is on Point. They use it as a celebration of the brand, divided into 3 different eras. It includes some of the most iconic cars and tracks, in Ferrari history. Obvious that this presents them in the best possible light, Seen from looking at the date for each track. Each loading screen has a text box, describing what is going on in each level. Vehicles sound amazing and are properly loud. Cars interior is well detailed and accurate. Damage. They specifically hate the idea of driving a damaged vehicle. Therefore, vehicles are particularly tough to break, and since you are not allowed to drive a damaged vehicle, mostly you can get away with is a cracked front glass, it means a very minimal damage models. It takes talent to actually break the car, i've managed to accomplish that twice.  One resulted in a flat tire, which you cannot see or feel, because it immediately forces the player to retire from the race. The other, i had crashed at full speed against a wall, which resulted in the driver suffering wrist injury that prevented him from switching gears, though the car was absolutely fine. Its the feeble human body inside that reached its limit. At points it goes too far, like tracks have a pit stop, other pilots stop there from time to time, especially in the longer races. However the player as no reason to do so, because it would be nearly impossible to even run out of fuel. The presentation outside career mode. Its one of those things Gran Turismo absolutly nailed. Many games have copied it since then, even Milestone can give detailed information about the vehicles themselves yet,strangely enough a game about ferrari doesn't. The title image is one of you cars in front of a ferrari dealer, thats about it, not the most inspiring location. The full car list, gives no information, other than the name of the vehicle. It even fails at keeping the vehicle module on screen. As it often crops the vehicle as you move down the list. No iconic drivers, which is a missed opportunity, you can tell the driver s where important, for example look at some of the dates on the tracks and the vehicles, pilots like Schumacher where racing at the time, however they are not present in game. I guess if you're copying the same game, Shift is not a bad choice, its their best game to date. Which is not saying much. I thought that one was quite decent, their handling and the physics are not the issue itself, thought there are problems related to them, more on that later.  The graphics are pretty good for the time, but even this is open for discussion because of issues with the settings and unnoticed details. First of all, anti-aliasing was turned off by default. It needs to be on, there's a weird graphical glitch with the trees and it wont even let you see the road. The settings are limited and there's nothing one can do about the draw distance. Worst of all, is that some of the smaller details will appear first. No direction resulting in unconventional difficulty. Ferrari Racing legends, isn't trying to simulate a professional level race, it instead opts to offer the player a series of challenges for each track. What happens is that you never actually compete against the AI ( i will also discuss that one later on) which could be an ok idea, idk why you would need to sacrifice AI, other than maybe the developer wasn't given much time to finish the game. The problem is that they wherent feeling particularly creative with the challanges either. This game is so ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• long and it's mostly the same challenges over and over again. It's so long, the supposed reward system doesn't even exist. They can either unlock a car or a track,  not even close to being enough. You will start a level with 2 challenges, and in the rewards section theres nothing there, basically theres no reward for completing the game. It's such a poor incentive to continue playing One could say, cool...i can just skip levels then? the answer is nope. You can start any of the 3 eras, but you cant skip any of the levels, each one is locked until you beat the previous one. I would have skipped the 10 lap races if i could And the difficulty is irregular, if you the challenge requires getting 1st place than its going to be considerably easier than having to beat a lap record, because you would be first regardless. About the AI, well, its brain dead. It is possible that it gets slightly more aggressive in the hardest difficulty. But the changes are very minor Regardless what difficulty you pick, they will take longer than you to reach full speed. It's not that they don't take corners well, it's more than they drive slower. In fact, and this is quite a frustrating aspect. They will try to return to their designated path no matter what. At first it felt the AI drives well, they're just slower, but that feeling didn't last for long. Once you are required to follow the pack and overtake only one each lap, it becomes a circus. When they are going slow, they often lose control, swerve left and right, they brake way to early for the speed their going. That sometimes resulted in me tapping the rear of the vehicle and immediately it just spins me around like i got hit by a blue shell. If they are by some miracle going fast, they often push me from the side, because i was overtaking them from their predefined path. Sure, the game is so easy it hardly matters, but it is frustrating. There's a race during the first era, where you need to overtake one vehicle per lap. It doesn't take 20 sec for 6 of those vehicles to crash into each other. I had to come to a full stop and wait for them to get back on track. This happens every time you do that race, at least on hard, that's how it went. Let's talk about the physics. Which are inconsistent, but mostly broken because of small oversights. well, to begin, every car handles in a similar way. I think the driving was good in Shift, but here, is off putting that you can drift with some of their oldest vehicles, its absolutly ridiculous (good old Shift oversteer). Thats the least of its problems though, its just lack of care or time. Like F1 cars can clip through the ground on a certain angle and at that speed they just hit the ground and fly off track.  Admittedly, because the game lets me, i tend to pass over curbs, means it happens more often to me, and i can see the front clipping the ground. Except i was looking through replays and that happens with the AI sometimes. There is one race that is bugged, with F333SP, that ends before the first lap, so...be creative. {"text": "Unfortunately just not good. I'm sure the performance issues are something that can easily be addressed further down the line and during Early Access you cant really judge them all too much for it. To me the main issues are something that's fundamentally wrong with the gameplay itself. First of all the characters movement feels much too indirect, making precise movement rather difficult even from a standstill which doesn't help the rather dodgy hit detection on buildings. Another problem is a personal taste, the low time to kill is probably comparable to what the modern Battlefield and Call of Duty games call Hardcore mode. I understand some people enjoy it but to me it feels incredibly counter-intuitive when a fast-paced game tries to add depth by making people die quicker. However, this issue is then countered by suddenly adding game-y aspects of having more armor that then protects you from arbitrary selections of guns, to be honest this just feels like there were two design documents and they only had money for one game so you have this mix and match of arcade and realism that doesn't feel great. In the end the question the developers should have asked themselves is: What makes our game fundamentally different from an already existing game from a company with vastly more money and manpower And the answer is: not enough If you want something very similar to this, buy Battlefield 4. {"text": "The game is a cute, shopkeeper merchant dungeon crawling fiasco. Unforgiving at times but forgiving enough to challenge you. The animations are amazingly smooth thanks to Rocio Gutierrez accompanied by solid sound design from Alex Benet. A shame the gameplay gets repetitive too quickly, but it's to be expected with a rogue-lite rougelike (but the grindfest is just unbelievable - you'll be grinding and dying alot, unless you play slow and safe). The soundtrack is beautiful with it's light accents and whimsical compositions by David Fenn, that gives it a nice light-hearted atmosphere regardless if you're in a death defying situation fighting a boss or trying to build up the town.  Some of the weapon varieties leaves something to be desired, as most are the same with only a different skin and different animations but do the same damage, reach the same aoe/length and barely affect the character. The level designs and enemies favour a certain playstyle, resulting in boring laborious dungeon crawling and shopkeeping. And it always surprises me how the same customer can walk in 7 times in one day to buy 7 things - where does these villagers get their money from? It's not a big town, 15 at most (and even if you expand the town, it still stays pretty small with 1 or 2 new npcs - that are also filthy rich). And hardly anyone ever leaves the town with no travelling merchants that come by. So how is it possible they're millionaires!? There is also nothing to do in town. It's a waste of space. It could've been utilised better had there been more life. Rather than having npcs aimlessly wander around making the town look dead, there could've been more meaningful animations to invigorate the environment and ambience. Putting immersion aside, the game while fun, has a tag not worthy of its price. It's too high thanks to the issues above. Wait for at least a 75% off sale/discount. Recommended because at least I had fun while it lasted. * However, I'm not recommending on the basis that, Digital Sun lost their own keys to re-sellers whether it be their own fault or 11 bit studios, and revoked my key where I bought it lawfully outside of Steam. A shame. Did I forget to mention they removed my key after playing 45 hours of the game? {"text": "As much as I like the zombies mode, I would have to say that this game really isn't worth the $60 they're asking for it and the season pass isn't worth it either.            I could talk about how good the campaign is, but lets be perfectly honest here. Most people are buying Call of Duty games for the multiplayer and this one does not feel good at all. After coming from Black Ops 3 where the movement system, while not the most favorable, was extremely fluent and easy to use Infinite Warfare feels slow and sluggish. The movement system honestly feels like a cheap rip off. It feels extremely slow and clunky and is just not at all fun to play with.     Zombies is a fun game mode in this game. It reminds me alot of how Call of Duty:World at War was in terms of how meleeing works and what happens if the player gets too close to them. The perks and the pack-a-punch are all pretty much the same as Treyarch's but I am not going to fault them for that because of the old saying,\"If it ain't broke don't fix it.\" That's not to say that they haven't tweeked certain perks to make them a little bit better. An example would be how Stamin-Up's counter part Rancin' Stripes does what Stamin-Up did but also acts as the Gung-Ho perk allow players to throw grenade, pick up items and shoot while sprinting. The power-ups are also the same as Treyarch how ever they have added in special backpacks that drop various items such as different grenade types. Everything has it's place and once you get use to everything the game mode really starts to become fun.      I saved the supply drops for last because unlike previous games it doesn't just impact the multiplayer side anymore. The biggest positive is free guns when they get added. In multiplayer you complete a special challenge and in zombies you simply pick it up. The supply drops biggest flaw is the fact that if a player has the ability to spend real money they will simply be able to progress through the prototype lab at a much faster rate than those who can't, which gives them an unfair edge in multiplayer. On the other side of this \"coin\" is the fact that zombies is a co-op game where players work together to achieve a goal whether it be high rounds or to complete the easter egg on any of the maps. If a player has damage increasing epic weapon then in the long run it helps the entire team because that player will be able to kill more zombies and take a bit of pressure off of their team mates.     At the end of the day what helps to kill the game is the multiplayer which doesn't feel right and the lack of replayability across the board. The only reason to buy is if you are a player like me who is a hardcore zombies person because chances are you will actually enjoy it.", "appid": "292730", "steamid": "profiles/76561198165380919", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "3", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1495195200.0}

{"text": "TLDR: Jet Racing Extreme is a simple, fast racing game with well-made damaging and destruction system. It is fun for a little bit but it is not anything special and is not worth its price. I feel like developers wanted to make a good arcade game but then mixed it with realistic damage and destruction system and it didn't match well. Details: + Fast-paced gameplay with nice (but somehow weird) steering. The speed one can reach here is really high and it is exciting; + Destruction and damage system - it is very good, detailed thing in this game. You can damage your wheels and even get them completely destroyed and you would still be able to drive your car. That is an interesting and well-made idea; + Maps are nice and interesting; +/- Car upgrades - There are many upgrades available to your vehicle parts which is nice. Although, I somehow had enough money to upgrade everything to its max level after my very first race and I did not even know why. That completely ruined the upgrade system for me. Hopefully they will change it someday in the future; - Sometimes you could get a feeling that the game is actually too fast - it is very nice to feel the speed but your vehicle always crash after touching literally anything. That is frustrating and I would rather like to enjoy the speed than seeing my car crashing so often in such an arcade game; - I feel like developer mistakenly mixed 2 different, opposite things in this game - they created realistic game if it comes to damage, destructions and physics but I did not like that - I feel like this game should be a very fast-paced arcade racer in which you could get unbelievable, enormous speeds and enjoy the fast ride without worrying about your car getting crashed that much. Unfortunately, that is impossible - your car gets destroyed everytime it touches something and it frustrates a lot - it completely removes the \"arcade\" thing; - Music is repetetive and boring. So are sound effects - honestly they were making me annoyed and I could not stand them after a while; - In-game purchases - the game itself is a port from mobile game but I try not to judge it by that. However, seeing in-game purchases or \"Premium\" versions etc. is not good. Only if the game was incredibly cheap but it is not - that is why I am surprised they even kept these in-game purchases in a PC version. That is a big NO; - Multiplayer seems to be dead. What is even worse, single player mode is boring - you do not even compete with any other AI-controlled cars. You just drive alone; - Graphics could be better; Summing up: I cannot recommend Jet Racing Extreme at its current state. It is not worth the price with what it offers at the moment. It has very good damage and destruction system and physics are nice. However, the thing how developer mixed arcade and realistic style is a big mistake in my opinion. I hope the game will be upgraded and more features will finally be added but as for now, I cannot recommend buying this game, especially for the full price.", "appid": "385270", "steamid": "profiles/76561197996924828", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "15", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1447934400.0}

{"text": "I believe the overall score for this game, which is currently \"mostly positive\" is very misleading; there seem to only be 40% of reviews that are positive. I stand with the 60%. The controls in the game are floaty, and not clean enough for a platformer, controls that are this shaky are fine in many genres, but not in a genre where controls are a key element. While none of the puzzles are too difficult to figure out, you will die on many of them several times before you can successfully complete them. Each time you die, the game takes a long time to reload, or fails to load entirely. As a result, we had to quit and restart in order to try again. Most disappointing, is that in order to get the best ending, you have to flip a number of switches throughout the game. If you quit the game at any time, your progress with these switches is not saved. This means, if you want the best ending, you have to complete the game in one sitting. {"text": "The game is super unpolished, and the boss fights are nowhere near the older games fun level. Classic mode is a requirement for any enjoyment, while dodge to win mechanics are pure cheese that are laughable compared to the advanced capabilities of the older titles. The movement speed is also unbearably slow compared to horse riding on the older games, and the lack of map feature makes backtracking for items annoying and requires alt-tabbing for walkthroughs. Any movement in general is bad, and there is a lot of platforming with bad movement. Including the flaky whip pipe to move mechanic, and jump to ledge with subpar jumping ability. (you'll know if you play it, as you can only just barely make it, and have to climb up every time.) Killing the horse reminds me of Starwars killing off Han and Luke, and makes me wonder if the devs are pulling a Starwars or SpecOps mind game on us. Like they deliberately wanted to make a bad game because they secretly hate the fans or something.  I dislike the crucible too, but the game needs some better items to be tolerable, and after grinding for those items and power leveling, you can become OP enough that the normal game feels stupid. The game doesn't give you enough normal weapon upgrades on purpose, weapons aren't equally balanced, and switching modes is janky. It would be ideal if I could double tap to fire jump then storm coast down, but you can't. There is no balance or polish with this game. It is designed to be either frustrating or stupid easy. There is no fun normal gameplay, and the puzzle mechanics are just as unpolished and unintuitive. I have multiple playthroughs of Darksiders 2, which may even increase later on. Meanwhile, Darksiders 3 is getting ONE, and I will never play it again unless it gets a map and better balancing. Also, throw some damn hints around for some of the puzzles. They're not all intuitive. Anyways, Darksiders 3 is a good way to kill a franchise. If it isn't dead already, and I hear any rumors that 4 is just as bad, it will not get a purchase until it goes on sale cheap. DS3 is just pure trolling that is only worth playing for the story, since the game itself is terrible. Even if they were going for Dark Souls, it wasn't done right. None of the mechanics are even close to Souls polish and balancing. Including slow loading the game to a checkpoint after death, when the damn game should be in memory, and instant load. PS. –≤ 21:18 (143.0 —á. –≤ –º–æ–º–µ–Ω—Ç –Ω–∞–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–∏—è) –ú–æ–π –ø—Ä–æ—à–ª—ã–π –æ–±–∑–æ—Ä —Å–æ—Å—Ç–æ—è–ª –∏–∑ –ª–∏—á–Ω–æ–π –∑–ª–æ–±—ã –∫ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º—É —Å–æ—Ç–æ–≤–∞—Ä–∏—â—É –ø–æ –∫—Ä—ã–ª—É, —Ç–µ–ø–µ—Ä—å –æ–Ω –ø—Ä–æ—Ç–∏–≤ –≤—Å–µ—Ö –∫—Ä—ã—Å, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã–µ —Ö–æ—Ç—è—Ç –Ω–∞–∂–∏–≤–∏—Ç—å—Å—è –Ω–∞ –∑–Ω–∞–Ω–∏–∏ –≤ –∫–∞–∫–æ–π —Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º–µ —è —Å–µ–π—á–∞—Å –Ω–∞—Ö–æ–∂—É—Å—å. –¢–µ–ø–µ—Ä—å –∏—Ö –∑–∞–¥–∞—á–∞ –∑–∞–±–æ–ª—Ç–∞—Ç—å –º–µ–Ω—è, –æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–∏—Ç—å –≤ –∫–æ—Å–º–æ—Å–µ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–≥–æ, –∑–∞—Å—Ç–∞–≤–∏—Ç—å –æ—Å—Ç–∞–Ω–æ–≤–∏—Ç—å—Å—è –∏ –±—ã—Ç—å –ø–µ—Ä–µ—Ö–≤–∞—á–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–º –±–µ–∑ —Ç–æ–ø–ª–∏–≤–∞ –∏ –≤–æ–∑–º–æ–∂–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ –µ–≥–æ –ø–æ–ø–æ–ª–Ω–∏—Ç—å, –æ–±–µ—Å—Ç–æ—á–∏—Ç—å –º–æ–¥—É–ª—å –ø—Ä—ã–∂–∫–∞ –∏ –¥–≤–∏–≥–∞—Ç–µ–ª—è, –∞ –ø–æ—Ç–æ–º —É–Ω–∏—á—Ç–æ–∂–∏—Ç—å –º–æ–π –∫–æ—Ä–∞–±–ª—å –∑–∞ —Å—á–∏—Ç–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ —Å–µ–∫—É–Ω–¥—ã. –†–µ—á—å –∏–¥—ë—Ç –æ –ø–æ—Å—Ç–æ—Ä–æ–Ω–Ω–∏—Ö —Å–Ω–∞–π–ø–µ—Ä—Å–∫–∏—Ö –ø—Ä–∏—Ü–µ–ª–æ–≤ –∏ –Ω–∏–∫–∞–∫–æ–π –∏–Ω–∏—Ü–∏–∞—Ç–∏–≤—ã —Ä–∞–∑—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç—á–∏–∫–æ–≤ —Å–¥–µ–ª–∞—Ç—å –≤—Å–µ –Ω–∞–∑–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è —Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º, —Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ü–∏–π, –∑–≤—ë–∑–¥ –∏ –ø–ª–∞–Ω–µ—Ç —Ö–æ—Ç—å —á—É—Ç–æ—á–∫—É –æ–ø—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ —Å–∫—Ä—ã–≤–∞–µ–º—ã–º–∏, –≤—ã–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ–º –¥—Ä—É–≥–∏–º —Ü–≤–µ—Ç–æ–º, –Ω–∞—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–æ–≤—ã–µ –∑–≤—ë–∑–¥—ã, —Å–∫–∞–Ω–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å –ø–ª–∞–Ω–µ—Ç—ã –∏ –æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–ª—è—Ç—å —Å–≤–æ—é –ø–ª–∞—à–∫—É —Å –∏–º–µ–Ω–µ–º –Ω–∞ –æ—Ç–¥–∞–ª—ë–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö –æ—Ç –æ—Å–Ω–æ–≤–Ω–æ–≥–æ –ø—É–∑—ã—Ä—è —Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ö. –•–æ—á–µ—Ç—Å—è —É–ø–æ–º—è–Ω—É—Ç—å, —á—Ç–æ –¥–æ —ç—Ç–æ–≥–æ –∏–≥—Ä–∞ —Å—Ç–æ–∏–ª–∞ 5–∫ –∏ —è –Ω–µ –≥–æ—Ç–æ–≤ –±—ã–ª –ø–ª–∞—Ç–∏—Ç—å –∑–∞ –Ω–µ—ë —Ç–∞–∫–∏–µ –¥–µ–Ω—å–≥–∏, –ø–æ–∫–∞ —Ç–∞ –Ω–µ –ø–æ—è–≤–∏–ª–∞—Å—å –≤ Steam –∑–∞ 2–∫. –Ø –Ω–µ –æ—Å–æ–±–æ –≥–æ—Ä–µ–ª –∂–µ–ª–∞–Ω–∏–µ–º –Ω–∏ –≤–æ–µ–≤–∞—Ç—å, –Ω–∏ –ø—ã—Ç–∞—Ç—å—Å—è —Ä–∞–∑–æ–±—Ä–∞—Ç—å—Å—è –≤ —ç–∫–æ–Ω–æ–º–∏–∫–µ. –ë—ã–ª–∏ –ª–∏—à—å –µ–¥–∏–Ω–∏—á–Ω—ã–µ —Å–ª—É—á–∞–∏, –∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –∫—Ç–æ-—Ç–æ –∏–∑ –¥—Ä—É–∑–µ–π –º–æ–≥ –∑–∞–∏–º–µ—Ç—å –∏–≥—Ä—É –ø–æ–¥–æ–±–Ω–æ–≥–æ –∂–∞–Ω—Ä–∞, —á—Ç–æ–±—ã —Å—ã–≥—Ä–∞—Ç—å –≤–º–µ—Å—Ç–µ, —á—Ç–æ-—Ç–æ –∑–∞ —ç—Ç–∏ –≥–æ–¥—ã –ø–æ—à–ª–æ –Ω–µ —Ç–∞–∫ –∏ –∫ –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥—É –¥–æ–ø–æ–ª–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è –∏ –ø—Ä–∏—É—Ä–æ—á–µ–Ω–Ω–æ–º—É –º–æ–µ–º—É –≤–æ–∑–≤—Ä–∞—â–µ–Ω–∏—è –≤ –∏–≥—Ä—É –Ω–∏ –æ–¥–Ω–∞ –∏–∑ —Å–ø–æ—Å–æ–±–æ–º. –ú–∞–∫—Å–∏–º–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –¥–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ –ø—Ä—ã–∂–∫–∞ —Å–º–µ–Ω–∏–ª–æ—Å—å –Ω–∞ –∑–∞–≥—Ä—É–∂–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –≥—Ä—É–∑–æ–≤—ã–µ –æ—Ç—Å–µ–∫–∏ –∏ –¥–ª–∏–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –ø–µ—Ä–µ–ª—ë—Ç—ã –æ—Ç –º–æ—ë –º–Ω–µ–Ω–∏–µ –æ–± –∏–≥—Ä–µ –Ω–∞ 2020 –≥–æ–¥ –Ω–µ –ø–æ–º–µ–Ω—è–ª–æ—Å—å. –°–ø–æ—Å–æ–± –¥–æ–±—ã—á–∏ –¥–µ–Ω–µ–≥ –≤ –±–æ–ª–µ–µ –ø—Ä–∏–±—ã–ª—å–Ω–æ–º –æ–±—ä—ë–º–µ —Å–≤–æ–¥–∏–ª—Å—è –∫ –∫–∞–º–µ–Ω–æ–ª–æ–º–Ω–µ –∞—Å—Ç–µ—Ä–æ–∏–¥–æ–≤, –Ω–∞—Ö–æ–∂–¥–µ–Ω–∏–∏ –≤ –Ω–∏—Ö –∞–ª–º–∞–∑–æ–≤/–æ–ø–∞–ª–æ–≤, –∞ –∑–∞—Ç–µ–º –≤—ã–∂–∏–¥–∞–Ω–∏–∏ —Å–∞–º–æ–π –≤—ã–≥–æ–¥–Ω–æ–π —Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ü–∏–∏ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Å–∫–∞–Ω–∏—Ä—É—é—â–∏–π —Å–∞–π—Ç, —á—Ç–æ–±—ã –ø–æ–ª—É—á–∏—Ç—å 1–∫–∫-1,5–∫–∫ –∑–∞ –∫–∞–∂–¥—É—é –µ–¥–∏–Ω–∏—Ü—É –ø–µ—Ä–µ—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–≥–æ –≥—Ä—É–∑–æ–≤–æ–≥–æ —Ç—Ä—é–º–∞. –ü–æ–º–∏–º–æ –∑–Ω–∞–Ω–∏–π –≥–¥–µ –∏ –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Å—ë —ç—Ç–æ –¥–æ–±—Ä–æ –Ω–∞—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å, –Ω—É–∂–Ω–æ —Å–ø–µ—Ü–∏–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–µ –æ–±–æ—Ä—É–¥–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∏ –≤–µ–∑–µ–Ω–∏–µ –Ω–∞—Ç–∫–Ω—É—Ç—å—Å—è –Ω–∞ –∞—Å—Ç–µ—Ä–æ–∏–¥ —Å –Ω—É–∂–Ω—ã–º —Ç–µ–±–µ —è–¥—Ä–æ–º. –ö–æ–º—É-—Ç–æ —ç—Ç–æ –∑–∞–Ω—è—Ç–∏–µ –ø–æ–∫–∞–∂–µ—Ç—Å—è —É–Ω—ã–ª—ã–º –∏ –∑–∞—Ç—è–Ω—É—Ç—ã–º, –∫—Ç–æ-—Ç–æ –Ω–∞–¥–µ–µ—Ç—Å—è –Ω–∞ –∫–æ–º–ø—Ä–æ–º–∏—Å—Å, —á—Ç–æ –Ω–∞–∫–æ–ø–∏—Ç –Ω–∞ –Ω—É–∂–Ω—ã–π –∫–æ—Ä–∞–±–ª—å –∏ –æ—Ç–æ–π–¥—ë—Ç –æ—Ç –¥–µ–ª, –Ω–∞ –¥–µ–ª–µ –∂–µ –Ω–∞–≥—Ä—É–∂–∞–µ—Ç –∫–æ—Ä–∞–±–ª—å —Ç–∞–∫, —á—Ç–æ —Å—Ç–æ–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç—å –≤–æ—Å—Å—Ç–∞–Ω–æ–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏—è —Ç–∞–∫–æ–≤–æ–≥–æ –ø–µ—Ä–µ–≤–∞–ª–∏–≤–∞–µ—Ç –∑–∞ –µ–¥–∏–Ω–∏—Ü—É –ø—Ä–æ–¥–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–≥–æ —Å—ã—Ä—å—è –∏ –≤–∞—Ä—å–∏—Ä—É–µ—Ç—Å—è –æ—Ç 1,3–∫–∫ –∑–∞ –Ω–∞–ø–∏—á–∫–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–π Asp Explorer –∏ 2,35–∫–∫-5,8–∫–∫ –∑–∞ –æ–±–∞ –≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç–∞ —Å–¥–µ–ª–∞—Ç—å –∏–∑ Python –±–æ–µ–≤—É—é —Ñ–µ—Ä–º–µ—Ä—Å–∫—É—é –º–∞—à–∏–Ω—É. –Ø –±—ã–ª –¥–∏–∫–æ –æ–ø–µ—á–∞–ª–µ–Ω, –∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –≤—Å—ë —Ç–æ—Ç –∂–µ —Å—Ç—Ä–∏–º—Å–Ω–∞–π–ø–µ—Ä, —É–ø–æ–º—è–Ω—É—Ç—ã–π –≤ –Ω–∞—á–∞–ª–µ –æ–±–∑–æ—Ä–∞. –≠—Ç–æ –±—ã–ª–æ –Ω–µ—á—Ç–æ –∏–∑ –∑–∞–ª–ø–∞ –ø–æ–ª—É—Å–æ—Ç–Ω–∏ –º–∞—è—á–∞—â–∏—Ö —Ä–∞–∫–µ—Ç–Ω–∏—Ü –±–µ–∑ –≤–æ–∑–º–æ–∂–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ —É–π—Ç–∏ –æ—Ç —Å—Ç–æ–ª–∫–Ω–æ–≤–µ–Ω–∏—è —Å –Ω–∏–º–∏, –∞ —Å–∏—Ç—É–∞—Ü–∏—è —Å –ø—É—Å—Ç—ã–º –±–∞–∫–æ–º –≤–≤–µ–ª–∞ –º–µ–Ω—è –≤ —Ç—É–ø–∏–∫. –ü–æ–∫–∞ –¥–µ–Ω–µ–≥ —Ö–≤–∞—Ç–∞–µ—Ç, –º–æ–∂–Ω–æ –≤—ã–∫—É–ø–∞—Ç—å –∫–æ—Ä–∞–±–ª–∏ {"text": "I finished a full 30-day play of papers, please and found that it is a game I would rather enjoy watching people more than actually playing it myself honestly.  Doing the checking paperwork thing was cool and refreshing at the start but as days dragon the game gradually became more of a 'chore' or 'work' type of simulation where I forgot that this was even a game in the first place.  That in itself was perhaps the essence which makes anything irritating and despicable which simply aggravates me to end and makes me cringe every time I think about it.    If players can choose whether to have a timer in story mode for each day or even adjust the speed of such timer that would have been a wiser choice:  this removes the pressure of quality vs. efficiency for those who do not desire it--a luxury which is simply not possible in real-life working environments.   Also, one should be able to freely modify the key bindings (e.g., tab for inspect instead of pulling out stamps, etc.) according to one‚Äôs own preference because I've been mixing up tab and spacebar way too frequently to call it remotely negligible and that has cost me valuable time on many occasions unsurprisingly. The voiceovers are nothing but mumbles or grumbles from said characters which is palatable to the extent that such a design choice do not really provoke one's emotional nature in any shape or form.  Even if full voiceovers are simply too much budget for an indie game, I feel like the developers could have made each individual trying to cross into Arstozka more human-like attributes and not only someone who you'd think of as a mere data block in a registry of perhaps hundreds of thousands of such similarly-motivated people where they would be forgotten as soon as they cross over to the other side.  At the very least it would make even the simulated terrorist attacks feel more personal and relatable. Despite the various shortcomings, I still like this game somewhat and would recommend whole-heartedly to anyone who are forgiving of aforementioned design flaws and also possess feverish sentiment for a vividly-provoking but not quite realistic working simulator that poses itself as a plausible indie game for the masses.  With imperfectly implemented in-game mechanics and a whole lot of depressing colour scheme, papers, please is the kind of indie simulator for those lazy Sunday afternoons when you got nothing else to do and feel like working overtime for a change.", "appid": "239030", "steamid": "profiles/76561198084628792", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "3", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1415966400.0}

{"text": "From the company who brought you the Golden Horse Armor DLC that started the (unwanted) DLC and microtransaction craze, and more recently, the epic (disappointment) game Fallout 76, comes the Quake III / Quake Arena / Quake Live reboot, Quake Champions! Are you a veteran Quake III player who wants to feel like a boss?  This game is for you!  Are you a noob who wants to get pwned and be a constant punching bag for a group of elite players? This game is for you!  Are you a regular player who wants to spend countless hours attempting to learn all the tricks and tips and attempt to reach godly Rapha levels of expertise (but likely never get there)?  This game is for you! Want to save yourself a headache and hours of frustration?  Then stay clear away from this game.  It pains me to say it, since I personally have almost 1500 hours into this game, but there is nothing here but pretty graphics and constant heartache.  If you like constant disappointment with your match outcomes, game stutters, and microtransactions, then, please, by all means, pick this one up. I could have learned to play a musical instrument in 1500 hours, rather than wasting my time on a game that gave me little overall pleasure and feeling of accomplishment. Quake Con 2018 drew in a large crowd of players who promptly dropped this like the pile of doo doo that it is. With the glaring negativity you have read so far, I do have to say that there is some good to this game.  I've made quite a few friends and had a blast playing with them privately.  (Also due to Twitch, since its hard to make friends directly through this game).  BUT, this game attempts to keep you in public matches with elite players, by offering you constant experience on public matches over private matches so you can get the latest and greatest cosmetic rewards.  If you are not a completionist or don't need every bit of visual customization there exists out there, and you have some friends to play with, then I would definitely recommend this game for a good time.  The various game modes they offer allow you to switch things up when you get bored with gameplay. This game does not allow you to feel like you are completing anything, but rather feel like you are going through the same process again and again, playing a match, dying (a lot) and returning to the lobby to wait for the next match.  That's it.  There's currently still no story or single player campaign, like Quake III had.  It's just a game to pass time.  Oh, and if you don't learn how to use the secret, little known abilities such as bunny hopping or strafe jumping, you'll be a sitting duck for everyone and everything else.  A game without clear followable movement rules that allows everyone to prosper equally, no story, and littered with microtransations (and yes, still loot boxes) is no game at all to feel as though you are a winner at.  This is why this game suffers so much with people who have not been a long-time Quake Arena / Quake III player. In addition, the game's management has been poor.  Both developmentally and community-wise.  The leadership on this game has been abysmal.  Instead of good development practices and a a community manager who engages the community, there's been setbacks, less than optimal code and releases, and ignored, and even targeted community policy changes. I guess with me, its a love / hate relationship.  I love the community I have built with playing this game, the friends I have made, but I hate thinking about how miserable and mismanaged this game is by the company.  And its not in the background either, since this game is still in EA and they are always tweaking both the game and community policies.  You can't look at the game as just a poorly released game, but a poorly ongoing mismanaged game.  That in itself is a complete turnoff for me in general. Not sure what Quake III / Quake Arena / Quake LIve is and want to know about the actual gameplay?  Games are set up as matches, where 8 players are dropped into a map / level, usually arena / round shaped (not linear like a single player level), and the goal is to have the most points to win.  The game could be made up of two 4 player teams, or 8 singles, and each player has an array of weapons to pick up and use against the others.  In most game modes, one kill is one point.  The most points win. They also have capture the flag, where the same killing rules are in place, but you get points for retrieving the other team's flag and bringing it back to your flag.  Slipgate mode, where you are focusing on capturing the other team's base for a certain time period to win.  Instagib, where it is one hit one kill with a railgun (pixel perfect shots).  And other various game modes such as rocket launchers and lightening guns without any splash (self-damage) damage.  Ah, yes, and duel mode where you can pick 3 characters against another player's 3 characters, and the first to lose all 3 (playing one at a time) loses. The community itself currently is not toxic either, I'd say you'll meet more decently good people than not.  Now, if Bethesda can just figure out how to manage their community better and bring a better game where people can feel like they can accomplish something or feel like a boss after being beaten down after several matches, they might just bring this game back to life.", "appid": "611500", "steamid": "profiles/76561197987948166", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "129", "votes_funny": "30", "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1563883200.0}

{"text": "I'm not sure how to start this review. I kinda want to just type: \"Horrible. Avoid.\" But I'd imagine you'd like to know the reasons. The game is primarily driven by dialog and narration. Neither of which is worthwhile. It is mired in political propaganda. Making most of the lines truly \"cringy\". (As they seem written to make a point, rather than support the story.) Dialog options are useless. Each time you get an option, you must choose. However, every choice in a set is basically the same. There is little variation between choices. Ultimately, nothing you choose matters to the end result. The in-game animations run at about 1.5 fps. No, there's nothing wrong with my computer. Further frames of animation are simply not there. Character designs aren't bad, but are overly simple. As if they were made by a child, or a year-one art student. Also, where is the color? Why is   in color   the main characters? The makers of HIVESWAP are proud the game has no challenge. They shouldn't be. The only interesting moments are torn away from you as quickly as possible. Creating a sense of dullness and boredom. {"text": "There's a catastrophic amount of audio desynchronisation issues, which the developers are by their own admission incapable of addressing. Worse still, the options for managing calibration are woefully inadequate, consisting of a single system-wide timing slider, despite the fact that every song has a different amount of desync. That alone should be enough to sink any rhythm game, but the design philosophy of form over function means that even on songs that are actually playable the constantly flashing background images can make it near-impossible to see the notes that you're meant to hit sliding in from off-screen, making it a game of memory rather than reaction or rhythm. Combine that with the console-style price points and it's impossible to recommend this over any other PC rhythm game. There's hundreds of completely free games out there that do the basics so much better, go play those instead.", "appid": "744060", "steamid": "profiles/76561198028125071", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "11", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1562932800.0}

{"text": "Jogo √© uma bosta ! servidor com lag mesmo com ping baixo e net de 200 Mb", "appid": "625340", "steamid": "profiles/76561198115852364", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1606219200.0}
{"text": "I was hoping this would be like the excellent Jedi Outcast or Jedi Academy games but it is nothing like them. This is a buggy console port with clunky controls, a god awful camera, and unsatisfying combat. The controls are bad with either keyboard/mouse or controller. General movement is much better with a mouse and the camera actually works fine with mouse, but doing combos and especially moving/throwing objects with force grip is easier with a controller (though still clunky). Force grip in this game is kind of important. There are always objects around you to grip and throw at enemies or grip enemies themselves. You also need to grip and manipulate objects to progress which is much harder to do with a mouse. Some moves and combos require you to press two buttons at the same time, one particular move requires three buttons, which are far easier to do on a controller. Also my mouse sensitivity became super high when I gripped light objects which made throwing them accurately next to impossible. So I'd recommend using a controller as it's less bad. However, with a controller that leads to the next problem... The camera. It's the worst. It doesn't work properly with controller. It consistently fails to rotate to where you're facing when you turn. You have to manually do it yourself ALL the time. Having to rotate the camera when you're in the heat of battle is annoying. Actually, having to turn the camera anytime is annoying. I don't know why it works fine with mouse but not with controller but it's irritating as hell.  Then you get to the combat and it becomes repetitive and frustrating especially with the poor controls. Turning is less accurate with a controller so you'll miss your targets a lot more when using force powers. I said earlier that using force grip is easier with controller but focusing on the object you want to grip can be a challenge because you have to be looking right at it which is harder to do with a controller.  In later levels you will constantly face off against a bunch of enemies  all at the same time that can resist your force powers, snipe you, use homing rockets, stunlock you while everyone shoots you, and it just becomes a chore. You can get knocked down with a rocket and it takes like three seconds to get back up for some stupid reason and someone else fires a rocket right as you stand and you're knocked down again. Suddenly you don't feel like such a bad a—ï—ï sith anymore. There are also quicktime events when fighting stronger enemies and bosses, because timed button presses are always fun and exciting and never get old.  You can't manually save your game. The menu has a save option but it doesn't work. You only have checkpoints and sometimes they're poorly placed and right before a cutscene so if you die you gotta watch it again and again because the cutscenes are unskippable. Sound/voice is also missing from some levels. Even using the recommended fix doesn't solve it. I had to copy the sound files from the disc version of the game (don't ask me how I got it) and transfer it to the game's folder to actually fix it. Great job devs. Oh yea this game is also locked at 30fps. You can download a fix to raise it but it causes issues with force grip which is already bad enough.  The 3 bonus levels you get with the Ultimate Sith Edition (accessible after you finish the main game and start a new game) aren't anything special. It's more of the same and the storyline is completely absurd for two of the levels. Just to give you an example:    This is another subpar console port with underwhelming, mediocre gameplay. Save yourself time and frustration and give it a pass.", "appid": "32430", "steamid": "profiles/76561198086212592", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "9", "votes_funny": "4", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1467115200.0}

{"text": "*CONTAINS SPOILERS* Story centers around an investigation regarding a corrupt sheriff.(Corrupt is putting it mildly, he's a racist, murdering bastard). Sounded promising when I started the first mission, and as always, the cinematics are great in this game... But holy crap was I disappointed.  The story missions in this DLC will take you two hours tops, and the majority of that time is spent driving around like a maniac. Endless waves of sheriff deputies will come at you, but don't worry, the new car you get is basically a tank. You preform crazy stunts, shooting red barrels, and blow up ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. It feels like something that belongs in a Saints Row game. Don't get me wrong, Saints Row is great, but the craziness that is Saints Row doesn't fit in Mafia III. Crazy jumps with an indestructible car, laying waste to a whole town while mowing down the cops, it just made me laugh. {"text": "Polyventure, while having great music and some immersive environments is a very experimental, EXTREMELY minimalistic game. While I am a fan of experimental, abstract, and minimalistic walking sims this game simply doesn't have enough depth to it beyond enjoying a few chill songs while wandering around static, somewhat ethereal environments.  Polyventure seems to be more or less just about wandering around strange locales while a chill \"Pure Moods\" ish sounding song plays in the background. While I was initially very captivated with the game and its opening Enigma - Sadeness sounding tune, it quickly became apparent that the game involved very little (to no) player interaction, instead consisting of the player meandering aimlessly about while a snippet of a song plays, looking at a few things (are all of the environments shown in the trailer?) before being warped out of that environment and onto the next \"hub\" area which has 4 pillars of colorful light (seen in the trailer) that the player can walk into. These are all unique but once inside of them there is no purpose to the player to complete (which is fine...) but save for one area involving some optional platforming along clouds there doesn't seem to be any player interaction required at all in Polyventure. Although I still enjoyed the music and can admire Polyventure as a piece of interactive \"art\" or as an interesting way to market the musical tracks, I can't recommend it at its baseline asking price of 4.99. Had the songs also been packaged into a soundtrack on Steam, then it would be a kind of cool experimental EP to pick up, however marketed in its store description as \"a game based on beautiful atmospheres and lucid dreaming, to concern about endangered species and the enviroment\" is injecting far more purpose into the title than is evident to any of the player during their sparse interactions with the level design.", "appid": "781520", "steamid": "profiles/76561198173606567", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "6", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1543492800.0}

{"text": "bune amk", "appid": "378370", "steamid": "profiles/76561198314011000", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1511611200.0}
{"text": "Necronator: Dead Wrong is an interesting premise let down by being released too early. The RPG card battler genre fused with an autobattler is a fun mix, but there isn‚Äôt enough content to justify the game‚Äôs price. Everything is quite repetitive and the AI eventually devolves into a spam fest instead of using tactics.   Before a run is started, the player is able to choose from the two currently available  commanders which each focus on a different theme. The first general is an undead knight that focuses on buffing units in her hand until even the weakest unit becomes a formidable opponent. The second commander is an undead puppet master who changes the game up a bit by having cards that are essentially towers. This in turn makes Necronator feel more like a traditional tower defense game. In my experience with both of these characters, the undead knight is quite a bit more powerful than the puppet master. This is because the knight is able to make weak units strong for relatively low mana costs. The puppet master‚Äôs puppets are strong, especially due to the fact that they can be summoned anywhere around an allied building, but the towers she summons are much too expensive for the their hitpoint pool and relative damage. Especially the Teddy Bear card that takes eighty mana for a unit that is not much stronger than a soldier skeleton.  The overworld is quite similar to the one found in other RPG card battlers in that there are branching paths that can be planned and have differing purposes. The most common are battles, but stores dot the map as do resting spots that provide health, card upgrades, or card removal. Shops require gold and allow for one card to be removed for a cost. Units are summoned using mana that is accumulated over time. Units are mainly undead or demons in appearance and they have health, attack, armor, and movement speed stats. The main issue that I have with the units is that there are only eight kinds of units and they are all pretty similar except for an ability. These abilities aren‚Äôt very unique either as other units can often gain these abilities with an upgrade. There are some unique upgrades that I would love to see more of and did make units unique, though they are pretty rare. The best upgrades were for the healer unit. The player could get an attack speed aura, increase the healing aura it emitted, or a rare upgrade was to spawn three weak, albeit, free units every fifteen seconds.  Enemy units have the same issue that player units have in that there is very little variety. Enemy units usually come in five or six varieties and have additional abilities applied to them based upon how hard the battle is, such as an elite battle. Enemies also don‚Äôt seem to cost the AI any mana, unlike the player. This makes it so that the AI‚Äôs strategy late game is to simply spam an ungoldy amount of units that are quite difficult to beat. The main way to defeat the AI in the early game is by focusing on cheap units with armor breaker. These will rip through the strong enemy units that it spawns as a challenge. The late game strategy is to get lots of units with Area of Effect attacks. The main issue I had with this is that the units with Area of Effect attacks are quite expensive in terms of mana which makes it difficult to compete against the legions of enemy units that run at the player. An interesting concept this game employs is that both the player as well as the AI gets artifacts. The main issue I found is that there are a good amount of player artifacts that are useless, while the AI has a ton of really strong artifacts. Two of the useless artifacts I received were coupons that made cards at the shop cheaper which wasn‚Äôt an issue due to money being really easy to obtain. The second artifact would summon nine powerful units, but only if the player played six of each card type, which was not realistic at all. Some artifacts such as enchanted pillar which provides more mana are almost required for a good run. Enemy artifacts are powerful as they often punish the player‚Äôs deck with useless cards.  Battles are fought on a three-dimensional map that has a certain path that units follow. Later maps have additional paths that can be chosen between by the player by modifying the direction a sign is facing. Battle is rather zen, but gets annoying later on in a run. This is because there are small villages that provide extra control and start out under enemy control. Late game, if the player does not get these villages in about a minute and a half, they have lost.  Battle maps don‚Äôt have a lot of variety and are simply reskins. This feels lazy and unpolished. There is a minor story, but it isn‚Äôt interesting. The player has a summoning crystal fused to them and they have to find the great Necronator. The traveling companion to the player‚Äôs chosen commander is a cute bat character named Chubat.  The sound design isn‚Äôt especially good in Necronator. The music gets quite repetitive very quickly, so much so that I turned it off withing the first ten minutes I played the game. The sounds can also get cacophonous as many units attacking each other all making attacking sounds playing over each other does not sound enjoyable at high to moderate volume levels. The graphics are the best part of the game. The game is three-dimensional in nature, but the textures are styled after pixel art which creates a diorama feeling. This is further compounded by the fact that all of the units in the game are pixel art sprites.  The controls are quite frustrating to deal which is surprising considering keyboard and mouse is rather accurate. When trying to pan using the left mouse button, sometimes it doesn‚Äôt work when the player accidentally mouses over their hand full of cards. The game also feels too much like a mobile port. To move the camera without accessing the camera menu, the player must swipe left or right with the mouse while hold the right mouse button.  :  The game feels pretty buggy, especially with the pathfinding AI. This AI never seems to know where to go and gets stuck rather frequently. After about 5 hours I felt like I had already seen everything. Due to this, the twenty USD price tag is too high to justify the amount the amount of content in it.    üëç   üëç Beautiful graphics üëé   üëé Low enemy variety Few units to use Repetitive gameplay", "appid": "1144970", "steamid": "profiles/76561198055780740", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "38", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1596456000.0}

{"text": "JULIA is... an okay game. The varied settings, atmosphere and general pacing of the game kept me glued til I completed the game.... but I have to say that it climaxed about 75-80% into the game for me and sort of sputtered in the end. The story got wilder and wilder and introduced some unnecessary layers and characters. The visuals are great and I love the accompanying background music (unintrusive, good looping, sets the mood just right), and some of the main characters are quite memorable, but I doubt I'll remember or care about the story even a week from now. The game interactions are heavily flavored with computer assisted interfaces and graphics. This fits in with the storyline and actually works well to frame your limited options. If it weren't for this, I would make a bigger deal from the fact that YOU CANNOT PAN THE VIEW in any scenes. There are hotspots that you can click, and they may let you zoom in\\out of points of interests or lets you move between places. NO ANIMATED zoom in\\out motion or movement between spots, except for the cutscenes. Most of the screens have animated parts, though (flickering light, billowing dusts, etc) so you'd never think that you're staring at a static picture. Oh, another negative point for this game is that the puzzles are generic ones that are skinned to fit within the game's universe. That's right, (just) visually skinned to fit in. They look right for the settings, but bears minimal logical connection to the storyline. The ones that tied in the most to the storyline that I can think of are the language translation puzzles and the password guessing ones. {"text": "I had my eye on Chaosbane for some time as both a fan of Diablo-style ARPGs and Warhammer, but passed over it at launch and thereafter due to is very mixed reception. I heard about the upcoming added Witch Hunter class and was motivated to finally take the plunge. Having now tried it at a sale price, I can say it's not really my thing, and that is disappointing. I do like the game, but it didn't grab me like an ARPG ought to. By all means try it for yourself, especially if you have someone to try the local coop with. I expected a situation where the beginning gameplay would be entertaining and that if I stuck with it I would encounter the dearth of endgame content so often referred to in other reviews, but as you can see from my play time I obviously did not get that far. I cannot pinpoint what about Chaosbane turned me off other then the general slowness of the combat flow, but 40k Inquisitor also has this and that in of itself did not kill that game or this one for me. There is just something... off about Chaosbane's basic gameplay. It made me want to go play either Vermintide 2 or a different ARPG. Chaosbane seems competently designed, taking several mechanical cues from Diablo 3 that kept me playing that game for so long: recharging health potion, a range of AoE and movement skills, easily redistributed skill allocations, et cetera. The basics are there, but the X factor is not. It lacks the charm and mod support of Torchlight 2, the audio/visual flair and breakneck combat pace of Diablo 3 or the oomph and diverse character builds of Grim Dawn.  I must say I am impressed that it has a local coop option, and that alone almost made me decide to keep the game, but it's hard getting even one other person to play these sorts of games with me. It wouldn't be the first time I enjoyed a game in coop that I didn't alone. {"text": "Here is the thing, It isn't exactly the game itself, as much as it is the community. When the game first came out, the community for it was amazing! Everywhere you looked, you could see a player in every map. It was a game where you had to work together to make any progress. You knew the big name players; FangBlade, Tigger, CurryIsHot, etc. The community was there. It was loving, it was caring, it was a game that you wanted to play with friends instead of alone. It wasn't so much how long it took to get somewhere, as opposed to how you got there. Now the game is just too quick and easy to do anything. There are far too many classes, and instead of using skills from each class; (for example, one of the most famous party quests, the Ludibrium Tower PQ, you NEEDED to have at least a magician and a thief in your party otherwise you could not complete the party quest) is now replaced with 'HEY I CAN BEAT EVERY BOSS IN THE GAME IN 2 DAYS BY MYSELF BECAUSE I BOUGHT NX'. It just doesn't have the same player base, and I believe that is the reason so many people are quitting. As someone who has played since 2006, these 10 years have really brought a change to my eyes on the game I once loved. Here are some key points: 1) The game is too rushed now. I know leveling slow sounds boring, but back in the day the excitement of getting to level 21 after hours of work so you can start Kerning PQing with your friends. Getting your 2nd job took work and then going to Ludi PQ was another fun adventure when you had friends to do it with. Getting tracks and looking for the best 'clicker' to get you into the PQs and what not. It was fun. Someone being level 70 back then was amazing. You'd look up to them. Now you can get it within 5 hours of playing hard. When Zakum first came out, for a long time there was a select few who could even dream about getting a zakum helmet, now everyone has one. 2) Pay to win. They added all this new stuff to upgrade your items like cubes and I don't even know what else. Back in the day the only thing that NX bought you was cool hair, clothes and pets. Now, if you wana be the best at this game, you have to pay a lot of money for it with cubes, and other NX items. 3) Simplicity. This is what is turning me off at the moment. Back when I played, there was only Mage, Bowmen, Theifs and Warriors (and the rare 'beginner' main), and it was awsome. Each class had strengths and weaknesses at different points in the game, and the world wasn't too gaint to explore. The old saying 'if it ain't broke don't fix it' I think. People enjoyed making one of each of the 4 classes (even more if you wanted Spearman, fighter, F/P mage, clerics, bandits etc). Now, when I opened maplestory, I see like 20 different classes at least, and each probably have their own sub-classes, it's just too much imo. Back then it was easy to balance (in fact they almost never had to balance any classes cause they were so equal) but, I imagine with this many classes now, sometimes they get out of balance and certain ones outshine heavily.", "appid": "216150", "steamid": "profiles/76561198079105032", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "37", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1475150400.0}

{"text": "Game Type: Hex-based Tactical RPG. Summary: Awesome visuals are outweighed by stale story, poor mechanics, and lots of bugs. Pros: The artwork and models for the time WERE TO DIE FOR. I mean absolutely gorgeous. Clearly where they blew their budget. Neutrals: Setting: Fairly run of the mill set up. Elves live in the woods, shoot bows, love trees; humans are dirty peasants, noble knights, and a corrupt totally not Catholic Church; lastly demons are super evil and nasty. Gameplay: Kinda bland with most units just taking turns using basic attacks just slapping each other back and forth. Cons: Story: Very boring story with the world's most boring narrator. Seriously, it's like they went looking for the most bland voice actor they could find. Difficulty: Every map your units besides the main characters start at level 1 with no promotions. This means they have the durability of wet paper. However if you have the right buildings when a unit levels up he can upgrade to his next archetype. This leads to nonsense like being a low level unit the whole map or being end game tier units after just a handful of battles. Basically way too hard to start way too easy at finish. {"text": "I do not precisely know what's the best point to watch upon this game. Do you like achievements? Ten minutes, maybe twenty, no more. You have just to visit all the locations - no, it's not that big - and purchase the costumes, do the voting thing and just keep on watching your autoclicker do its job. The Italian translation is one of the best I saw here on Steam. Every single time I wonder about who and how makes these translation. It's simply awesome. We have literally to \"accumulare il ritiro dalla nascita\". Which means something like \"accumulate the retreat from the beginning\". This seems more of an Italian war simulator, you know, we usually begin to think about switching sides before even starting the conflict. But probably something got lost in translation - maybe \"retirement\" in English, which translates to \"pensionamento\" in Italian? I don't really know how one should be supposed to retreat since he's born.. =P For the sake of having something fun in a negative review I chose to maintain the Italian language in-game too, being welcomed by a screen that tells me that Russia is the \"miglior paese per i restanti\". Something like \"the best country for those who stay\" (since \"restare\" is like, \"resta a casa\" with this COVID epidemics, \"stay at home\"!). Unluckily I've been to Russia and also many times to Ukraine and former USSR countries but I don't have that much experience so let's see what we can do here if we are \"restanti\" that accumulate \"ritiri\" from the start. Ok guys I'm just stopping here, it's clear that I'm just making fun of a long machine translated thing, if \"la tua zucca si risolve all'ospedale\" which literally means \"your head (\"zucca\" is quite vulgar =P) resolves in a hospital\" - in how much time? The graphics and overall the whole game is ridiculously designed, everything looks like it's been taken like Whatsapp stickers and put upon badly drawn backgrounds. We are greeted though with the awesome Russian anthem throughout the whole game. It repeats itself over and over, there are no other sounds apart some stupid effects. Somehow, I really love Slavic countries anyways. Definitely. My Cyrillic tattoo on my right arm puzzles many guys here in Northern Italy. And it's in Ukrainian, too. The game is just a pointless clicker, and as I said with a normal autoclicker you can clear everything easily. You simply get money by clicking and you can buy something like.. clothes and things to eat or something like that. So, with an autoclicker, you'll easily get all the money you'll need. Once you'll get to 100 rubles or whatever that is, you'll be able to buy a new background, basically. There's some of them, some \"stages\" in which nothing changes. You can change the \"skin\" of your clickable thing which goes basically from worst to even worst graphical content. Take a peek at all the screenshots I'm quite sad about the fact that this game has tons of fake reviews - i.e.: dozens of Italian reviews, for instance, all positive, made up by some words clearly machine-translated with lots of errors and made by fake accounts. Anyways. Summing everything up. It's a clicker, you'll be able to get all the achievements in less than half an hour with an autoclicker, and there's nothing funny or particularly amusing here. Just boring and without any kind of entertainment or replayability value since it's all about clicking and buying images of things. If you're European try to travel to the East and you'll find some of the most beautiful countries, cultures and people of the whole world. And I have no Slavic blood at all, but just trust me, visit everything there if you can! The levels are VERY small like not the size overall but 1 level feels like a coridor with like 1 a bit larger and open area thats it. There is just too little space to roll around the enemys. Like i dont know how you can optimize a game like that. I have a i7 8700k and a GTX 1070 16gb RAM and in some places i get 35 Fps like this is just horrible and very bad made. {"text": "This was the first game that brought me to Steam when I bought the hardcopy back in, whenever it was released (dif. account). I think that, over the years, the main thing that always bugged me was the unit sprite draw distance; the distance at which units on the map degraded in graphical quality to preserve rendering speed. Apart from that, the game has to be played at maximum difficulty to present any challange, and powerful countries such as England and France sometimes invade you even though historically it wouldn't make sense.  Then there is the Ottoman Empire which takes huge chunks of time during the turn-switch, because it creates a million single-stack armies which all have to be moved aimlessly and whatnot - best to defeat the ottomans or weaken them early-on to save 3 minutes per turn.  I have had a hate-love relationship with this game as I love the time period and the potential, but the poor execution of the game itself is a big turn-off.  Below is a small list of features. {"text": "I was an enthusiastic member of the 7D2D community, buying copies for friends and even paying for a hosted server. Sadly, it became clear to me that the devs, while very talented, are constantly tinkering with their creation instead of finishing it. New mechanics are added, old ones are completely redone, and each new version of the game has significant differences from the previous. Normally, I would consider this a sign of progress in an early access game, but in this case, instead of following a roadmap towards completion and release, this game is not really any closer to coming out of early access than it was years ago. Consider that the three reviews listed on the store page are from 2013 - 2014 and that there have been a multitude of changes since then, so those \"endorsements\" are a bit deceiving. And each new alpha revision introduces a host of bugs, while it is difficult to eliminate existing bugs when the core coding is not complete. Most successfully released games establish a stable core, and then have a list of must-have features followed by the \"wouldn't it be nice?\" ones. 7D2D keeps tinkering with its core and tries to add new items to the list at the same time.  Will you enjoy this game? Maybe. I did, and I got my money's worth. Unfortunately, I can't recommend it to people in general, not because it has the problems that many early access games have, but because after following the progress for five years, I no longer have faith that the developers will ever be able to release the game in a polished state. However, if you don't mind this and the fact the game may change significantly while you play it, then you may have fun with it still. The one thing this game does have going for it is that the devs are good at what they do, even if it does seem like they are constantly changing their minds on what to do next and how to do it.", "appid": "251570", "steamid": "profiles/76561198004661075", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "43", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1556971200.0}

{"text": "no more joke review >:( As one of their official Partnered Community Leaders, I was promised communication with the KurtzPel Team, and for the past few months that promise gradually began to fall through, and with it so did the morale of the other partners. The lack of transparency from the KurtzPel team for the past few months has taken a massive toll on this game, which you can evidently see on their official Discord and the current playercount. This game used to have around 3,000 concurrent players, and that number has steeped to a meager 1,000.  Overall tardiness to address issues and tardiness in issuing balance patches is a major factor to the resulting player count decline. They are willing to lose players because they want to save balance patches for a \"big update\" they have in store. This in hand means players will have to endure an entire month or two of repetitive gameplay that is plagued with poor balance and bugs. When the content update does come through, the \"balance\" changes generally lead to even more balance issues and thus, the cycle continues. The patch notes are released within a day before the actual patch, rendering player feedback for the new patch utterly useless as players do not have any intervention between these updates. There was once a period of time where they had a testing server which greatly alleviated some issues for a time, but the discontinuation of it has once again stirred more issues then it has fixed as the lack of community feedback intervention between updates for 2 months has shown to be quite detrimental to the game's health. In terms of actual gameplay and its surrounding aspects, issues that have plagued the game since launch still exist to this day. Noticeable server lag for the Asia and Europe regions. Simple bugs that were reported on day one that are still not fixed today. Unfair matchmaking and wintrading issues are still prominent. Game optimization has only gotten worse, with the addition of an unasked for server lobby changes that allows 50 more players in the lobby. Overall game rewards have declined immensely. The first Pre-Season awarded players with a variety of the game's lootboxes, dyes, and exclusive golden accessories as well as the usual in-game currency rewards (CP). The current Pre-Season right now only offers CP with no other incentives. For event rewards, for the past 2 months players were given Basic Boxes for staying logged in for 30 minutes, and the boxes for the majority of the time gave useless rewards and the infamous Basic Dye, which is roughly 3 cents. Even the current Christmas Event has rewards locked by a lootbox that functions very similar to the Basic Box, meaning players will generally get poor rewards and will most likely not be able to get most of the event exclusive items that may never return. They are hesitant to give formal responses to lingering and prominent issues of the game. Before players were given lengthy responses to the future and current state of the game, but now this game undergoes periods of times where you can do nothing but wait for the next update that hopefully fixes issues. For instance, a 20 minute PvE cooldown for all missions was initiated because the team thought there was an exploit that allowed unusually fast clears. Now, the PvE cooldown has been reduced to 10 minutes and no further explanation or follow up was given afterwards. It is very disheartening to see the game at a state like this, and the game's Early Access ends in 2020 as per their statement which you can see on the store page. Please know that I have no hard feelings against the company or their team members. But if there's anything I could want right now, I would want to come back to a game that properly acknowledges their community and listens to them.", "appid": "844870", "steamid": "profiles/76561198067940958", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "12", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1556625600.0}
