{"text": "I love brawler games such as Devil May Cry, Hack G.U, N3: Ninety-Nine Nights or Lords of the Fallen and so many other similar games where you can slay so many enemies without getting too bored with them. Unfortunately, this game didn't meet my expectations, at least not for an actual PC game. The game doesn't have bad graphics, if I could compare them to something similar, I would say Tales of Zestiria or Tales of Berseria. It's from the same company anyway, but that gives you an idea. The anti-aliasing wasn't that great however, I am playing on a 1080p monitor at this time and the graphic settings were on the highest possible. During my first hour of game-play, the game wasn't bad at all. The game intro was really cool along with the soundtrack in the background as well later during the character customization to make it sound so heroic. But then after 12 hours of game-play, I realized how repetitive the game actually is which makes the progression very difficult because it seems like the game only has at least 6 or 10 maps through the entire game, so that's pretty boring when you think about it that way. At this point, I'm pretty sure I've been playing in the same maps over 60 times each from difficulty 1 to difficulty 4. Each difficulty has between 10 to 40 missions the higher the difficulty is. Same goes for the monsters since later on, they're the same except they're re-skinned so that's a little bit boring. You get like one or two new times of monsters passed difficulty 3 then 6, but then the further you progress, the more often you'll see them so they're not rare or unique for long. The maps are also pretty small and there's a lot of strange corners here and there for nothing. Other problems are when you're fighting monsters in corners, you constantly have to give orders to your teammates to follow you so you don't end-up squished in there. The world itself seems pretty small since all you have is a tiny headquarter or something with 5 floors which count the mission gate, the elevator, a lab with a hallway, 3 doors and 2 out of 3 which are almost always locked, a veteran quarter with the same thing as the lab, and the recruit floor, which is also the same thing as the two others and some sort of research floor, which is the same thing as well. The story is great despite the fact that the created character doesn't talk and reply to everyone by nodding all the time or gesturing once in a while as if they were mute, but you have the option to choose the voice to be heard during battle so that makes things weirder. The quotes from each NPCs are also very repetitive, during and after a mission completed, the same quotes will come back almost every time. And if you decide to do a mission alone, your character will talk to himself or herself as if there was a group with them. I still couldn't figure out if the created character had a level or something, but gearing up later is highly focused on crafting and grinding through the game. The character creation is pretty awesome however. I like the clothing styles, it's very similar to S4 League or Phantasy Star Universe if anyone know one of those games. Every NPCs has their own and unique personality. If there's someone who likes Borderlands 2 and/or is a fan of the Mechromancer, the character named Kanon is pretty much just like her. Same awesome and hilarious personality for instance. The game lack of combos and fancy finisher or ultimate against monsters. After all, you're supposed to be some kind of monster slayer or something, and other NPCs are claiming that your character has special powers or abilities at the beginning of the game which other people don't seems to have. But that's not really the case, the NPCs can do the same things you do, so you're not really unique at the end of the day. A bit later through the game, you unlock some abilities called \"Predator moves\" but these things are nothing special, everyone can do it. Their only purpose is to give you some self-buffs or party-buffs or debuff your enemies as you devours them them with it. There's some bugs here and there, but they're minors at least. Monsters have no boundaries, they can hop and run out of the map unexpectedly while you're forced to remain on the map due to invisible walls. You can shoot them if they're out of the map unless as long as they're not clipping through buildings and stuff which can also happen if they jump away from you and decide to flee. Fortunately, it's a rare issue. It happened to me only two times or so. But it can be annoying when their weak points are the ones constantly clipping through stuff. I can't really recommend this game if you plan on having a lot of fun for hours, fighting enemies here and there, but it's a good way to kill boredom. Apparently this game is a port from the PS Vita so that would explain a few things. I would totally recommend Devil May Cry 1, 2, 3 or 4 over this game anytime however, but then you won't get the sweet character customization. If I could fix this game myself, I would throw the fighting style of .hack//G.U from the PlayStation 2 (A remake is coming to PS4 and PC by the way), and add much more maps to fight in along with new monsters for a better and bigger variation. Then the game would be great! But for now, I think I'll just keep playing it for the story and once I'm done with the story, I'll just move on to something else.", "appid": "460870", "steamid": "profiles/76561198088996579", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "9", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1500206400.0}

{"text": "Quite frankly, this game is having an identity crisis.  The games take place over a 30 day period, with each in-game year taking about 10 minutes. The game never pauses. All of this coalesces into a game that you would, ideally, be awake for 30 days straight for. Sleeping, going to work, going shopping are all things that people need to do to continue living, and doing any of those would leave your nation to rot. The time that it requires you to do anything makes you treat it like a mobile game- logging on every once in a while ang checking in. However, war and other player-driven evens can easily force you into constant vigilance during inopportune times.  It wants to be both an MMO and strategy game, but can't make those two sides happy with each other.  I could see something like this working as a single player turn-based strategy game, but as an MMO, it flops. The entire overtone is weird too. It's religious in a very eastern way, which isn't a bad thing. Or, wouldn't be. This game, rather than tell you what it means when it deals with spirituality, instead points you towards books. It understands that these concepts may be foreign to you, but BARELY helps you to understand them. Good ideas, interesting takes, bad followthrough. It doesn't know what it wants to be, and ends up being a chimera instead.", "appid": "1117160", "steamid": "profiles/76561198392731640", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "4", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1586001600.0}

{"text": "2 years after launch review. Bethesda's Preying for your money with this one! PROS : The game looks beautiful. Graphically it's the best game I've played in a long time. The game play loop will be very familiar for hardcore Dishonored players. Aesthetically, the game feels like Dishonored set in future, and in space. And that's actually a very good thing. Due to this, players opting for the stealth build will find much to love in this game. Level design is fantastic and Talos-I is a fantastic sci-fi playground. With that being said, a character build focusing on stealth is easily the most rewarding way to experience Prey. Everything from character models to UI will remind you that this is a game made by Arkane Studios with stealth in mind. That's all it boils down to, really. And that's not necessarily a bad thing either. CONS : Now coming to the bad things, the combat, while not horrible, is easily the most bad and also the most boring way to experience Prey. I didn't know this beforehand so after starting the game, I quickly focused on creating a combat focused Morgan. First mistake on my part. Depending on which route you take, you may encounter quite difficult enemies early on. Lacking the proper upgrades and weapons equals certain death for sure. And speaking of combat, the weapons available are also quite lackluster. They feel especially frustrating since there are only 2 weapons that deal any actual damage, the pistol and the shotgun. Rest of your arsnel includes a gloo gun, a disruptor, a ray gun which does 0 damage and a generic wrench. Thats it! If you were hoping for some badass looking futuristic sci-fi weapons, you're outta luck chum! As such, I whole-heartedly suggest you play as a stealth focused Morgan in Prey. 5/10 at full price. 7/10 at sale.", "appid": "480490", "steamid": "profiles/76561198370866756", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1565524800.0}

{"text": "First off: thanks to a good friend for the key. It was worth a try. Do I recommend this game? No, it feels like work actually. Being unbiased, I can say that   succeeds in being familiar yet original. It reunites elements of RTS, survival, management, board games and a bit of 4X (in the technologies research department). What bothers me is: I like pizza, chocolate, barbecue and hamburger, but not everything at the same time, got it? That's Northgard in a nutshell: it does everything at once, but not in an enjoyable way, at least for me.  For instance: the winter mechanic - it slows down the game and can easily put your food resources on negative - and for a real time game focused on annihilating other clans, it's just too much. If the game were turn-based, it would be fine (just take a look at the winter mechanic in Endless Legend, which works great, as you have time to plan your moves). The fact that this game doesn't have active pause also hurts those (like me) who prefer a more tactical approach.  While I do not recommend this game, I encourage you to give it a try, as this is a very fresh idea, made up of pillars from several different genres. This is more like a \"love it or have it\" kind of game, and in the end you might like it. Thankfully you can have a good picture of the gameplay under the two hour limit of the refund. Too bad I'm immune to the critical acclaim this game received. Well, no game is for everyone.", "appid": "466560", "steamid": "profiles/76561198064268501", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "22", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1593432000.0}

{"text": "No joke the game bugged out on launching and uninstalled itself KEK. Honestly one of the worst games i've ever experienced.", "appid": "1151340", "steamid": "profiles/76561198067410547", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "2", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1603627200.0}
{"text": "Let me start this by saying that the   is quite good. The fighting is solid, the campaign is... eh... it's a campaign, and the available multiplayer modes are mostly good. The only game modes newcomers will be able to (reliably) enjoy are Duels (1v1s), Brawls (2v2s), or co-op of the other modes and even that's questionable.  The reason is this: Gear stats, revenge, and environmental kills. If you disagree that's fine, you don't have to agree with me as this is subjective. If you'd like to refute these points, that's also fine but you are very unlikely to change my mind. All I ask is you read them, and if you choose to respond do so in a measured manner. In Elimination, Skirmish, and Dominion the stats on your equipment becomes active. This, at lower levels (I'd say lower than level 30 gear) makes very little difference in gameplay, most heroes of this level have pretty basic stats. But, when you get to higher gear levels (let's say 50+) you've made substantial changes to your attack, defense, or (most importantly) your revenge mode. Revenge is a mechanic that automatically parries all incoming attacks upon use, turns your parries into knockdowns, turns your throws into knockdowns, makes your attacks uninterruptable, and increases your attack/defense by a significant amount. This, in of itself, is not a bad thing. It is a very cool idea, and gives someone who's being attacked by multiple opponents a fighting chance. It is influenced by a number of stats: Revenge mode attack, revenge mode defense, revenge gain on defense, and revenge gain on injury. If you inflate any of these stats to a significant degree (especially the two revenge gains) you border on making yourself overpowered. The reason being that your revenge mode will now activate faster/be more powerful than your opponent's. This wouldn't be so bad... You can buy gear using real world money. Not only can you do that, you can also buy \"Champion Status\" that causes you to receive more gear after matches, more experience, more steel (currency), and get more salvage from destroying extraneous equipment. Yes, these things can all be ground out via in-game orders (daily missions) or repeatedly completing matches. If that changes things for you, that's fine, but it doesn't fix the imbalance for me.  Experience level determines received gear level, the amount of salvage you have determines how quickly you can level that gear, meaning that those who stump up the time or money for champion status have a definite advantage in these modes. Now, you might be thinking, \"What if I want to play Elimination or Domination without gear stats?\" Well... Ubisoft thinks you should play custom games, because  Alternatively you might be questioning, \"What about that Skirmish mode you mentioned?\" To answer that all I really need to say is: Skirmish is so badly broken that I don't know a single person who enjoys it (Yes, you probably exist and might even tell me you enjoy it, but at time of writing I've never met anyone who does). Skirmish is so bad that Ubisoft not only left it out of the open beta, but they felt they had to tack it onto their Elimination matchmaking to actually get people to play it. Also, orders that apply to Elimination can't be completed in Skirmish and vice versa. Notice how we're all the way down here and I haven't even gotten into networking issues? So let's open that can of worms too. There are no dedicated servers, meaning that you are forever on a P2P network. So the host's system gets overtaxed, their bandwidth is exploited, and (sometimes) when they leave the lobby shuts itself down, denying anyone in it gear, steel, and experience. Not only that but P2P networking on PC is dangerous. Both in the realm of cheating and information protection. Yes, there are likely safeguards in place. Yes, they could be close to (or completely) ironclad in some way. Now, as I've run out of things to complain about (for now), I'll do a quick roundup of bugbears both mentioned and unmentioned. So... uPlay... uPlay uPlay uPlay... You poorly performing moneygrab of a platform. To clue anyone who isn't aware in, uPlay only exists because Ubisoft doesn't like paying Steam to carry their games, just like Origin. Unlike Origin and EA, Ubisoft sells their games on Steam as well, with the caveat that you must install and run uPlay at all times while playing their games. It's buggy, slow, and causes their games to interact very poorly with the Steam overlay. In fact you can't use Steam to invite your friends to Ubisoft games, because the games aren't built to work with it (Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't, it's always seemed intentional to me). To put the cherry atop the poorly frosted and slightly burnt cake, the sex split for heroes is even. 3 male, 3 female, 3 that you can decide their sex. I can't be the only one that remembers when Ubisoft said it'd be too expensive to make two models in Assassin's Creed Unity for male/female assassins. In this game there are... 18 models that all have multiple gear sets, not counting NPCs. Yes. I know. Extraneous, but I still like poking fun at a corporation that doesn't respond truthfully to criticism. If you've made it this far, you have my thanks. Have a good one, and... yeah... I heartily recommend you do not buy this game, for the moment.", "appid": "304390", "steamid": "profiles/76561197991197832", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "5", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1487764800.0}

{"text": "I started playing the game relatively early and it has always been a torture,  the developers do things, but years too late.  Promises are made that are not kept. Who plays the game professionally knows that it is a single tragedy and the bad things outweigh the good ones.  There will surely be a lot of people still having fun with this title, after all there are some pretty well implemented things but the game has turned from a great love to the worst hell. {"text": "First chapter looked promising. Nice graphics, amazing atmosphere, perfect mood for horrorish game with puzzle elements. But the longer you play the game the more issues you can discover. There are lots of glitches and game breaking bugs that will force you to start over from beginning. That also means you can't get certain achievements unless you play the entire chapter without dying AND without quiting the game, because reloading the game restores all background props to their original form such as opened doors or destroyed planks. You can't save progress if you select a chapter. You can save the game manually at certain 'checkpoint stations' and the game autosaves randomly between objectives and there is no option to turn the autosave off. Enemy combat is unbalanced and you sometimes hit the enemy and they receive no damage. Opening menu interface during the gameplay may occassionally freeze the screen and you cannot return to game or click any menu options. I once experienced a glitch where the game was unpaused but the menu interface stayed on the screen with ESC key not working anymore at this point, therefore forcing me to manually shut down the game (ALT+F4). It really bothers me because if these bugs were fixed, the game would be perfect. {"text": "This game does a lot of things well. Unfortunately it has the worst short game simulation of any golf game I've ever played, on any platform. {"text": "The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing are not very incredible. Van Helsing starts off strong, fighting enemies in an isometric top-down loot crawler.  Making your way across the country side, killing hordes of enemies feels satisfying.  You are able to upgrade your equipment by swapping out for all this found loot.  There are many fun quirks, NPCs, and side quests to find, explore, and interact with.  Then, what I suspect was the 2nd game, you find yourself in a completely different scenario.  You are less focused on fighting monsters and roaming the countryside and more about this city rebellion, where you are fighting back forces to take back the city.  The break in flow here severely put this gamer off.  No longer did it feel as though I was an explorer / monster hunter, but a lackey attempting to fulfill everyone's orders to keep a city.  It felt too military and not enough fantasy for me.  An entire game of this just to set up what you had already suspected,  Slog past this, and you'll end up with the 3rd game. Finally, the story begins to pick up, and you are back into a fantasy world, minus an odd side-quest to a circus area that adds very little to the story.  At this point, I stopped caring about the side quests and the odd rewards.  Anyone who I interacted with wanted me to do yet another task for them.  I accepted quests with no intention of roaming all the way back to turn them in.  I simply wanted to finish the game, get some back-story and finally figure out why I have been playing this game for the last 50 hours.  As eager as I was to skip so much content, my online partner was even more so, almost skipping past the little tidbits about your ghost companion just to rush through the last phase of the game. So, here we sit, with likely another 10 hours of story left, to find out what happens and who this mysterious Prisoner 7 is,   and not a whole lot of enthusiasm to complete it.  The game starts off promising, then makes me slog through an uninteresting mid-plot.  It has essentially kissed me then punched me in the neither region.  Now, I'm debating if I want to complete the deed, or lock it in the closet and throw away the key.  Hrmm, after this much investment into a love-hate relationship, I might as well see it to the end, even if the climax is disappointment. Looking for that dungeon crawler itch?  Is it your thing?  Pick it up on sale.  Have limited time to play a game, and looking for a beginning to end polished, worth-your-time experience?  I'd say, look elsewhere for a more deserving monster. Online Coop Play Note: I played from the beginning with a friend via online-coop, which was very satisfying (albeit weird to have two Van Helsings, like some weird split personality / clone disorder).  Speaking of online play, if one person skips the dialog, it skips for everyone, so beware if you decide to team up with some stranger online and you are interested in the story.  As for latency, the online aspect was smooth and with little to no problems the entire time. In closing, Van Helsing's play style is solid overall, but with much more filler and non-uniform scenarios that really breaks the immersion and feels like unnecessary padding.  If this game were given another 'cut' with the extras removed, it could be a rich, satisfying game, but like the Ink, I don't see that parallel universe bleeding over into ours any time soon.", "appid": "400170", "steamid": "profiles/76561197987948166", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "25", "votes_funny": "9", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1574856000.0}

{"text": "This game isn't for everyone. If you're into single-player, story-driven content, go play a single-player, story-driven game. It's wrong to completely blast this game as \"‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•\"; however, it is very apparent that it has its issues. Most of the storytelling is pretty bad, with the exception of the Forsaken campaigns and Season of the Dawn story missions. Crucible, although in its best state it has been in two years, is plagued with hackers and unbalanced weapons.  Where this game really shines is its endgame. Compared to its state in Year 1 or the majority of Destiny 1, there is just so much to do now.  Exotic quests, farming for weapons/armor, seasonal quests, the Menagerie, Gambit Prime / Reckoning, pinnacle / ritual weapon quests, dungeons, and perhaps the most impactful, raiding.  There are seven raids in Destiny 2; and the majority of them are very well designed and super fun. The majority of them also award very good loot; for example, Anarchy from Scourge of the Past, One Thousand Voices from LW, Divinity from GoS, and Midnight Coup / Legend of Acrius from Leviathan. Raiding is definitely the reason why I like this game so much; and it's probably one of the best experiences I've had in any video game ever.  This game is evolving. It's constantly being patched and tweaked and new content releases every three months -- keeping the playerbase hooked.  Again, to reiterate, this game isn't for everyone. {"text": "Mordhau was lot of fun during the first month after release, but beyond that, the lethargy of content development and moribund player base has become excruciatingly apparent. The existing build suffers from an abundance of balancing problems with both maps and equipment, and a deficit of stable servers and playable maps. Yes, there are still lots of server issues, even after recent improvements, and most remain capped at 48 instead of the official 64 player limit. Joining one of the few 64 slot servers while they contain more than 54 people will introduce instabilities in performance and constant packet loss. The game lacks any kind of modding tools, and the developers have made it clear that releasing such tools is a low priority for them. The existing 8 maps (4 large for Frontlines and 4 very small for Deathmatch) will get very old very fast for most folks. I'm not counting Crossroads because that map is little more than horses and spawnkilling; having no objectives also means that the only way to end a match on Crossroads is to fully drain your opponents tickets, which takes a long time, being that there is only a single zone to capture. TL,DR I cannot recommend this game in good conscience unless you are willing to accept its numerous problems with balancing, server performance, and lack of modding tools, as well as the likelihood that the game may not be updated beyond its current state. Even then, you may want to look/wait for a sale.", "appid": "629760", "steamid": "profiles/76561197998364683", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "11", "votes_funny": "2", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1564660800.0}

{"text": "Despite the terrible hidden object scenes, I played the game through to the end because I was intrigued by the history of not only the battles, but of the three main characters in the game storyline as well. The character storylines are quite good and very convincing, leading me to believe that these were real people who actually fought in the American Civil War. More on that in a bit.   -Historical information about battles, locations, and generals. Everytime you finish a hidden object \"battle\", you get a little history lesson about the specific battle and which side won the battle, or whether it was a draw. -Storyline. All three main characters have great storylines. The further you progress in the game, the more information you unlock about them. -Decoding letters. This part of the game is actually fun, way more fun than the hidden object scenes. However, it's just too easy. Some of the code letters look almost identical to the encoded letters themselves. There's also overly dramatic music that only plays during these letter decoding sequences, which would seem better suited for a boss fight. -Tiny, & I mean   low-res hidden objects on low-res backgrounds. In one scene in particular, some of the hidden objects are no bigger than a pixel or two. -Hidden objects totally irrelevant for the time period. I've seen this before in other HOG's, and normally it doesn't bother me, but this is a game about a major historical event. Cassette tapes? Car keys? Even a space invader? Come on, this really detracts from gameplay immersion. -Falsified history. I assumed that the three characters were real people, it turns out they were fictional. None of the three characters in this game existed, which is fine, but... Hidden Mysteries: Civil War fails spectacularly as a hidden object game. However, the character storylines and the historical information do add some interest to the game. Unfortunately, some of the historical information is extremely inaccurate. It's definitely not worth full price, probably not worth the 75% off I got it for. Avoid this one.", "appid": "385390", "steamid": "profiles/76561198077867324", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "22", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1449144000.0}

{"text": "trash game.", "appid": "1172470", "steamid": "profiles/76561198972830257", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1605009600.0}
{"text": "Usually, when I review a game, I make sure that I have finished it or at least the story mode. Reviewing Alien Isolation before I have finished the story mode is an exeption. I remember back at 2013-2014 when the game came out, a lot of my favorite YouTubers played it and weren't dissapointed, in fact, they all really liked it and thats why I always wanted to try it myself. But it was always to expensive for me, until recently when the game was -95% off (1.50$) so I got hyped and bought it to finaly try it myself.  The game starts very good, creates a good atmosphere with good sounds and levels, the story also starts promising but I don't want to spoil too much in case you want to buy it. The thing that made me not recommend this game is the fact that the game is extremely boring after the first few missions. It starts very well but thats it, its very boring to play after mission 3 or 4 and there are 18 missions. The story also gets very confussing as I found myself wondering why am I supossed to go there and what am I supossed to do,  happened a few times during my gameplay. The maps are also very very similar, there is nothing new and unique to be seen. You will constantly be walking in circles as the entire game is on the same space ship with the exception of one flashback. It starts well but there is nothing new to be seen or done after, pretty much the entire game (or at least until where I have played which is mission 13th) is the same, go here, do that, don't get killed. Thats it. Which is exactly why I have no plans to finish the game. On the other hand, the game is well made and optimazed, didn't find any major / game breaking glitches, the graphics and the sounds are on a very good level but the confusing and boring plot is the thing that makes me wanna not recommend this game. In my opinion DEFINETLY not worth it on full price (38$). I would recommend buying it if its 10$ or less in case you really want to try it. EDIT: I love collecting Achievements and Trophys which was the main reason I forced myself to finish this game about 1 week after I wrote this review. After finishing it, I still wouldn't recommend it at its default price BUT I will take my word back for saying that the levels are very repetitive and pretty much the same because I did saw some beautiful levels, creating a great atmosphere in the final parts of the game.", "appid": "214490", "steamid": "profiles/76561198160543205", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "3", "votes_funny": "2", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1592481600.0}

{"text": "If you REALLY want to get this game on Steam, buy the XL version. it comes with 8 additional characters who are really fun to play. Also, keep in mind that there is no more new content being released to this game due to the upcoming MK11. But please read the review before considering to buy. Don't get me wrong this is a great game and the graphics are very nice. The fatalities and brutalities are sick. It is fun during the first few weeks but soon you will realize it gets really repetitive. The developers technically make you do the same thing over and over again but just in different ways (faction wars, multiplayer, towers). Initially that is the point of arcade but since NRS and WB don't release any new updates or content on this, I can't recommend it. Not to mention it is very difficult to find opponents in multiplayer due to such a low player base (around 2,000 during sale times and 300-600 during non-sales). Unfortunately, the PC port is the least supported compared to PS4 and Xbox. This game will provide you 40 hours of gameplay at most, but after that its just another one of those obsolete games in your library, which gets occasional visits once in a while. {"text": "It's a bloody mess. I have to admit that I fell for the \"we'll listen to the community feedback\" lie, genuinely thinking that this game would go in the right direction. But it didn't. It went straight into a DLCfest. The season pass doesn't grant you access to all the paid content, Wildrun isn't part of it, and on top of that, it costs almost as much as the game itself. Plus, it gives so little content that it makes no sense to pay that much: a bunch of bikes, new specs made with recycled and/or slightly edited assets and a new gamemode which should be competitive, but in reality it's just about who glitches the most. The physics are broken, the cars don't feel alright at all. The steering capabilities also differ depending on input peripheral, with DirectInput ones having increased precision and steering radius, while keyboard and Xinput pads users get impaired controls. This issue hasn't been fixed, despite being a hot topic on the game's forums. Vehicles aren't many for today's standards and they're terribly unbalanced. While updates fix the handling of some cars, all they do is changing the current kings. On top of that, bikes seem to dominate in almost any spec and they're locked behind a paywall. Despite the major outcry on the forums for more balance, nothing seems to have changed yet. Moreover, the engine sounds are terrible. –ø–æ–Ω—è—Ç–Ω–æ–π —Ü–µ–ª–∏), –∫–∞—Ä—Ç–∏–Ω—ã (–∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã–µ –Ω—É–∂–Ω–æ —Å–±—ã—Ç—å), –∑–∞–Ω—è—Ç—å—Å—è –ø–æ–∏—Å–∫–æ–º –∫—Ä—É–ø–Ω–æ–π –Ω–∞–∂–∏–≤—ã (–∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä–∞—è —Ö–∏—Ç—Ä–æ –∑–∞–ø—Ä—è—Ç–∞–Ω–∞), {"text": "Revised- The game is grindy. I mean that the game's time is padded out by this need to get money quick to fight off demons. Golly ghee, a survival game with padded time? The game adapts a mechanism that has the player use coins to cut down trees. Clearing treed areas allow for farming and wider hunting. Well ghee gamer, that sounds like a decent mechanic. Buggy. Biggest issue. Saves getting corrupt. Here is the resolve as of current.  1. Hold down the windows key and press \"r\" and type in %appdata% and hit enter. 2. This should open up the \"roaming\" folder. 3. Hit the back button one time so you end up in the \"appdata\" folder. 4. Locate and enter the \"locallow\" folder. 5. Locate and delete the \"noio\" folder. 6. Start the game  So, I personally love the game but the bug is a game killer. {"text": "Now, Don't get the vote wrong. I love the game and it's one with the most potential I've ever seen of its own style. I could put the good parts but it would be just spoiling. However, there are some TERRIBLE flaws. Firstly, most minimally: You can't change controls. I'm used to using arrows on the PC VERSION (You'll see why it's uppercase). Second, the control buttons switch from PC to console, even if you're not on console, so if you're new, you won't remember how to, say, put turrets and it's gonna be terribly bad for doing things such as Last Stand, where turrets are VITAL. You can't force to find items, so if you skim over the easier levels, you'll never find basic level items, therefore never finish your collections. The bonuses are almost useless, but still very nice. Now, for the HUGE flaw that wrecks the entire system: I need you to follow me here: SAS4 is available on both   and as mobile app. Of course, the website version is on PC. So, do you think they ported the PC version for a PC game? Nah. Pc game, mobile port. When they could have used the PC version. Now, one could just say: \"Oh, but it's just uncomfortable for you! Many can just play it the same!\" No, the two games are very different. I haven't gone deep in PC game, but there is another currency called \"Alloy\", which gets somewhat more useful in the Black Strongbox part of the game, if I remember. It also helps doing some kind of augments, but I've wrote enough that going back would be a waste. I will maybe update this part if I go further. Also, the entire view of the game is different, done to be just clicks apart, while the mobile version is based on \"scrolling\", which is obviously more practical on mobile. Oh, let's not forget the entire other set of missions on another planet that is on the pc version. Honestly? The game itself is wondrous. Perfectly sculpted missions, the virus has some originality and goes beyond that would be considered \"realistic\", becoming even a DIGITAL virus, infecting many tough bosses. The scaling is perfect, inventing many augments and upgrades to bosses, not just making \"levels\" for zombies. The missions are one more unique than the last and they are all equally entertaining and unique. The bosses themselves are very fun and balanced. An example: The first boss found (And easiest to defeat) is the Regurgitator. High melee damage, an ability to vomit acid and a kind of very fast worms supposed to distract you from the main threat. The Regurgitator is then followed by the Wicker. The wicker is able to summon fireballs from far away to incendiate the player. It is faster, multiplicatively stronger than the Regurgitator and shoots meteors upon death, discouraging close-up fighting with wickers.  Devastators, oh now we're having fun.  Devastators are incredibly more resistant than the wicker. Faster, deals destructingly high damage and goes into a berserk at around 15-20% health and deals ungodly, one-shotting tier damage and becomes practically the fastest unit in the game. They don't come together, no. There's a huge difference from them.  The scaling's beautifully balanced, once again. Infact, if we're considering the game itself, i'd give it like a 8-9/10, maybe 10/10 when I will get into Nightmare mode and Black Strongboxes, but they chose to make it a mobile port. If they choose to modify or change it back to be a PC port, then I'd switch back to recommending it, because it's beautiful.  We need more story development though, I share it with many.", "appid": "678800", "steamid": "profiles/76561198219500180", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "93", "votes_funny": "5", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1512648000.0}
{"text": "I don't even know how to start this. The idea behind the game is kinda innovative and interesting, but that's about it. Short review: Not worth your time or money, just skip this one. Long review: There are 3 bars that make barely any difference and your healt, the one that actually matters. You can attack only when standing which makes dodging impossible. Did I mention that attacking is an automatic mechanic that activates when your standing near an enemy? Yes, you don't need to attack, game does it for you. The levels are extremly linear. There is always only 1 correct way to go and turning to a side street is a dead end. There are also no poiters showing you where to go, which won't matter when you realise you just need to keep moving right. Enemy AI is as basic as it gets, always running at you from all sides. Enemy spawns are random and they spawn endlessly until you reach safe area, which means making a wrong turn forces you to battle 5-6 more \"breeds\". Many game mechanics don't work at all. Example: you do less damage when tired- I kill enemies in 2 hits both when tired and on full energy. Also I found a lot of crates that can't be opened, which is not explained at any point. I believe those to be weapon creates meaning you're stuck with your starter weapon. Animations in this game are quite bad, considering only you and enemies move, and it looks like both you and them have a stick up your butts. The music is generic, nothing more I can say about that. The voice acting was ok, alto there were only 3-4 lines on the game start. Graphics are generic too. I can't choose between unity assets or devs just not trying at all. {"text": "I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME Quick overview: - Entertaining to play with friends - Buggy game - Buggy and flawed mechanics - Bad and incompetent developers with lots of money This game has a massive amount of flaws and the developers have decided that they simply don't care. I play this game for at least an hour every day with friends because it's entertaining enough. But every playthrough is riddled with issues that make it frustrating to play. There's so much that can be done to improve the game, but the developers (who are swimming in money) seem to be incompetent. To further prove their incompetence, their most recent update as of this review has completely broken the game. The game has masses FPS and stuttering problems. The only way to fix this is by disabling the replay and deathcam feature. The ironic part about this is that the replay and deathcam feature are the only way to report cheaters, the very issue Bluehole has been tirelessly trying to address and work on for the past 2 months. That aside, this game is NOT early access anymore. Therefore it is UNACCEPTABLE for a game to have these issues. Bluehole has so much money and yet they are unable to perform basic QA for their game. This is already a big warning sign. The developers are swimming in money and yet seem unable to fix even the most simplest of issues; issues or things that can be changed by someone who just spends an hour watching Unreal Engine tutorials on youtube. Since release, the developers had had only very minor updates and at a snails pace. The only grand amount of content added to the game are just more lootboxes. Hell, even the lootboxes are bad. Not only are they bland (they don't even have a special animation when opening them to give you a thrill), the current lootbox model encourages you to NOT get more lootboxes as they get more expensive to aquire the more you aquire in a week. Let me describe some of the issues and flawed mechanics I've experienced. Get ready for a wall of text. When I shoot someone around medium distance, bullets sometimes tend to go way below the target. This had led to many instances where the bullet decides to hit the ground instead of an enemies head. Bullets travel very slowly and is easily noticeable at meadium distance. Landing with parachutes is usually a game of chance where you will see if you a). Remain suspended in the air for a few seconds before landing, b). Wait to see if you take fall damage or get launched across the floor to take fall damage, or c). Wait to see if you land where you want to land and not end up teleported to let's say the roof or floor. So many instances where you die as soon as you get behind a wall because of bad netcode. So many instances where you shoot someone, but in the deathcam they never took any damage . So many instances where you shoot someone in the face, but the bullet ends up hitting the ground behind your target. So many instances where someone shoots at you without looking at you (not hacking) At the start of the match, looting is complete aids. It usually takes 5 seconds to pick things up, probably due to server lag. It's really frustrating when you land next to an enemy and you are unable to pick up a gun or ammo because the server is taking it's time. The loot distribution is also not competitive. Maybe it's bad luck, but when landing next to a crowd of enemies, my buddies and I never actually end up in buildings with actual weapons (usually just attachments and ammo). One time, throughout 2 matches in a row, I searched over 10 buildings and could not find a single gun. Loot distribution needs more balance and needs to be more competitive. This also includes parts where the zone is across the map and you are unable to find a single vehicle (meaning you will die). But like I said, maybe I'm just unlucky. During a play session, you will most likely have to restart your game every 3 matches. The game has severe flaws when it comes to loading into a match. Usually on the first match we play, one of us has to close our game and relaunch it because they are stuck in the loading screen. Vaulting is very rough. I can't even begin to count the amount of times I died because my character refused to jump out of a window or climb over something The game does not encourage stealth in any way. No matter how you move, your character will stomp their feet around like a teen throwing a fit. The only way to truly be stealthy is by going prone. But prone is the easiest way to get yourself killed. The sounds and sound direction in this game has issues as well. Some things are louder than they should be, while others are quieter than they should be. One time, an enemy player was running right next to me and the sound was never picked up by the game. Sometimes, someone can be walking or shooting near you, but it can be hard to tell the direction because of the sound system (but it happens more with walking than shooting). It's not just me because my friends have these issues too. My headset is a HyperX Cloud II and I can hear probably everything in the game lol. Last night while playing, an enemy threw a grenade into the room I was in and it landed right next to me. I heard the pin being removed, but I never heard the nade being thrown or even land right next to me. Driving is always risky in the game. I don't mean it because other players can hear you and easily blow up your vehicle (if at least 3 spray all their ammo at you), I mean it's risky because it's so easy to end up in a situation where you get ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• by the game world and physics. You could be driving and suddenly an invisible bump will stop the car in it's tracks and damage you. You could be driving, run into something, get stuck in it and have it cause constant damage to your vehicle to the point where it blows up within 2 seconds. You could end up flipping around on the floor and may or may not take damage; all depends on if the game feels like punishing you. There's plenty of more issues with the game. Like I said before, I still play it (only with friends) because it's entertaining. But every play session is frustrating because of the issues it has. Like I said before, some of the improvements that can be made to the game can be easily done by someone who spent a short amount of time watching Unreal Engine tutorials on youtube.  The reason why games like Fortnite are flourshing isn't necessarily because it's free, but instead it's because the developers are actively developing the game, adding to the game, fixing the game, and interacting with the community. Bluehole has done none of the things above, or at least at an extremely slower pace; which is confusing since they're swimming in money thanks to this game.", "appid": "578080", "steamid": "profiles/76561198022696584", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "9", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1519300800.0}

{"text": "I was genuinely hopeful for Deck Casters. A combination of deck-building, RTS, and MOBA sounded like a good concept. The fact that the console version of this game was somewhat successful as well, particularly for a small studio, added further to my interest in the game. I have tried my utmost to get this game running at an optimum level on my rig (i5-4690K, 16GB RAM, Nvidia 980 running Windows 10) which is far and away better than the minimum specs. I was planning to do a gameplay video of the game. I have all of the latest drivers, etc. for my hardware. Unfortunately, the game runs extremely poorly regardless of whatever I try to do with it. I posted my concern with the game's optimisation on the discussion boards here on Steam. Others have asked questions of the developers as well. Sadly, the level of commitment to communication with the potential buyers of the game has been well below par. To put it simply, they have only responded to one comment. It was in regards to the differences between the console and PC ports as they have different names. As   discovered this version of the game has fewer features than the console version. Make sure you read and upvote his review as it features quite a bit of research. Additionally, there has been no launch discount that has been applied to the game which has become standard. This is especially the case for largely multiplayer dependent games from indie developers. The US$16.99 price for the game is a prohibitive barrier of entry for a studio releasing their first game on Steam. I argue that this is especially the case given the recent winter sale. Insofar as this is a single player game, its only intention is to teach the players the fundamentals of gameplay so that you are prepared for the multiplayer. Again, it does a poor job. The actual in-game tutorial is nothing more than a few screens of information. It doesn't teach players new to the genre what they're supposed to do. The actual singleplayer game mode essentially forces the player to learn the game for themselves. It is far too vague and not intuitive for beginners. Unless the developers have a change of attitude, begin making themselves available on the discussion forums, and actually show that they care about their game and its potential player base, you can almost consider this one to be dead on arrival. Unfortunately, I cannot possibly give this game a thumbs up in its current predicament. Should things change I'll be more than happy to revisit my review and make the changes reflective of the game in its (and its community's) state at that time.", "appid": "739050", "steamid": "profiles/76561198062232099", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "29", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1515585600.0}

{"text": "Good game, but is flawed in several ways. The matchmaking is bugged, expect many disconnects. If a player decides to rage quit, you lose any points gathered along with items and even your rank will drop.  Currently there is only one type of objective, which may get old after a while. Fix some generators, open a door and escape while evading a killer. Some variety would be nice.  Some additional balancing should be done on both sides. It can be difficult to get lost as the hunter if the survivors are very coordinated. The game gives some visual cues, but I feel like there could be some more to aid the killer, especially when there is only one survivor left. Small details like giving the survivors more emotion are missing. When struggling on a hook and having a neutral blank face detracts from the mood. {"text": "The combat in this game is neat, but it is entirely designed for one on one combat. However, for some inexplicable reason, this game has been littered with 1v2-3-4 and so on battles around every turn, and it does not play well. Maybe there's options for it somewhere in the menus, but this game's lock on system are unfathomably clunky.  You lock on by tapping the right bumper on controller. To even think about changing targets, you need to hold down that right bumper to enable your right stick to change targets, as they have mechanics already bound to the right stick, like parries. With other games, the lock on system is just a simply click of the stick, and you flick it to change targets. Super easy, super natural. Adding that extra button that needs to be held breaks muscle memory and ruins your flow in an instant. In situations where there are more than two enemies (or just two if they're particularly strong and aggressive) this title is almost unplayable. and it's almost the ENTIRETY of the challenges the game throws your way. Playing with friends would be an upside, but once you get to any actual challenges the game forces you into solo. Maybe things changed with the new expansion, but early game for this title requires true patience. Obviously, these could just be solved by putting in more time and learning to master the systems. If you chose to do this, I would imagine it would take far longer than other games would, based on how 1v1 central the combat is. Maybe one day I'll turn to this game and get really into it, then have to change this review because my third eye opened to how this game really works. For now though, I wanted to have a fun little casual experience with my friends, and there is nothing casual about this title unfortunately. It's just frustrating, and it seems confused on how it should handle enemy encounters, or even control. No discredit to those who chose to stick with this game. You have all of my respect for pushing through and prevailing over these messy systems.", "appid": "473690", "steamid": "profiles/76561198083021042", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1560254400.0}

{"text": "Alien Hallway is a strategy game that follows the tug of war formula presented in popular games such as Swords and Soldiers HD. Unfortunately for Alien Hallway, the game contains bare minimum of features presented in a tug of war game. The maps are hilariously small, with no branching paths. This means that for the majority of the game, you are left sitting on your ass spamming buttons until either you or the alien opponent is defeated. There is no strategy involved in this setup, the miners cost a whopping 10 energy which can be spammed right on cool-down in conjunction with whatever space marine(s) you wish to summon. The polish is absolutely abysmal in this game. Some aliens, specifically melee ones, do not have attack animations. They do damage by simply running or walking into your soldiers. Along with low production value, the game appears to have performance and frame-rate issues when there are too many soldiers and/or aliens on screen at once. This makes Alien Hallway virtually unplayable in the endgame. I pity the fool that spent money on this game. {"text": "I‚Äôve sunk hundreds of hours into turn-based strategy games over the years, and both steampunk and Japanese culture are near and dear to my heart. Being connected to some of my lifelong favorites,   sounded right up my alley. Unfortunately, despite the game‚Äôs many charms, there are some significant detractors that make me hesitant to recommend it, even at a discount. However, if the developers address some of the larger issues in future updates, it is a game I‚Äôd eagerly check out again. The Japanese steampunk tone of the game is mainly set through the art style and character designs. The maps are visually beautiful dioramas that lean into the Japanese aesthetic well. For example, the city signs are a mixture of kanji (iconographic characters), hiragana (phonetic alphabet for native Japanese words and grammar), katakana (phonetic alphabet for foreign words), and romaji (modern English alphabet), exactly what you might see in a Japanese city today. Alongside the buildings are Victorian Era cars and industrial steam technology. Depending on the character, clothing is either steampunk or Japanese. Steampunk clothing elements include top and bowler hats, flat caps, corsets, and aviator goggles. Japanese clothing elements include yukata, geta, and school uniforms. The design of the Hopkins steam robot is particularly well-done. However, some of the female character design choices were puzzling or even questionable. On the puzzling end of the spectrum, there are characters the game refers to as geishas, but those characters do not appear to have the elaborate kimono or hairstyles one would expect to see with geisha. On the questionable end of the spectrum, the named female characters‚Äô body proportions and clothing seem needlessly sexualized. For example, a thong doesn‚Äôt really seem like the most sensible wardrobe choice for guerilla warfare. To get a general feel for the game, I opted to play on easy difficulty. Each chapter‚Äôs map is set up as a three-dimensional model like a tabletop miniature game with each character unit represented by a miniature figure. Each unit has three action points per turn. Some units, like main named characters, will immediately perform their ordered actions on your turn. Other units, like the militia, will carry out their ordered actions after you end your turn, and the computer will move them around along with the enemy and civilian units. Movements like walking or running are animated as sliding like a game piece on a game board, while actions like firing weapons are fully animated. The visually stunning map dioramas, tabletop miniature aesthetic, and fun animations are among the game‚Äôs many charms. The range of camera abilities, from full rotation, zooming, and full control over where to move the camera, allows for a cinematic virtual experience. I did need to lower my mouse sensitivity as much as possible to avoid vertigo. Personally, I thought watching the computer move the camera around during its turn enhanced the tabletop miniature experience, but I understand why that isn‚Äôt everyone‚Äôs cup of tea. However, as mentioned earlier, there are some significant detractors to the gameplay experience. First, the game often doesn‚Äôt provide enough information on how things work to make good strategic decisions, meaning an experimental trial-and-error approach is often required. In and of itself, this wouldn‚Äôt necessarily be a detractor if it weren‚Äôt for the second and third issues of lengthy (1-2 hour) chapters with no checkpoints or way to save, undo, or cancel. The fourth issue is that the AI for your units that the computer moves is a hot mess, often directing your units in a way that ends up contrary to what was desired. Sometimes this even resulted in them becoming frozen and unusable for the remainder of the chapter. For this reason, it would probably have been better to have full control over all of your units‚Äô moves during your turn. It was disheartening to rage-inducing to have to start a chapter yet again after more than an hour because of a failed experimental move, misclick, or the computer moving your units contrary to your orders. The game‚Äôs initial charms grow thin on successful replays. After the second chapter (the first non-tutorial chapter), you get access to TeamBuilder. Although in some respects it seemed intuitive, not understanding what training entailed left me stuck in an untenable position for the third chapter to the point I literally had to backtrack and replay the second chapter yet another time. While I did learn from my failures and successive attempts did go better, the fact that after almost 12 hours on easy difficulty I still haven‚Äôt been able to successfully complete the third chapter has made the gameplay start to feel less like an enjoyable strategic challenge and more of a slog. This is especially true when you consider that the first chapter is a short barebones tutorial. I honestly may have thrown in the towel a while ago if it weren‚Äôt for the fact that I wanted to be sure to give the game a fair chance before reviewing it. To be fair, the story is clearly not the primary focus of the game and is more of a thread loosely tying the combat chapters together. That said, a staggering 3 minute 20 second long introductory cutscene that can only be described as an info dump plays on loading and seems to be where you get most of the story details. Other than that, there is also a short voice-narrated radio broadcast and a short text explanation at the beginning of each chapter. From the database, it appears like there are 8-9 chapters total (it looks like chapter 8 has a part 1 and a part 2), including the first tutorial chapter, but I can‚Äôt say how the story pans out since I haven‚Äôt been able to make it to the end of chapter 3. The music has industrial elements and sounds like it is utilizing traditional Japanese instruments like the koto. The introductory cutscene and the radio broadcast at the beginning of each chapter are the only places with voice acting. The radio broadcast audio is really well-done, perfectly evoking early radio broadcast sound quality and style. The sound effects enhance the animations for different actions in a way that fits the ambience of the game. At the time of this review, the price on Steam is $12.99 USD, and the game has no achievements, bonus content, extras, or trading cards. Current roadblocks to progressing in the game make it impossible to provide an evaluation of the content-to-price ratio. Ultimately, despite  ‚Äôs many charms, the game unfortunately fails to deliver a playable turn-based strategy experience. In its current state, I cannot recommend purchasing this game, although if the developers make future improvements I‚Äôd be eager to give it another try.", "appid": "1153730", "steamid": "profiles/76561198032373667", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "33", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1605700800.0}

{"text": "dont trust trailer game :)", "appid": "227940", "steamid": "profiles/76561198325124020", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1546689600.0}
{"text": "I have put off writing this review for some time, waiting for the updates to fix the bugs. While the updates did stream in eventually, having played much of the Deus Ex series, I found myself disappointed by the latest installment, as well as Square Enix's decision to nickel and dime players of the series. Let me start off by talking about the microtransactions in the game. Firstly, and especially, for a singleplayer game, you'd expect that the DLC items you purchased would be available on all playthroughs. Nope, Square Enix allows you to only use consumables (Praxis Kits, ammo, credits etc.,) once - similar to how some multiplayer games work - which is fairly ridiculous considering the fact that the price of the game and Season Pass aren't low. Add on to the fact that the game allows you to buy - yes, buy with real money - credits and Praxis kits - without having to earn them through your playthrough of the game. While I won't comment on the ethics of this decision, it is extremely offputting that the game shoves these in your face, moreover it being a singleplayer game. Before I forget, they ran an 'Augment your Pre-order' scheme prior to the release of the game encouraging players to preorder the game in exchange for 'rewards' that would unlock everytime the number of pre-orders hit a particular tier. This meant they had such 'rewards' ready, but were intentionally not offering them as part of the game, but as incentives to encourage pre-orders.The silver lining to this is that even without paying for the credits or Praxis kits, I was able to get through the game with a sizable inventory and enough Praxis for augmentations. Continuing on with the story - the game attempts to tell the story of a world that discriminates against Augs following the 'Aug incident'. While at times, the story was convincing, I found it lacking the immersion that was present in the previous games - especially emotionally. Sure, while the environment and the city hubs are much better in general, however, something about it just didn't sit right with me. Without having read the comics, I can safely say that many players will not be well-acquainted with the individuals introduced within the story - Alex, as an example. Unfortunately, the ending was just as lacklustre as that of Deus Ex: Human Revolution, and was incredibly abrupt. After discussing the negatives, I still want to commend certain points in the game. Despite the story being lacklustre at best, the tidbits that are expected to be found in a Deus Ex game are plentiful and generally intriguing in this game. Michael McCann's compositions fits the overall themes of the game and added to the experience fairly well. Gameplay has been greatly improved from Human Revolution, especially if you enjoy waltzing in and shooting enemies in first person mode. I particularly like the fact that they have added new augmentations not present in HR - that increases the choices in terms of playstyle available to Jensen. The many side quests have also been fantastic - ranging in terms of the versatility of such quests, and the rewards you gain from them. With that said, as stoked as I was for the release of this game 5 years after Human Revolution, I am unable to recommend Deus Ex: Mankind Divided. While the game does impress with its improved environment and combat, for what it's worth, as a DX game I feel that the story-telling is an essential element of the game, and one that it cannot fall flat on. Unfortunately, that, and the whole saga with pre-ordering and microtransactions prevent me from recommending this game in good conscience. If you do decide to get the game, you will however, probably still have a lot of fun exploring the environment, completing the main story and side-quests. If you eventually enjoy the game, good for you. If you don't, I hope that this review would have helped in managing your expectations for the game.", "appid": "337000", "steamid": "profiles/76561198008832226", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "144", "votes_funny": "2", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1483012800.0}

–¢—É—Ç –∫—Ä–æ–º–µ –ø–∞—Ä–æ—á–∫–∏ –º–µ—Å—Ç –Ω–∏—á–µ–≥–æ –∏ –Ω–µ—Ç. –õ–∞–¥–Ω–æ, –∏–≥—Ä–∞ –∫–æ—Ä–æ—Ç–∫–∞—è –∏ –º–æ–∂–Ω–æ –±—ã–ª–æ –±—ã —Ä–∞–∑–Ω–æ–æ–±—Ä–∞–∑–∏—Ç—å –µ—ë –¥–µ—Ç–∞–ª—è–º–∏, —Ö–æ—Ç—è –±—ã —Ä–∞–∑–Ω—ã–º–∏ –∑–æ–º–±–∏, –≤—Å–µ —Ç–∞–∫–∏ –º–µ–≥–∞–ø–æ–ª–∏—Å –∏ —á—Ç–æ –≤—ã –¥—É–º–∞–µ—Ç–µ? Hormis cela , c'est beau , c'est plaisant ; mais il n'y a aucune profondeur dans le gameplay .  Comme beaucoup l'ont dit d√©j√† , il suffit d'avoir un enclos avec 3/4 dinosaures et hop l'argent ne sera jamais plus un probl√®me ; le plus difficile (n'ayant crainte cela ne l'est pas) ... FIni Tr√®s peu de b√¢timents , pour un jeu de ce genre c'est bien dommageable . L'impression que tout a √©t√© mis dans les graphismes . Une demi d√©ception , parce que l'univers est r√©ellement plaisant mais cela s'arr√™te h√©las ici .", "appid": "648350", "steamid": "profiles/76561198099052993", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "43", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1573992000.0}
{"text": "For the full review click  Eternity: The Last Unicorn is an action adventure game with a hint of RPG sprinkled on top where the combat is fairly hard compared to an average RPG and that might very well come as a shock for folks who are interested in it solely because they like unicorns. I mean, who doesn‚Äôt? They are magical beings with the power of friendship bracelets and they can stab you in the butt in a heartbeat. It‚Äôs not Dark Souls hard, but it‚Äôs not casual in the least. I have to say the combat honestly isn‚Äôt unfair, it‚Äôs just tough. At least, that is until you get to some of the boss fights. In particular, there is one boss that can nearly ruin the player experience within a few hours of gameplay. That said, the game is not unplayable in the least, but the bigger issue at hand is that you often fight the camera angles and glitches more than the monsters. GAMEPLAY If you can‚Äôt handle a Soulsborne style of combat then I‚Äôd say steer clear of this title. Players are quite vulnerable to attacks as only a few blows will kill you. For Soulsborne vets, this won‚Äôt be an issue. Enemies often gang up on you in groups and you can withstand only a few hits before you are dead. There is a dodge ability, which is quite fast, overly fast even, but it does not always work because you will get stuck on geometry or simply surrounded by enemies and be unable to escape. So your only option is to run backward, try to get the camera to give you some idea of where you are, and wait for them to run after you so you can attack maybe two at a time and survive. There are several issues with the combat. First and foremost is that the camera is fixed and rather difficult to work with. You will have to move in and out of frame just to be able to see what is going on, let alone attack an enemy. Often you will be walking backward and shooting arrows or swinging a sword, hoping for the best because you can‚Äôt see anything in front of you due to the camera. This happens frequently throughout the game, even in boss fights. It‚Äôs as if the game has no regard for the player knowing what is around them. During a boss fight, several times I would try to land an attack while looking straight through the middle section of the boss and no line of sight. There are old games games that do fixed camera position well, like Onimusha, but Eternity: The Last Unicorn‚Äòs attempt to emulate the camera angles of those old games simply does not work at all. There is also a wolf boss about a quarter of the way through the game and it is all out of balance. I honestly rage quit the game after trying to beat it for over an hour. He constantly faces forward so there is no way for a side attack with the sword unless he starts using his special attacks. And if I attacked with a sword he would be less aggressive, yet the sword was nearly impossible to beat him with because I couldn‚Äôt dodge him in time, so using a bow is the best method‚Ä¶.except that you rarely get a chance to move away long enough to charge the bow because the room is too small. You can tell it‚Äôs too small because the wolf boss glitches out now and then as he backs up. You‚Äôll need to grind at least 4-5 more levels and carry a unicorn‚Äôs buttload of health with you to be able to beat it. This is not good since most folks will arrive at this boss at roughly lvl 10-11, and they will need to be a lvl 14-15 in order to beat that wolf. Expect the wolf boss to be harder to beat than pretty much all of the bosses after him, I kid you not. On the subject of bosses, I feel they often have hitboxes that are extra wide, so even if you dodge you will still likely get hit unless there is some additional space between you and the boss. Not all bosses were like this, but many at least felt like this. Dodginig into the boss seemed to help sometimes. It could be they have a longer invincibility frame or something. Half my dodges would not work against some of them, even though they worked fine against mid-bosses. Granted, being able to dodge is assuming you can see the space between you and the enemies because the camera angle makes it so that it can be difficult to trust your depth perception. Even knowing where the edge of the arena is can be tough because of the camera angle, and you‚Äôll take damage because while it may look like you are far enough away from the boss to avoid getting hit, you actually aren‚Äôt. On top of that, they have incredible amounts of health, meaning it could take forever as you chip away with 1-2% attacks to defeat them if you are even slightly underleveled. Expect to be dodging and kiting for ages with weapons that do very little damage unless you grind a lot to get OP and even then it‚Äôs still a kite-n-slash drawn out dance-a-thon. Another issue is that most of the boss battle arenas are too small, making it hard to dodge because, just like the regular enemies and bosses, you too can get stuck on geometry. I had two instances where my character was jammed on some geometry like a tree root or something, unable to attack or dodge while the enemy quickly killed me. I also had an instance in the Jotundrir Cave where my character, Bior, simply refused to attack any more and just stood still in the water. He would also occasionally disappear in the water while dodging, though still be vulnerable to attacks. The swamp tentacle boss just glitched out on me and froze, but at least my character could stand there and shoot arrows endlessly until it died. When fighting Naglfar the Viking, I found there was a location near the front of the arena where Bior would freeze up and get killed. That happened twice and it sucked because that was one of the few camera angles where I could judge my distance from the boss correctly.  When fighting with Aurehen in the Fallen Woods, I switched to a sword and suddently the sword disappeared and she started whacking monsters with her bow, even though I had the sword correctly selected in the weapon guide in the left corner of the screen.  Also, Aurehen froze in place when going back to the Valkyrie, who apparently only said to give my Wisdom move a try.  It was a very frustrating playthrough. Backtracking is an intrinsic aspect of the game, so expect to be running around in the same areas repeatedly for a fetch quest of some kind, fighting the same group of monsters over and over, and then finally getting some sort of unlock only to repeat the process again. It‚Äôs helpful to level up, but beyond that, the game just gets repetitive really fast because the game world is simply not all that interesting. That leaves the player with mostly trying to enjoy the combat as the sole reason for continuing as running in circles is a chore and while there are some unlockable hidden areas, the payoffs are just not particularly thrilling. I sort of liked the combat. It‚Äôs not easy and that‚Äôs fine by me, but I just didn‚Äôt think the storyline and experiences with enemies and bosses were worth the effort to continue playing for long. VERDICT While I see lots of folks complain about the combat, I don‚Äôt see that as the main issue. {"text": "Let's Division 2 back on Steam", "appid": "365590", "steamid": "profiles/76561197992135975", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "24", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1547035200.0}
{"text": "Nekoboom is a rhythm game that appears to have been made with RPG Maker MV, this is not confirmed, but the menus have a style that looks like its from RPG Maker, as the ‚Äúregistered buttons‚Äù which include the arrow keys, and ASZX the keys. Despite what people associate RPG Maker games to be, this game does not follow the mold at all. It looks like quite some work was put into the game to make it have rhythm game controls, and the characters look like they were custom drawn for the game specifically, even the character you control looks like was given a custom walking animation to fit the model. The story‚Ä¶as best as I can piece, is that you have been locked in a prison for some type of accident caused by some type of special power that lay latent in you, but you are unaware. You travel through, and fight your way out, and your backstory is you were a commander of some type of squad. The reason the story sounds quite are, are translations issues, sentences making little coherent sense and some very ‚Äúinteresting‚Äù random dialogue lines. Translation and lack of coherence aside, some text boxes have far too much text and the text sometimes comes out of the boxes. The game plays much like any other rhythm game, having lanes that run from left to right rather than from top to bottom, and while most rhythm games have a specific key allotted per lane and you must press that key per note on said lane, this one is a bit different in this regard. Where most games vary on difficulty by adjusting the speed/BPM to be quicker, this one seems to have a consistent beat, and instead when you begin you only have one bar of ‚Äúnotes‚Äù and as you progress, you will be upgraded to having to keep track of 4 bars. The main issue with having 4 bars and 8 different keys to press is that you are bound to make mistakes quite often unintentionally. The main issue with making mistakes is that you have no clear indication as to how many errors you may make, or how your health is looking like. The last biggest issue I had with the gameplay was the creation of artificial difficulty when facing the final boss, since as the game progresses, enemies obviously have more health than enemies in the beginning, but if you make any errors in the final boss battle, you are given a game over. Coupled with the 8 keys and a one shot death, the game became quite tedious, though if it did not have this ridiculous battle, the game would have been quite short, about half an hour max perhaps. Sadly this is not the best areas, the characters one their own during dialogue look, well some better than others, not the worst looking, nor best looking, pretty decent art compared to the character models. The character models, npc wise, do tend to have some odd idle animations, looping abruptly and looking out of place. Your own character model on the other hand, feels stiff when walking, and a bit off, likely from self animating it, but an okay attempt for a first try at a game. The soundtrack, a grand total of two songs, one for when you are out of battle and the other while in battle, so it does feel a bit repetitive hearing the same song throughout, especially for the final battle. Overall, while I applaud the work the devs seem to have put, and how proud they seem to be of their first work, it‚Äôs a start, though I sadly cannot recommend it based on the issues above. It is an interesting start, as not many rhythm games are made, but visuals and sounds apart, the gameplay was the least appealing aspect in the sense of its unforgiving difficulty spike, and abundance of keys to press for rhythm.  Verdict: 2/10 If you like this review please follow our curator", "appid": "852210", "steamid": "profiles/76561198199595411", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "96", "votes_funny": "8", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1527940800.0}

Long story short, he infects Heller with the same virus that he has himself. Deemed the ‚ÄúMercer Virus‚Äù or as it was called previously, the Blacklight virus. He doesn't really state why he has done what he's done. Nevertheless, the events of the game unfold.  I did mention the Hulk specifically because of the game ‚ÄúThe Incredible Hulk: Ultimate Destruction‚Äù‚Äîwhich is awesome, one of my favorites‚Äîand this game is made by the same people. [For some reason I equate that game being on Gamecube the most despite it being on all the consoles of that time.] Regardless, ‚ÄúRadical Entertainment‚Äù shortly had layoffs after this game's [Prototype 2] release. They still exist and are currently (Nov 2020) owned by Activision. But I think I can see what went wrong with this title. Topical issues aside regarding viruses, I think the premise of a viral outbreak is a good setting for a game. I personally really found uncovering the mystery and nature of the virus in The Division to be one of its stronger features. But in Prototype, it's really not terribly interesting. The virus essentially makes you into a zombie-esque thing or makes you into a superhuman. Like an approximation of Carnage the symbiote from Spider-Man but with the versatility of T-1000. The combat is... while a tad goofy, has its moments. ‚ÄúPhase One‚Äù brawlers to ‚ÄúPhase Two‚Äù‚Äînot-Bane super-soldiers. (The enemy has neon blue tubes going into the back of their massive head. If they aren't inspired by Bane, call me incredulous.) All the way up to Juggernauts and Goliaths‚Äîsmall building sized enemies. They all have certain ways to deal with them. And the weapon selection is quite decent. Though, once you get to the more interesting weapons, the game is almost over. You'll have claws, a big blade, a whip, big rock hands that you can smash tanks with. But these all take time to unlock. This was one of the more interesting ideas in Prototype 1. When you   consumed people, you gain their memories. Filling out a ‚ÄúWeb of Intrigue‚Äù. Though, it never really goes anywhere interesting. Consuming DNA also gets you to level up. It's pretty much that simple. Because you're a symbiote of sorts, you can change into the people you consume. Strait down to their DNA. This is   often required to get into facilities and complete other objectives. This task is repeated ad nauseam. Changing your disguise also aids in escape. Made easier than the first game by clearly prompting you when you've broken line of sight. Prototype 1 has real issues with that. Heller (as well as Mercer) are people who can literally throw cars at helicopters. While running. On the   of a skyscraper. While being shot with missiles. Why on Earth would a steel door stop them? In the rare case that subtlety is needed‚Äîas in, to not scare away a target that you need the memories of, it makes sense. But these moments often end in chaos anyways. Just like every mission. Better to simply barge in. You're also able to stealth consume people   being watched. Immediately taking their position. It just seems like there was so many ideas about stealth that ultimately came to nothing because everything ends with a giant monster throwing helicopters regardless.", "appid": "115320", "steamid": "profiles/76561198064850410", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "19", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1604318400.0}

{"text": "A peculiar game with absurdist humour. Which in my opinion is its main redeeming quality. Gameplay: You play as a cat in the turkey castle/headquarters trying to find your way around. There's very little explaining and lacks any tutorial or even a keymap setting in order to check the keys out. Apparently it uses WASD and Q/E/R but you have to stumble on your own pressing random keys until you figure out what does what. You have your main sword attack, a ranged attack that has limited ammo and mousetraps that are even more limited. It is possible there's something else in your arsenal that I did not manage to find. Combat in itself feels VERY clunky which is something that makes the game difficult. I do enjoy difficult games but only when said difficulty is not based on clunky controls and animations but actual gameplay difficulty. The game feels very much rushed which is evident when you find a huge bug at the first minute of playing. Running to the corridor to the far right, from the first room you start in, makes you fall through the geometry and respawn at the start. This is 100% repeatable and you can't help but wonder how something this huge went by unnoticed? Other than that, gameplay, once you get the hang of it, feels very repetitive. Graphics: Graphics-wise the game is mediocre. It is made with Unity engine and I'm pretty sure I've seen some artwork assets (eg the protagonist's armor) in several other projects. There are very few graphical settings (mainly Resolution, Fullscreen, VSync and AA toggle) and only the turkeys look very good in my opinion. Music/Sound Design: While music quality is decent it is also quite repetitive and gets old fast. Very fast. Sound effects are good. Pros: -Funny. Neutral: -Some artwork assets do not look original. Cons: -Clunky combat -Very repetitive gameplay. -Repetitive music. -Very high price for what it is. Conclusion: I can not recommend this game at its current price of 14 Euro. Perhaps bundled or on sale for the comedy value alone. Score: Gameplay:\t\t4/10 Graphics:\t\t        5/10 Music/Sound:\t        5/10 Concept/Story:\t6/10 More game reviews @", "appid": "565540", "steamid": "profiles/76561197984799260", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "10", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1489752000.0}
